{"timeCrawl": "22:38:00", "uri": "710010100", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T22:38:00Z", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "source": {"title": "enca.com", "uri": "enca.com", "id": "147"}, "url": "http://www.enca.com/money/air-berlin-files-for-insolvency-but-keeps-flying", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "FRANKFURT AM MAIN - Germany's Air Berlin announced Tuesday that it had filed for insolvency after its main shareholder Etihad Airways said it would not plough any more cash into the troubled carrier.\n\nThe German government said it was providing a bridging loan of 150 million euros (R2.3 billion) to keep the airline flying at a time when many Germans are still on holiday.\n\nGerman rival Lufthansa said in a separate announcement it was in talks with Air Berlin to take over parts of the group.\n\nAir Berlin has long battled for survival, booking losses amounting to 1.2 billion euros over the past two years and relying on cash infusions from Etihad.\n\nIn a surprise announcement, the airline said it had filed for insolvency with the court of Berlin-Charlottenburg after Etihad \"notified Air Berlin PLC of the fact that it will not provide any further financial support to the Air Berlin group\".\n\nEtihad, which holds a 29.2-percent stake in Air Berlin, said that the development was \"extremely disappointing\" but it could no longer justify further funding after providing an additional 250 million euros in April.\n\n\"Air Berlin's business has continued to deteriorate at an unprecedented rate, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges,\" the Abu Dhabi-based company said.\n\nGerman Economy Minister Brigitte Zypries told a hastily assembled press conference that the government was assisting Air Berlin with a loan to prevent passengers from being stranded during the busy holiday season.\n\n\"To keep Air Berlin's flight operations going, the government has decided to grant a bridging loan for 150 million euros,\" she told reporters.\n\nThe money should be enough to keep Germany's second-largest airline running \"for three months\", she said, adding that flights would go ahead as scheduled and that new tickets could still be booked.\n\nMonopoly\n\nIn a bid to turn the tide, the Berlin carrier embarked on an extensive restructuring plan last year that included leasing 38 aircraft with crew to Lufthansa and slashing 1,200 jobs -- or one in seven of its workforce.\n\nAmid the restructuring, it was hit by a series of flight cancellations and severe delays, leading to a flood of complaints.\n\nLufthansa said it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the Air Berlin Group and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff\".\n\nAir Berlin said the talks with Lufthansa \"and other partners\" about acquiring its assets were already far advanced.\n\nThe insolvency proceedings mark the latest setback for Etihad, which has been struggling for years to make inroads in the European market through its Air Berlin and Alitalia subsidiaries, both battling heavy competition from low-cost competitors.\n\nAlitalia, in which Etihad holds a 49-percent stake, went into administration in May after employees refused to accept job and salary cuts as part of a new rescue plan.\n\nRyanair, meanwhile, was sharply critical of the government support for Air Berlin and said it had lodged complaints with Germany's competition authority and the European Commission.\n\nThe Irish no-frills airline claimed there was an \"obvious conspiracy\" playing out between the German government, Lufthansa and Air Berlin, to carve up the latter's assets while excluding competitors.\n\nTravellers in Germany will suffer higher prices as a result of the \"Lufthansa monopoly\", Ryanair said in a statement.\n\nHot potato\n\nOn Germany's DAX index of leading firms, Lufthansa soared to the top of the leaders board, rising 4.73 percent to 20.59 euros at the close.\n\nShares in Air Berlin, not listed on the Dax, plunged more than 35 percent to 0.51 euros.\n\nGermany's giant services-sector union Verdi responded with dismay to Air Berlin's decision to file for administration.\n\n\"This is a heavy blow for Air Berlin employees,\" said Verdi board member Christine Behle.\n\n\"Our priority now is to secure jobs. Air Berlin must proceed with the utmost transparency and provide all necessary information.\"\n\nThe pilots' union Cockpit said the Air Berlin news came as \"a shock\".\n\nIt welcomed the government's help in minimising the disruption over the coming months, but it accused Etihad of making the wrong strategic and management decisions and turning its back on Air Berlin workers.\n\n\"Etihad is dropping Air Berlin like a hot potato,\" it said.\n\nAir Berlin said two members of its board of directors who had been nominated by Etihad had resigned.", "id": "9369305", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "12:28:00", "uri": "709758028", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T12:13:00Z", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "source": {"title": "Associated Press", "uri": "hosted2.ap.org", "id": "566"}, "url": "http://hosted2.ap.org/CARIE/0260ea4c3e85456b80715585ba3c7b5b/Article_2017-08-15-EU-Germany-Air-Berlin/id-7b4e1146fa084603bfcfcba91f745141", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "BERLIN (AP) -- Germany's second largest carrier, Air Berlin, is filing for bankruptcy protection after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad, said it would make no more financing available.\n\nThe loss-making airline said Tuesday that after Etihad pulled funding, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin.\"\n\nTo allay travelers' fears that they could be stranded on summer holiday, the German government immediately said it would provide a loan of 150 million euros ($177 million) so the airline it can continue flights for the time being.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travelers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the Economy and Transport ministries said in a statement. \"The return flights of these travelers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nEconomy Minister Brigitte Zypries later told reporters the money was expected to last for three months.\n\nUnion ver.di called it a \"severe blow\" for the more-than 7,000 employees of Air Berlin.\n\n\"Our priority now lies with securing the jobs,\" said Christine Behle, a union board director. \"Air Berlin must proceed with transparency and provide all important information.\"\n\nAir Berlin has been posting losses for years. It has been restructuring its operations and has been kept aloft in recent years by Etihad, which holds a 29.2 percent stake.\n\nIn December, German rival Lufthansa's Eurowings and Austrian Airlines units reached a deal to lease 38 planes from Air Berlin.\n\nFollowing the bankruptcy announcement, Lufthansa said it was \"supporting the restructuring efforts of the airline jointly with the German government\" and that its leased aircraft would continue operating as before.\n\nLufthansa, Germany's largest airline, said it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the Air Berlin group and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff.\"\n\nZypries said that the bridge loan \"should give enough time for the negotiations to be brought to a conclusion.\"\n\nThe German transport and economy ministries said Air Berlin had been in negotiations with Lufthansa \"and another airline\" for a long time.\n\nEtihad Airways said the bankruptcy filing was \"extremely disappointing for all parties,\" especially as it had supported the airline over six years, but that it could not continue pumping money into a loss-making business.\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" it said.\n\nIt said it pumped 250 million euros of additional funding into Air Berlin as recently as in April and helped it \"explore strategic options\" for its business. It said the German carrier's business has \"deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\nThe Emirati national airline said it continues to have codeshares and other business relationships with Air Berlin and will support its management.\n\nAir Berlin's decision comes three and a half months after another Etihad-backed European carrier, Alitalia, entered its second round of bankruptcy protection in a decade.\n\nEtihad said at the time that Alitalia needed a \"fundamental and far-reaching restructuring\" and it was not prepared to keep pumping money into the struggling Italian airline.\n\n____\n\nKirsten Grieshaber in Berlin and Adam Schreck in Dubai contributed to {"timeCrawl": "10:25:00", "uri": "710250718", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T16:49:00Z", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "source": {"title": "The Star Online", "uri": "thestar.com.my", "id": "334"}, "url": "http://www.thestar.com.my/business/business-news/2017/08/16/air-berlin-files-for-insolvency-but-keeps-flying/", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "FRANKFURT: Germany's Air Berlin announced Tuesday that it had filed for insolvency after its main shareholder Etihad Airways said it would not plough any more cash into the troubled carrier.\n\nThe German government said it was providing a bridging loan of 150 million euros (RM756.2mil) to keep the airline flying at a time when many Germans are still on holiday.\n\nGerman rival Lufthansa said in a separate announcement it was in talks with Air Berlin to take over parts of the group.\n\nAir Berlin has long battled for survival, booking losses amounting to 1.2 billion euros (RM6.05bil) over the past two years and relying on cash infusions from Etihad.\n\nIn a surprise announcement, the airline said it had filed for insolvency with the court of Berlin-Charlottenburg after Etihad \"notified Air Berlin PLC of the fact that it will not provide any further financial support to the Air Berlin group\".\n\nEtihad, which holds a 29.2% stake in Air Berlin, said that the development was \"extremely disappointing\" but that it could no longer justify further funding after providing an additional 250 million euros in April.\n\n\"Air Berlin's business has continued to deteriorate at an unprecedented rate, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges,\" the Abu Dhabi-based company said.\n\nGerman Economy Minister Brigitte Zypries told a hastily assembled press conference that the government was assisting Air Berlin with a loan to prevent passengers from being stranded during the busy holiday season.\n\n\"To keep Air Berlin's flight operations going, the government has decided to grant a bridging loan for 150 million euros,\" she told reporters.\n\nThe money should be enough to keep Germany's second-largest airline running \"for three months\", she said, adding that flights would go ahead as scheduled and that new tickets could still be booked.\n\n'Monopoly'\n\nIn a bid to turn the tide, the Berlin carrier embarked on an extensive restructuring plan last year that included leasing 38 aircraft with crew to Lufthansa and slashing 1,200 jobs -- or one in seven of its workforce.\n\nAmid the restructuring, it was hit by a series of flight cancellations and severe delays, leading to a flood of complaints.\n\nLufthansa said it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the Air Berlin Group and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff\".\n\nAir Berlin said the talks with Lufthansa \"and other partners\" about acquiring its assets were already far advanced.\n\nThe insolvency proceedings mark the latest setback for Etihad, which has been struggling for years to make inroads in the European market through its Air Berlin and Alitalia subsidiaries, both battling heavy competition from low-cost competitors.\n\nAlitalia, in which Etihad holds a 49% stake, went into administration in May after employees refused to accept job and salary cuts as part of a new rescue plan.\n\nThe Irish no-frills airline Ryanair, meanwhile, was sharply critical of the government support for Air Berlin, which it said paved the way for Lufthansa to acquire Air Berlin in what would amount to anti-competitive behaviour.\n\nTravellers in Germany will suffer higher prices as a result of the \"Lufthansa monopoly\", Ryanair spokesman Robin Kiely was quoted as telling the German news agency DPA.\n\n'Hot potato'\n\nOn Germany's DAX index of leading firms, Lufthansa soared to the top of the leaders board, rising 4.73% to 20.59 euros at the close.\n\nShares in Air Berlin, not listed on the Dax, plunged more than 35% to 0.51 euros.\n\nGermany's giant services-sector union Verdi responded with dismay to Air Berlin's decision to file for administration.\n\n\"This is a heavy blow for Air Berlin employees,\" said Verdi board member Christine Behle.\n\n\"Our priority now is to secure jobs. Air Berlin must proceed with the utmost transparency and provide all necessary information.\"\n\nThe pilots' union Cockpit said the Air Berlin news came as \"a shock\".\n\nIt welcomed the government's help in minimising the disruption over the coming months, but it accused Etihad of making the wrong strategic and management decisions and turning its back on Air Berlin workers.\n\n\"Etihad is dropping Air Berlin like a hot potato,\" it said.\n\nAir Berlin said two members of its board of directors, who were nominated by Etihad, had resigned. - AFP", "id": "9454046", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "16:42:00", "uri": "709871723", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T16:42:00Z", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "source": {"title": "Channel NewsAsia", "uri": "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "FRANKFURT AM MAIN: Germany's Air Berlin announced on Tuesday (Aug 15) that it had filed for insolvency after its main shareholder Etihad Airways said it would not plough any more cash into the troubled carrier.\n\nThe German government said it was providing a bridging loan of \u20ac150 million (US$175 million) to keep the airline flying at a time when many Germans are still on holiday.\n\nGerman rival Lufthansa said in a separate announcement it was in talks with Air Berlin to take over parts of the group.\n\nAir Berlin has long battled for survival, booking losses amounting to \u20ac1.2 billion over the past two years and relying on cash infusions from Etihad.\n\nIn a surprise announcement, the airline said it had filed for insolvency with the court of Berlin-Charlottenburg after Etihad \"notified Air Berlin PLC of the fact that it will not provide any further financial support to the Air Berlin group\".\n\nEtihad, which holds a 29.2 per cent stake in Air Berlin, said that the development was \"extremely disappointing\" but that it could no longer justify further funding after providing an additional \u20ac250 million in April.\n\n\"Air Berlin's business has continued to deteriorate at an unprecedented rate, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges,\" the Abu Dhabi-based company said.\n\nGerman Economy Minister Brigitte Zypries told a hastily assembled press conference that the government was assisting Air Berlin with a loan to prevent passengers from being stranded during the busy holiday season.\n\n\"To keep Air Berlin's flight operations going, the government has decided to grant a bridging loan for 150 million euros,\" she told reporters.\n\nThe money should be enough to keep Germany's second-largest airline running \"for three months\", she said, adding that flights would go ahead as scheduled and that new tickets could still be booked.\n\n'MONOPOLY'\n\nIn a bid to turn the tide, the Berlin carrier embarked on an extensive restructuring plan last year that included leasing 38 aircraft with crew to Lufthansa and slashing 1,200 jobs - or one in seven of its workforce.\n\nAmid the restructuring, it was hit by a series of flight cancellations and severe delays, leading to a flood of complaints.\n\nLufthansa said it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the Air Berlin Group and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff\".\n\nAir Berlin said the talks with Lufthansa \"and other partners\" about acquiring its assets were already far advanced.\n\nThe insolvency proceedings mark the latest setback for Etihad, which has been struggling for years to make inroads in the European market through its Air Berlin and Alitalia subsidiaries, both battling heavy competition from low-cost competitors.\n\nAlitalia, in which Etihad holds a 49 per cent stake, went into administration in May after employees refused to accept job and salary cuts as part of a new rescue plan.\n\nThe Irish no-frills airline Ryanair, meanwhile, was sharply critical of the government support for Air Berlin, which it said paved the way for Lufthansa to acquire Air Berlin in what would amount to anti-competitive behaviour.\n\nTravellers in Germany will suffer higher prices as a result of the \"Lufthansa monopoly\", Ryanair spokesman Robin Kiely was quoted as telling the German news agency DPA.\n\n'HOT POTATO'\n\nOn Germany's DAX index of leading firms, Lufthansa soared to the top of the leaders board, rising 4.73 per cent to \u20ac20.59 at the close.\n\nShares in Air Berlin, not listed on the Dax, plunged more than 35 per cent to \u20ac0.51.\n\nGermany's giant services-sector union Verdi responded with dismay to Air Berlin's decision to file for administration.\n\n\"This is a heavy blow for Air Berlin employees,\" said Verdi board member Christine Behle. \"Our priority now is to secure jobs. Air Berlin must proceed with the utmost transparency and provide all necessary information.\"\n\nThe pilots' union Cockpit said the Air Berlin news came as \"a shock\".\n\nIt welcomed the government's help in minimising the disruption over the coming months, but it accused Etihad of making the wrong strategic and management decisions and turning its back on Air Berlin workers.\n\n\"Etihad is {"timeCrawl": "12:33:00", "uri": "709760102", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T12:03:00Z", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "source": {"title": "National Post", "uri": "nationalpost.com", "id": "973"}, "url": "http://nationalpost.com/pmn/news-pmn/german-carrier-air-berlin-filing-for-bankruptcy/wcm/05ca32cd-31dd-4af2-90a5-649a0ae99e72", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "BERLIN -- Germany's second largest carrier, Air Berlin, is filing for bankruptcy protection after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad, said it would make no more financing available.\n\nThe loss-making airline said Tuesday that after Etihad pulled funding, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin.\"\n\nTo allay travellers' fears that they could be stranded on summer holiday, the German government immediately said it would provide a loan of 150 million euros ($177 million) so the airline it can continue flights for the time being.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travellers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the Economy and Transport ministries said in a statement. \"The return flights of these travellers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nEconomy Minister Brigitte Zypries later told reporters the money was expected to last for three months.\n\nUnion ver.di called it a \"severe blow\" for the more-than 7,000 employees of Air Berlin.\n\n\"Our priority now lies with securing the jobs,\" said Christine Behle, a union board director. \"Air Berlin must proceed with transparency and provide all important information.\"\n\nAir Berlin has been posting losses for years. It has been restructuring its operations and has been kept aloft in recent years by Etihad, which holds a 29.2 per cent stake.\n\nIn December, German rival Lufthansa's Eurowings and Austrian Airlines units reached a deal to lease 38 planes from Air Berlin.\n\nFollowing the bankruptcy announcement, Lufthansa said it was \"supporting the restructuring efforts of the airline jointly with the German government\" and that its leased aircraft would continue operating as before.\n\nLufthansa, Germany's largest airline, said it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the Air Berlin group and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff.\"\n\nZypries said that the bridge loan \"should give enough time for the negotiations to be brought to a conclusion.\"\n\nThe German transport and economy ministries said Air Berlin had been in negotiations with Lufthansa \"and another airline\" for a long time.\n\nEtihad Airways said the bankruptcy filing was \"extremely disappointing for all parties,\" especially as it had supported the airline over six years, but that it could not continue pumping money into a loss-making business.\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" it said.\n\nIt said it pumped 250 million euros of additional funding into Air Berlin as recently as in April and helped it \"explore strategic options\" for its business. It said the German carrier's business has \"deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\nThe Emirati national airline said it continues to have codeshares and other business relationships with Air Berlin and will support its management.\n\nAir Berlin's decision comes three and a half months after another Etihad-backed European carrier, Alitalia, entered its second round of bankruptcy protection in a decade.\n\nEtihad said at the time that Alitalia needed a \"fundamental and far-reaching restructuring\" and it was not prepared to keep pumping money into the struggling Italian airline.\n\n-- -- -\n\nKirsten Grieshaber in Berlin and Adam Schreck in Dubai contributed to {"timeCrawl": "12:05:00", "uri": "709745801", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T12:05:00Z", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "source": {"title": "Daily Journal", "uri": "dailyjournal.net", "id": "141"}, "url": "http://www.dailyjournal.net/2017/08/15/eu-germany-air-berlin/", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "BERLIN -- Germany's second largest carrier, Air Berlin, is filing for bankruptcy after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad, said it would make no more financing available.\n\nThe loss-making airline said Tuesday that after Etihad pulled funding, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin.\"\n\nTo allay travelers' fears that they could be stranded on summer holiday, the German government immediately said it would provide a loan of 150 million euros ($177 million) so the airline it can continue flights for the time being.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travelers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the Economy and Transport ministries said in a joint statement. \"The return flights of these travelers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nAir Berlin has been posting losses for years and has a debt of 1.2 billion euros. It has recently been restructuring its operations to try and stay in business and has been kept aloft in recent years by Etihad, which holds a 29.2 percent share.\n\nIn December, German rival Lufthansa's Eurowings and Austrian Airlines units reached a deal to lease 38 planes from Air Berlin.\n\nFollowing the bankruptcy announcement, Lufthansa said it was \"supporting the restructuring efforts of the airline jointly with the German government\" and that its leased aircraft would continue operating as before.\n\nLufthansa, Germany's largest airline, said it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the Air Berlin group and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff.\"\n\nThe German transport and economy ministries said Air Berlin had been in negotiations with Lufthansa \"and another airline\" for a long time.\n\nEtihad Airways said the bankruptcy was \"extremely disappointing for all parties,\" especially as it had supported the airline over six years.\n\nIt said it pumped 250 million euros of additional funding into Air Berlin as recently as in April and helped it \"explore strategic options\" for its business. It said the German carrier's business has \"deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" it said.\n\nThe Emirati national airline said it continues to have codeshares and other business relationships with Air Berlin and will support its management.\n\n\"Germany is an important market for Etihad and Abu Dhabi, and we remain committed to providing comprehensive air links as a key enabler of trade and tourism,\" it said.\n\nAir Berlin's decision comes three and a half months after another Etihad-backed European carrier, Alitalia, entered its second round of bankruptcy protection in a decade.\n\nEtihad said at the time that Alitalia needed a \"fundamental and far-reaching restructuring\" and it was not prepared to keep pumping money into the struggling Italian {"timeCrawl": "15:36:00", "uri": "709842041", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T15:36:00Z", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "source": {"title": "Channel NewsAsia", "uri": "channelnewsasia.com", "id": "1555"}, "url": "http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/business/air-berlin-files-for-insolvency--flights-to-keep-going-9125876", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "FRANKFURT AM MAIN: Germany's Air Berlin on Tuesday announced it had filed for insolvency after its main shareholder Etihad Airways said it would not plough any more cash into the troubled airline.\n\nThe German government said it was providing a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($175 million) to keep the carrier flying at a time when many Germans are still on holiday.\n\nGerman rival Lufthansa said in a separate announcement it was in talks with Air Berlin to take over parts of the group.\n\nAir Berlin has long battled for survival, booking losses amounting to 1.2 billion euros over the past two years and relying on cash infusions from Etihad.\n\nIn a surprise announcement, the German airline said it had filed for insolvency with the court of Berlin-Charlottenburg after Etihad \"notified Air Berlin PLC of the fact that it will not provide any further financial support to the Air Berlin group\".\n\nEtihad, which holds a 29.2-percent stake in Air Berlin, said the development was \"extremely disappointing\" but that it could no longer justify further funding after providing an additional 250 million euros in April.\n\n\"Air Berlin's business has continued to deteriorate at an unprecedented rate, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges,\" the Abu Dhabi-based company said.\n\nGerman Economy Minister Brigitte Zypries told a hastily assembled press conference that the government was assisting Air Berlin with a bridging loan to prevent passengers from being stranded during the busy holiday season.\n\n\"To keep Air Berlin's flight operations going, the government has decided to grant a bridging loan for 150 million euros,\" she told reporters.\n\nThe money should be enough to keep Air Berlin running \"for three months\", she said, adding that flights would go ahead as scheduled and that new tickets could still be booked.\n\nIn a bid turn to the tide, Germany's second-largest airline embarked on a massive restructuring plan last year that included leasing 38 aircraft with crew to Lufthansa and slashing 1,200 jobs - or one in seven of its workforce.\n\nAmid the restructuring, it was hit by a series of flight cancellations and severe delays, leading to a flood of complaints.\n\nLufthansa said it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the Air Berlin Group and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff\".\n\nAir Berlin said the talks with Lufthansa \"and other partners\" about acquiring its assets were already far advanced.\n\nThe insolvency proceedings mark the latest setback for Etihad which has been struggling for years to make inroads in the European market through its Air Berlin and Alitalia subsidiaries, both battling heavy competition from low-cost competitors.\n\nAlitalia, in which Etihad holds a 49-percent stake, went into administration in May after staff refused to accept job and salary cuts as part of a new rescue plan.\n\n'HOT POTATO'\n\nOn Germany's DAX index of leading German firms, Lufthansa soared to the top of the leaders board, gaining 4.50 percent to 20.55 euros just after 1440 GMT.\n\nShares in Air Berlin, not listed on the Dax, plunged by more than 37 percent to 0.48 euros.\n\nGermany's giant services sector union Verdi responded with dismay to Air Berlin's decision to file for administration.\n\n\"This is a heavy blow for Air Berlin employees,\" said Verdi board member Christine Behle. \"Our priority now is to secure jobs. Air Berlin must proceed with the utmost transparency and provide all necessary information.\"\n\nThe pilots' union Cockpit said the Air Berlin news came as \"a shock\".\n\nIt welcomed the government's help in minimising the disruption over the coming months, but it accused Etihad of making the wrong strategic and management decisions and turning its back on Air Berlin workers.\n\n\"Etihad is dropping Air Berlin like a hot potato,\" it said.\n\nAir Berlin said two members of its board of directors, who were nominated by Etihad, had resigned.", "id": "9308148", "details": {}, "date": It has been restructuring its operations and has been kept aloft in recent years by Etihad, which holds a 29.2-percent stake.\n\nIn December German rival Lufthansa's Eurowings and Austrian Airlines units reached a deal to lease 38 planes from Air Berlin.\n\nFollowing the bankruptcy announcement, Lufthansa said it was \"supporting the restructuring efforts of the airline jointly with the German government\" and that its leased aircraft would continue operating as before.\n\nLufthansa, Germany's largest airline, said it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the Air Berlin group and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff.\"\n\nZypries said that the bridge loan \"should give enough time for the negotiations to be brought to a conclusion.\"\n\nThe German Transport and Economy Ministries said Air Berlin had been in negotiations with Lufthansa \"and another airline\" for a long time.\n\nEtihad Airways said the bankruptcy filing was \"extremely disappointing for all parties,\" especially as it had supported the airline for over six years, but that it could not continue pumping money into a loss-making business.\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" it said.\n\nIt said it had pumped 250 million euros of additional funding into Air Berlin as recently as in April and helped it \"explore strategic options\" for its business. It said the German carrier's business has \"deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\nThe Emirati national airline said it continues to have codeshares and other business relationships with Air Berlin and will support its management.\n\nAir Berlin's decision comes three and a half months after another Etihad-backed European carrier, Alitalia, entered its second round of bankruptcy protection in a decade.\n\nEtihad said at the time that Alitalia needed a \"fundamental {"timeCrawl": "04:15:00", "uri": "710099666", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T04:15:00Z", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "source": {"title": "geo.tv", "uri": "geo.tv", "id": "3799"}, "url": "https://www.geo.tv/latest/153842-air-berlin-files-for-insolvency-after-etihad-withdraws-support", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Air Berlin - Germany's second-largest airline - filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses, leaving valuable runway slots up for grabs.\n\nThe move offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against expansion by low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nLufthansa confirmed it was in talks to take over parts of the business, while a source said easyJet was the second airline referred to by the government as being in talks with Air Berlin. The British budget carrier declined to comment.\n\nThe insolvency comes with thousands of Germans enjoying summer holidays, and just ahead of a September general election.\n\nThe German government has granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($176 million) to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations continue.\n\nThe government said it expected decisions to result from these negotiations in the coming weeks.\n\nLufthansa has already leased Air Berlin planes to provide flights by its Eurowings budget airline and has made no secret of its interest in taking on more of Air Berlin's business while being mindful of the potential obstacles posed by debts and anti-trust issues.\n\n\"Lufthansa has played a canny waiting game over a number of years and is now well placed to cherry-pick those parts of Air Berlin's operation that suit it best without buying the whole loss-making enterprise,\" said Jonathan Wober, an analyst at CAPA-Centre for Aviation.\n\nRyanair said Air Berlin was being prepared for a Lufthansa takeover, which it said would breach competition laws. But German Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt said he was confident there would be no anti-trust issues because the business would be sold off in bits.\n\nIn a statement published after trading hours, the Irish carrier said it had lodged a complaint with the German and European competition authorities regarding \"the obvious conspiracy\" playing out in Germany over Air Berlin.\n\n\"This manufactured insolvency is clearly being set up to allow Lufthansa to take over a debt-free Air Berlin, which will be in breach of all known German and EU competition rules,\" Ryanair's statement said.\n\nA spokesperson for the European Commission said it was in \"constructive contact\" with Germany about the Air Berlin issue.\n\nEuropean Union state aid rules allow rescue and restructuring aid to companies that are in financial difficulty, but such aid is subject to strict conditions.\n\nAir Berlin, which became famous for its \"Mallorca shuttle\" services, piled up debt after a series of takeovers and bookings have been hit in recent months by concerns over its finances.\n\nIt made a net loss in almost every year since 2008 and in 2016 reported a record deficit of 782 million euros ($915 million), equivalent to more than 2 million euros a day.\n\nFunding from Etihad Airways, which bought into Air Berlin in 2011, has helped keep it afloat and the Abu Dhabi-based airline provided an additional 250 million euros in April.\n\nBut Etihad has been reviewing its European investments after they failed to yield the profits expected. Alitalia, another of Etihad's investments, is also in administration and is seeking bidders.\n\nTalks between Etihad and TUI, Europe's largest tour operator, about forming a joint venture holiday airline by merging TUIfly with Air Berlin's leisure airline Niki collapsed earlier this year.\n\nShares in Air Berlin last traded down 34 percent at 0.51 euros on Tuesday, valuing the airline at about 60 million euros. Ten years ago the carrier was worth around 1 billion euros.\n\nLufthansa shares were up 4.7 percent at 20.59 euros.\n\nPilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) blamed the shortcomings of past management at Air Berlin for its woes and expressed anger with Etihad.\n\n\"It is a scandal that Etihad is dodging its responsibility and is leaving Air Berlin's staff out in the cold,\" VC President Ilja Schulz {"timeCrawl": "14:19:00", "uri": "709808062", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T14:19:00Z", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "source": {"title": "Luxemburger Wort", "uri": "wort.lu", "id": "510"}, "url": "http://www.wort.lu/en/international/bankruptcy-air-berlin-files-for-bankruptcy-flights-to-keep-going-5992fdcaa5e74263e13c5c5b", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "(AFP) - Germany's Air Berlin on Tuesday announced it had filed for bankruptcy after its main shareholder Etihad Airways said it would not plough any more cash into the struggling airline.\n\nThe German government said it was providing a bridging loan of 150 million euros to keep the carrier's flights going at a time when many Germans are still on holiday.\n\nGerman rival Lufthansa said in a separate announcement it was in talks with Air Berlin to take over parts of the group.\n\nAir Berlin has long battled to stay afloat, booking losses amounting to 1.2 billion euros over the past two years and relying on cash infusions from Etihad for survival.\n\nThe German airline said in a statement that it had filed for insolvency with the court of Berlin-Charlottenburg after Etihad \"notified Air Berlin PLC of the fact that it will not provide any further financial support to the Air Berlin group\".\n\nEtihad, which holds a 29-percent stake in Air Berlin, said the development was \"extremely disappointing\" but that it could no longer justify further funding after providing an additional 250 million euros in April.\n\n\"Air Berlin's business has continued to deteriorate at an unprecedented rate, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges,\" it said.\n\nGerman Economy Minister Brigitte Zypries told a hastily assembled press conference that the government was assisting Air Berlin with a bridging loan to prevent passengers from being stranded during the holiday season.\n\n\"To keep Air Berlin's flight operations going, the government has decided to grant a bridging loan for 150 million euros,\" she told reporters.\n\nThe money should be enough to keep Air Berlin running \"for three months\", she added.\n\nIn a bid turn to the tide, Germany's second-largest airline embarked on a massive restructuring plan in September 2016 that included renting 38 aircraft with crew to Lufthansa and slashing 1,200 jobs -- or one in seven of its workforce.\n\nAmid the restructuring, it was hit by a series of flight cancellations and severe delays, leading to a flood of complaints.\n\nLufthansa said it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the Air Berlin Group and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff\".\n\nGermany's giant services sector union Verdi responded with dismay to Air Berlin's surprise announcement.\n\n\"This is a heavy blow for Air Berlin employees,\" said Verdi board member Christine Behle.\n\n\"Our priority now is to secure jobs. Air Berlin must proceed with the utmost transparency and provide all necessary information.\"\n\nThe pilots' union Cockpit said the Air Berlin news came as \"a shock\".\n\nIt welcomed the government's help in minimising the disruption over the coming months, but it accused Etihad of making the wrong strategic and management decisions and turning its back on Air Berlin workers.\n\n\"Etihad is dropping Air Berlin like a hot potato,\" it said.\n\nAir Berlin said two members of its board of directors, who joined after being nominated by Etihad, had resigned.", "id": "9294667", "details": {}, {"timeCrawl": "12:18:00", "uri": "709752997", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T12:18:00Z", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "source": {"title": "WSOC", "uri": "wsoctv.com", "id": "497"}, "url": "http://www.wsoctv.com/news/business/german-carrier-air-berlin-filing-for-bankruptcy/592189688", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "The loss-making airline said Tuesday that after Etihad pulled funding, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin.\"\n\nTo allay travelers' fears that they could be stranded on summer holiday, the German government immediately said it would provide a loan of 150 million euros ($177 million) so the airline it can continue flights for the time being.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travelers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the Economy and Transport ministries said in a joint statement. \"The return flights of these travelers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nAir Berlin has been posting losses for years and has a debt of 1.2 billion euros. It has recently been restructuring its operations to try and stay in business and has been kept aloft in recent years by Etihad, which holds a 29.2 percent share.\n\nIn December, German rival Lufthansa's Eurowings and Austrian Airlines units reached a deal to lease 38 planes from Air Berlin.\n\nFollowing the bankruptcy announcement, Lufthansa said it was \"supporting the restructuring efforts of the airline jointly with the German government\" and that its leased aircraft would continue operating as before.\n\nLufthansa, Germany's largest airline, said it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the Air Berlin group and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff.\"\n\nThe German transport and economy ministries said Air Berlin had been in negotiations with Lufthansa \"and another airline\" for a long time.\n\nEtihad Airways said the bankruptcy was \"extremely disappointing for all parties,\" especially as it had supported the airline over six years.\n\nIt said it pumped 250 million euros of additional funding into Air Berlin as recently as in April and helped it \"explore strategic options\" for its business. It said the German carrier's business has \"deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" it said.\n\nThe Emirati national airline said it continues to have codeshares and other business relationships with Air Berlin and will support its management.\n\n\"Germany is an important market for Etihad and Abu Dhabi, and we remain committed to providing comprehensive air links as a key enabler of trade and tourism,\" it said.\n\nAir Berlin's decision comes three and a half months after another Etihad-backed European carrier, Alitalia, entered its second round of bankruptcy protection in a decade.\n\nEtihad said at the time that Alitalia needed a \"fundamental and far-reaching restructuring\" and it was not prepared to keep pumping money into the struggling Italian {"timeCrawl": "18:28:00", "uri": "709917682", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T18:28:00Z", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "source": {"title": "timesofmalta.com", "uri": "timesofmalta.com", "id": "818"}, "url": "https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20170815/business-news/air-berlin-goes-bust-after-etihad-withdraws-support.655755", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Air Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection today after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses, leaving valuable runway slots up for grabs.\n\nThe move offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against expansion by low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nLufthansa confirmed it was in talks to take over parts of the business, while a source said easyJet was the second airline referred to by the government as being in talks with Air Berlin. The British budget carrier declined to comment.\n\nThe insolvency comes as thousands of Germans enjoy their summer holidays and just ahead of a September general election.\n\nBerlin has granted a bridging loan of \u20ac150 million to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations continue.\n\nThe government said it expected decisions to result from these negotiations in the coming weeks.\n\nLufthansa has already leased Air Berlin planes to provide flights by its Eurowings budget airline and has made no secret of its interest in taking on more of Air Berlin's business while being mindful of the potential obstacles posed by debts and anti-trust issues.\n\n\"Lufthansa has played a canny waiting game over a number of years and is now well placed to cherry pick those parts of Air Berlin's operation that suit it best without buying the whole loss-making enterprise,\" Jonathan Wober, analyst at CAPA-Centre for Aviation, said.\n\nRecord loss\n\nRyanair said Air Berlin was being prepared for Lufthansa's takeover, which it said would breach competition laws. But German transport minister Alexander Dobrindt said he was confident there would be no anti-trust issues because the business would be sold off in bits.\n\nIn a statement published after trading hours, the Irish carrier said it had lodged a complaint with the German and European competition authorities regarding \"the obvious conspiracy\" playing out in Germany over Air Berlin.\n\n\"This manufactured insolvency is clearly being set up to allow Lufthansa to take over a debt-free Air Berlin which will be in breach of all known German and EU competition rules,\" Ryanair said.\n\nAir Berlin, which became famous for its \"Mallorca shuttle\" services, piled up debt after a series of takeovers and bookings have been hit in recent months by concerns over its finances.\n\nIt made a net loss in almost every year since 2008 and in 2016 reported a record deficit of \u20ac782 million, equivalent to more than \u20ac2 million a day.\n\nFunding from Etihad Airways, which bought into the airline in 2011, has helped to keep it afloat and the Abu Dhabi-based airline provided an additional \u20ac250 million euros in April.\n\nBut Etihad has been reviewing its European investments after they failed to bring in the profits expected. Alitalia, another of Etihad's investments, is also in administration and is seeking bidders.\n\nMeanwhile talks between Etihad and TUI, Europe's largest tour operator, about forming a joint venture holiday airline by merging TUIfly with Air Berlin's leisure airline Niki collapsed earlier this year.\n\nShares in Air Berlin last traded down 34 percent at \u20ac0.51 today, valuing the airline at about \u20ac60 million. Ten years ago the carrier was worth around \u20ac1 billion.\n\nLufthansa shares were up 4.7 percent at \u20ac20.59.\n\nPilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) blamed the shortcomings of past management at Air Berlin for its woes and expressed anger with Etihad. \"It is a scandal that Etihad is dodging its responsibility and is leaving Air Berlin's staff out in the cold,\" VC President Ilja Schulz {"timeCrawl": "15:29:00", "uri": "709838650", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T15:29:00Z", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "source": {"title": "Business Recorder", "uri": "brecorder.com", "id": "1214"}, "url": "http://www.brecorder.com/2017/08/15/364903/air-berlin-files-for-bankruptcy-flights-to-keep-going/", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "FRANKFURT AM MAIN: Germany's Air Berlin on Tuesday announced it had filed for bankruptcy after its main shareholder Etihad Airways said it would not plough any more cash into the struggling airline.\n\nThe German government said it was providing a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($175 million) to keep the carrier's flights going at a time when many Germans are still on holiday.\n\nGerman rival Lufthansa said in a separate announcement it was in talks with Air Berlin to take over parts of the group.\n\nAir Berlin has long battled to stay afloat, booking losses amounting to 1.2 billion euros over the past two years and relying on cash infusions from Etihad for survival.\n\nThe German airline said in a statement that it had filed for insolvency with the court of Berlin-Charlottenburg after Etihad \"notified Air Berlin PLC of the fact that it will not provide any further financial support to the Air Berlin group\".\n\nEtihad, which holds a 29-percent stake in Air Berlin, said the development was \"extremely disappointing\" but that it could no longer justify further funding after providing an additional 250 million euros in April.\n\n\"Air Berlin's business has continued to deteriorate at an unprecedented rate, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges,\" it said.\n\nGerman Economy Minister Brigitte Zypries told a hastily assembled press conference that the government was assisting Air Berlin with a bridging loan to prevent passengers from being stranded during the holiday season.\n\n\"To keep Air Berlin's flight operations going, the government has decided to grant a bridging loan for 150 million euros,\" she told reporters.\n\nThe money should be enough to keep Air Berlin running \"for three months\", she added.\n\nIn a bid turn to the tide, Germany's second-largest airline embarked on a massive restructuring plan in September 2016 that included renting 38 aircraft with crew to Lufthansa and slashing 1,200 jobs -- or one in seven of its workforce.\n\nAmid the restructuring, it was hit by a series of flight cancellations and severe delays, leading to a flood of complaints.\n\nLufthansa said it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the Air Berlin Group and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff\".\n\n- 'Hot potato' -\n\nGermany's giant services sector union Verdi responded with dismay to Air Berlin's surprise announcement.\n\n\"This is a heavy blow for Air Berlin employees,\" said Verdi board member Christine Behle.\n\n\"Our priority now is to secure jobs. Air Berlin must proceed with the utmost transparency and provide all necessary information.\"\n\nThe pilots' union Cockpit said the Air Berlin news came as \"a shock\".\n\nIt welcomed the government's help in minimising the disruption over the coming months, but it accused Etihad of making the wrong strategic and management decisions and turning its back on Air Berlin workers.\n\nAir Berlin said {"timeCrawl": "15:23:00", "uri": "709836361", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T15:23:00Z", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "source": {"title": "Agence France Presse (AFP)", "German rival Lufthansa said in a separate announcement it was in talks with Air Berlin to take over parts of the group.\n\nAir Berlin has long battled for survival, booking losses amounting to 1.2 billion euros over the past two years and relying on cash infusions from Etihad.\n\nIn a surprise announcement, the German airline said it had filed for insolvency with the court of Berlin-Charlottenburg after Etihad \"notified Air Berlin PLC of the fact that it will not provide any further financial support to the Air Berlin group\".\n\nEtihad, which holds a 29.2-percent stake in Air Berlin, said the development was \"extremely disappointing\" but that it could no longer justify further funding after providing an additional 250 million euros in April.\n\n\"Air Berlin's business has continued to deteriorate at an unprecedented rate, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges,\" the Abu Dhabi-based company said.\n\nGerman Economy Minister Brigitte Zypries told a hastily assembled press conference that the government was assisting Air Berlin with a bridging loan to prevent passengers from being stranded during the busy holiday season.\n\n\"To keep Air Berlin's flight operations going, the government has decided to grant a bridging loan for 150 million euros,\" she told reporters.\n\nThe money should be enough to keep Air Berlin running \"for three months\", she said, adding that flights would go ahead as scheduled and that new tickets could still be booked.\n\nIn a bid turn to the tide, Germany's second-largest airline embarked on a massive restructuring plan last year that included leasing 38 aircraft with crew to Lufthansa and slashing 1,200 jobs -- or one in seven of its workforce.\n\nAmid the restructuring, it was hit by a series of flight cancellations and severe delays, leading to a flood of complaints.\n\nLufthansa said it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the Air Berlin Group and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff\".\n\nAir Berlin said the talks with Lufthansa \"and other partners\" about acquiring its assets were already far advanced.\n\nOn Germany's DAX index of leading German firms, Lufthansa soared to the top of the leaders board, gaining 4.50 percent to 20.55 euros just after 1440 GMT.\n\nShares in Air Berlin, not listed on the Dax, plunged by more than 37 percent to 0.48 euros.\n\nGermany's giant services sector union Verdi responded with dismay to Air Berlin's decision to file for administration.\n\n\"This is a heavy blow for Air Berlin employees,\" said Verdi board member Christine Behle.\n\n\"Our priority now is to secure jobs. Air Berlin must proceed with the utmost transparency and provide all necessary information.\"\n\nThe pilots' union Cockpit said the Air Berlin news came as \"a shock\".\n\nIt welcomed the government's help in minimising the disruption over the coming months, but it accused Etihad of making the wrong strategic and management decisions and turning its back on Air Berlin workers.\n\n\"Etihad is {"timeCrawl": "14:24:00", "uri": "709810509", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T14:24:00Z", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/german-carrier-air-berlin-filing-for-bankruptcy-36034560.html", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/article36034559.ece/13ea1/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-e4a54b3d-7a16-48f5-87ba-23ab0b70e505_I1.jpg\n\nGermany's second largest carrier, Air Berlin, is filing for bankruptcy protection after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad, said it would make no more financing available.\n\nThe loss-making airline said that after Etihad pulled funding, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin\".\n\nTo allay travellers' fears that they could be stranded on summer holiday, the German government immediately said it would provide a loan of 150 million euros (\u00a3137 million) so the airline can continue flights for the time being.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travellers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the economy and transport ministries said in a statement. \"The return flights of these travellers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nEconomy minister Brigitte Zypries later told reporters the money was expected to last for three months.\n\nUnion ver.di called it a \"severe blow\" for the more than 7,000 employees of Air Berlin.\n\n\"Our priority now lies with securing the jobs,\" said Christine Behle, a union board director. \"Air Berlin must proceed with transparency and provide all important information.\"\n\nAir Berlin has been posting losses for years. It has been restructuring its operations and has been kept aloft in recent years by Etihad, which holds a 29.2% stake.\n\nIn December, German rival Lufthansa's Eurowings and Austrian Airlines units reached a deal to lease 38 planes from Air Berlin.\n\nFollowing the bankruptcy announcement, Lufthansa said it was \"supporting the restructuring efforts of the airline jointly with the German government\" and that its leased aircraft would continue operating as before.\n\nLufthansa, Germany's largest airline, said it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the Air Berlin group and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff\".\n\nMs Zypries said that the bridge loan \"should give enough time for the negotiations to be brought to a conclusion\".\n\nThe German transport and economy ministries said Air Berlin had been in negotiations with Lufthansa \"and another airline\" for a long time.\n\nEtihad Airways said the bankruptcy filing was \"extremely disappointing for all parties\", especially as it had supported the airline over six years, but that it could not continue pumping money into a loss-making business.\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" it said.\n\nThe Emirati national airline said it continues to have codeshares and other business relationships with Air Berlin and will support its management.\n\nAir Berlin's decision comes three and a half months after another Etihad-backed European carrier, Alitalia, entered its second round of bankruptcy protection in a decade.\n\nEtihad said at the time that Alitalia needed a \"fundamental and far-reaching restructuring\" and it was not prepared to keep pumping money into the struggling Italian airline.", "id": "9295582", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "German carrier Air Berlin filing for bankruptcy", "image": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/article36034559.ece/ALTERNATES/h342/PANews%20BT_P-e4a54b3d-7a16-48f5-87ba-23ab0b70e505_I1.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "concepts": [], "location": null, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "id": 106, "label": "dmoz/Business/Industrial Goods and Services/Industrial Supply", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Industrial_Goods_and_Services/Industrial_Supply"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 143, "label": "dmoz/Reference/Education/Colleges and Universities", "uri": "dmoz/Reference/Education/Colleges_and_Universities"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 855, "label": "dmoz/Science/Environment/Air Quality", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Environment/Air_Quality"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 857, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Home and Garden/Climate Control", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Home_and_Garden/Climate_Control"}], "time": "14:24:00"}
{"timeCrawl": "18:34:00", "uri": "709920138", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T18:34:00Z", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "source": {"title": "Channel NewsAsia", "uri": "channelnewsasia.com", "id": "1555"}, "url": "http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/business/air-berlin-files-for-insolvency-after-etihad-withdraws-support-9126514", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "BERLIN: Air Berlin , Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses, leaving valuable runway slots up for grabs.\n\nThe move offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against expansion by low-cost rival Ryanair .\n\nLufthansa confirmed it was in talks to take over parts of the business, while a source said easyJet was the second airline referred to by the government as being in talks with Air Berlin. The British budget carrier declined to comment.\n\nThe insolvency comes as thousands of Germans enjoy their summer holidays and just ahead of a September general election.\n\nBerlin has granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros (US$176 million) to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations continue.\n\nThe government said it expected decisions to result from these negotiations in the coming weeks.\n\nLufthansa has already leased Air Berlin planes to provide flights by its Eurowings budget airline and has made no secret of its interest in taking on more of Air Berlin's business while being mindful of the potential obstacles posed by debts and anti-trust issues.\n\n\"Lufthansa has played a canny waiting game over a number of years and is now well placed to cherry pick those parts of Air Berlin's operation that suit it best without buying the whole loss-making enterprise,\" Jonathan Wober, analyst at CAPA-Centre for Aviation, said.\n\nRECORD LOSS\n\nRyanair said Air Berlin was being prepared for Lufthansa's takeover, which it said would breach competition laws. But German transport minister Alexander Dobrindt said he was confident there would be no anti-trust issues because the business would be sold off in bits.\n\nIn a statement published after trading hours, the Irish carrier said it had lodged a complaint with the German and European competition authorities regarding \"the obvious conspiracy\" playing out in Germany over Air Berlin.\n\n\"This manufactured insolvency is clearly being set up to allow Lufthansa to take over a debt-free Air Berlin which will be in breach of all known German and EU competition rules,\" Ryanair said.\n\nAir Berlin, which became famous for its \"Mallorca shuttle\" services, piled up debt after a series of takeovers and bookings have been hit in recent months by concerns over its finances.\n\nIt made a net loss in almost every year since 2008 and in 2016 reported a record deficit of 782 million euros (US$915 million), equivalent to more than 2 million euros a day.\n\nFunding from Etihad Airways, which bought into the airline in 2011, has helped to keep it afloat and the Abu Dhabi-based airline provided an additional 250 million euros in April.\n\nBut Etihad has been reviewing its European investments after they failed to bring in the profits expected. Alitalia , another of Etihad's investments, is also in administration and is seeking bidders.\n\nMeanwhile talks between Etihad and TUI , Europe's largest tour operator, about forming a joint venture holiday airline by merging TUIfly with Air Berlin's leisure airline Niki collapsed earlier this year.\n\nShares in Air Berlin last traded down 34 percent at 0.51 euros on Tuesday, valuing the airline at about 60 million euros. Ten years ago the carrier was worth around 1 billion euros.\n\nLufthansa shares were up 4.7 percent at 20.59 euros.\n\nPilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) blamed the shortcomings of past management at Air Berlin for its woes and expressed anger with Etihad. \"It is a scandal that Etihad is dodging its responsibility and is leaving Air Berlin's staff out in the cold,\" VC President Ilja Schulz said in a statement.\n\n(Reporting by Victoria Bryan, Maria Sheahan; and Gernot Heller. Additional reporting by Andreas Cremer.; Editing by David Holmes, Greg Mahlich)", "id": "9337622", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Air Berlin files for insolvency after Etihad withdraws {"timeCrawl": "14:36:00", "uri": "709815444", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T14:36:00Z", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "source": {"title": "USA Today", "uri": "usatoday.com", "id": "335"}, "url": "https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/flights/todayinthesky/2017/08/15/air-berlin-files-bankruptcy-after-etihad-pulls-plug/568138001/", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "BERLIN (AP) -- Germany's second largest airline, Air Berlin, is filing for bankruptcy protection after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad, said it would make no more financing available following years of unsuccessful turnaround attempts.\n\nThe loss-making airline, which carries some 80,000 people a day mostly on short-haul destinations, will get a 150 million euro ($177 million) government loan to keep flights running and not leave travelers stranded during the peak summer season.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travelers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the German Economy and Transport Ministries said in a statement Tuesday. \"The return flights of these travelers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nThe loan cash is expected to last for three months, the government said, after which the airline's future is uncertain. Rival Lufthansa, which is Germany's biggest carrier, and another unidentified airline are in talks to take over some operations, the government said.\n\nARCHIVES: Reports suggest Etihad has big plans for Air Berlin (2014)\n\nUnion ver.di called it a \"severe blow\" for the more-than 7,000 employees of Air Berlin.\n\n\"Our priority now lies with securing the jobs,\" said Christine Behle, a union board director. \"Air Berlin must proceed with transparency and provide all important information.\"\n\nEconomy Minister Brigitte Zypries said that the bridge loan should give Air Berlin enough time to wrap up talks on the sale of some operations.\n\nThe bankruptcy filing was prompted by the decision by Etihad, which holds a 29.2% stake, to stop funneling money into the airline after years of propping it up.\n\nAir Berlin said that in light of Etihad's decision, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin.\"\n\nAlready the carrier had been trying to ease its costs and lighten its debt load of 1.2 billion euros. In December, it reached a deal to lease 38 plans to Lufthansa's units Eurowings and Austrian Airlines.\n\nEtihad Airways said the bankruptcy filing was \"extremely disappointing for all parties,\" especially as it had supported the airline over six years, but that it could not continue pumping money into a loss-making business.\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" it said.\n\nIt said it had injected 250 million euros of additional funding into Air Berlin as recently as April and helped it \"explore strategic options\" for its business. But it said the carrier's business \"deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\nThe Emirati airline said it continues to have codeshares and other business relationships with Air Berlin and will support its management.\n\nShares in Air Berlin plunged 39% on Tuesday after being suspended for trading earlier.\n\nAir Berlin's decision comes three and a half months after another Etihad-backed European carrier, Alitalia, entered its second round of bankruptcy protection in a decade.\n\nEtihad said at the time that Alitalia needed a \"fundamental and far-reaching restructuring\" and it was not prepared to keep pumping money into the struggling Italian airline.\n\nKirsten Grieshaber in Berlin and Adam Schreck in Dubai contributed to this story.\n\nRead or Share this story: https://usat.ly/2w6E3b0", "id": "9297590", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Air {"timeCrawl": "15:15:00", "uri": "709832656", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T15:15:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"title": "The Phuket News Com", "uri": "thephuketnews.com", "id": "6109"}, "url": "https://www.thephuketnews.com/air-berlin-files-for-bankruptcy-flights-to-keep-going-63471.php", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "The German government said it was providing a bridging loan of 150 million euros (B1.948 billion) to keep the carrier's flights going at a time when many Germans are still on holiday.\n\nGerman rival Lufthansa said in a separate announcement it was in talks with Air Berlin to take over parts of the group.\n\nAir Berlin has long battled to stay afloat, booking losses amounting to 1.2 billion euros over the past two years and relying on cash infusions from Etihad for survival.\n\nThe German airline said in a statement that it had filed for insolvency with the court of Berlin-Charlottenburg after Etihad \"notified Air Berlin PLC of the fact that it will not provide any further financial support to the Air Berlin group\".\n\nEtihad, which holds a 29-percent stake in Air Berlin, said the development was \"extremely disappointing\" but that it could no longer justify further funding after providing an additional 250 million euros in April.\n\n\"Air Berlin's business has continued to deteriorate at an unprecedented rate, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges,\" it said.\n\nGerman Economy Minister Brigitte Zypries told a hastily assembled press conference that the government was assisting Air Berlin with a bridging loan to prevent passengers from being stranded during the holiday season.\n\n\"To keep Air Berlin's flight operations going, the government has decided to grant a bridging loan for 150 million euros,\" she told reporters.\n\nThe money should be enough to keep Air Berlin running \"for three months\", she added.\n\nIn a bid turn to the tide, Germany's second-largest airline embarked on a massive restructuring plan in September 2016 that included renting 38 aircraft with crew to Lufthansa and slashing 1,200 jobs -- or one in seven of its workforce.\n\nAmid the restructuring, it was hit by a series of flight cancellations and severe delays, leading to a flood of complaints.\n\nLufthansa said it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the Air Berlin Group and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff\".\n\n- 'Hot potato' -\n\nGermany's giant services sector union Verdi responded with dismay to Air Berlin's surprise announcement.\n\n\"This is a heavy blow for Air Berlin employees,\" said Verdi board member Christine Behle.\n\n\"Our priority now is to secure jobs. Air Berlin must proceed with the utmost transparency and provide all necessary information.\"\n\nThe pilots' union Cockpit said the Air Berlin news came as \"a shock\".\n\nIt welcomed the government's help in minimising the disruption over the coming months, but it accused Etihad of making the wrong strategic and management decisions and turning its back on Air Berlin workers.\n\n\"Etihad is dropping Air Berlin like a hot potato,\" it said.\n\nAir Berlin said two members of its board of directors, who joined after being nominated by Etihad, had resigned.", "id": "9304466", "details": {}, {"timeCrawl": "14:26:00", "uri": "709811367", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T14:26:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"title": "Miami Herald", "uri": "miamiherald.com", "id": "283"}, "url": "http://www.miamiherald.com/news/business/article167242207.html", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Germany's second largest airline, Air Berlin, is filing for bankruptcy protection after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad, said it would make no more financing available following years of unsuccessful turnaround attempts.\n\nThe loss-making airline, which carries some 80,000 people a day mostly on short-haul destinations, will get a 150 million euro ($177 million) government loan to keep flights running and not leave travelers stranded during the peak summer season.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travelers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the German Economy and Transport Ministries said in a statement Tuesday. \"The return flights of these travelers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nThe loan cash is expected to last for three months, the government said, after which the airline's future is uncertain. Rival Lufthansa, which is Germany's biggest carrier, and another unidentified airline are in talks to take over some operations, the government said.\n\nUnion ver.di called it a \"severe blow\" for the more-than 7,000 employees of Air Berlin.\n\n\"Our priority now lies with securing the jobs,\" said Christine Behle, a union board director. \"Air Berlin must proceed with transparency and provide all important information.\"\n\nEconomy Minister Brigitte Zypries said that the bridge loan should give Air Berlin enough time to wrap up talks on the sale of some operations.\n\nThe bankruptcy filing was prompted by the decision by Etihad, which holds a 29.2 percent stake, to stop funneling money into the airline after years of propping it up.\n\nAir Berlin said that in light of Etihad's decision, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin.\"\n\nAlready the carrier had been trying to ease its costs and lighten its debt load of 1.2 billion euros. In December, it reached a deal to lease 38 plans to Lufthansa's units Eurowings and Austrian Airlines.\n\nEtihad Airways said the bankruptcy filing was \"extremely disappointing for all parties,\" especially as it had supported the airline over six years, but that it could not continue pumping money into a loss-making business.\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" it said.\n\nIt said it had injected 250 million euros of additional funding into Air Berlin as recently as April and helped it \"explore strategic options\" for its business. But it said the carrier's business \"deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\nThe Emirati national airline said it continues to have codeshares and other business relationships with Air Berlin and will support its management.\n\nShares in Air Berlin plunged 39 percent on Tuesday after being suspended for trading earlier.\n\nAir Berlin's decision comes three and a half months after another Etihad-backed European carrier, Alitalia, entered its second round of bankruptcy protection in a decade.\n\nEtihad said at the time that Alitalia needed a \"fundamental and far-reaching restructuring\" and it was not prepared to keep pumping money into the struggling Italian
