{"timeCrawl": "16:42:00", "uri": "709871740", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T16:22:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"title": "Associated Press", "uri": "hosted2.ap.org", "id": "566"}, "url": "http://hosted2.ap.org/CARIE/0260ea4c3e85456b80715585ba3c7b5b/Article_2017-08-15-EU-Germany-Air-Berlin/id-68ff36ca9ea34336b93ae50492d4c8a4", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "BERLIN (AP) -- Germany's second largest airline, Air Berlin, has filed for bankruptcy protection after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad, said it would make no more financing available following years of unsuccessful turnaround attempts.\n\nThe loss-making airline, which carries some 80,000 people a day mostly on short-haul destinations, will get a 150 million euro ($177 million) government loan to keep flights running and not leave travelers stranded during the peak summer season.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travelers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the German Economy and Transport Ministries said in a statement Tuesday. \"The return flights of these travelers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nThe loan will allow Air Berlin to operate until the end of November, its CEO Thomas Winkelmann said.\n\nAfter that the airline's future is uncertain. Rival Lufthansa, which is Germany's biggest carrier, and another unidentified airline are in talks to take over some operations. Winkelmann said the talks were \"very well advanced.\"\n\nUnion ver.di called the bankruptcy a \"severe blow\" for Air Berlin's more than 7,000 employees.\n\n\"Our priority now lies with securing the jobs,\" said Christine Behle, a union board director. \"Air Berlin must proceed with transparency and provide all important information.\"\n\nEconomy Minister Brigitte Zypries said that the bridge loan should give Air Berlin enough time to wrap up talks on the sale of some operations.\n\nThe bankruptcy filing was prompted by the decision by Etihad, which holds a 29.2 percent stake, to stop funneling money into the airline after years of propping it up.\n\nAir Berlin said that in light of Etihad's decision, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin.\"\n\nAlready the carrier had been trying to ease its costs and lighten its debt load of 1.2 billion euros after reporting a record loss of 782 million euros last year. In December, it reached a deal to lease 38 plans to Lufthansa's units Eurowings and Austrian Airlines.\n\nEtihad Airways said the bankruptcy filing was \"extremely disappointing for all parties,\" especially as it had supported the airline over six years, but that it could not continue pumping money into a loss-making business.\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" it said.\n\nIt said it had injected 250 million euros of additional funding into Air Berlin as recently as April and helped it \"explore strategic options\" for its business. But it said the carrier's business \"deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\nShares in Air Berlin plunged 34 percent on Tuesday to 51 euro cents.\n\nThe Emirati national airline said it continues to have codeshares and other business relationships with Air Berlin and will support its management.\n\nAir Berlin's decision comes three and a half months after another Etihad-backed European carrier, Alitalia, entered its second round of bankruptcy protection in a decade.\n\nEtihad said at the time that Alitalia needed a \"fundamental and far-reaching restructuring\" and it was not prepared to keep pumping money into the struggling Italian airline.\n\n____\n\nKirsten Grieshaber and Frank Jordans in Berlin, and Adam Schreck in Dubai contributed to this story.", "id": "9319984", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Air Berlin files for bankruptcy after shareholder pulls {"timeCrawl": "14:18:00", "uri": "709807615", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T14:18:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"title": "wbrc.com", "uri": "wbrc.com", "id": "219"}, "url": "http://www.wbrc.com/story/36137038/air-berlin-files-for-bankruptcy-after-shareholder-pulls-plug", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "BERLIN (AP) - Germany's second largest airline, Air Berlin, is filing for bankruptcy protection after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad, said it would make no more financing available following years of unsuccessful turnaround attempts.\n\nThe loss-making airline, which carries some 80,000 people a day mostly on short-haul destinations, will get a 150 million euro ($177 million) government loan to keep flights running and not leave travelers stranded during the peak summer season.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travelers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the German Economy and Transport Ministries said in a statement Tuesday. \"The return flights of these travelers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nThe loan cash is expected to last for three months, the government said, after which the airline's future is uncertain. Rival Lufthansa, which is Germany's biggest carrier, and another unidentified airline are in talks to take over some operations, the government said.\n\nUnion ver.di called it a \"severe blow\" for the more-than 7,000 employees of Air Berlin.\n\n\"Our priority now lies with securing the jobs,\" said Christine Behle, a union board director. \"Air Berlin must proceed with transparency and provide all important information.\"\n\nEconomy Minister Brigitte Zypries said that the bridge loan should give Air Berlin enough time to wrap up talks on the sale of some operations.\n\nThe bankruptcy filing was prompted by the decision by Etihad, which holds a 29.2 percent stake, to stop funneling money into the airline after years of propping it up.\n\nAir Berlin said that in light of Etihad's decision, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin.\"\n\nAlready the carrier had been trying to ease its costs and lighten its debt load of 1.2 billion euros. In December, it reached a deal to lease 38 plans to Lufthansa's units Eurowings and Austrian Airlines.\n\nEtihad Airways said the bankruptcy filing was \"extremely disappointing for all parties,\" especially as it had supported the airline over six years, but that it could not continue pumping money into a loss-making business.\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" it said.\n\nIt said it had injected 250 million euros of additional funding into Air Berlin as recently as April and helped it \"explore strategic options\" for its business. But it said the carrier's business \"deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\nThe Emirati national airline said it continues to have codeshares and other business relationships with Air Berlin and will support its management.\n\nShares in Air Berlin plunged 39 percent on Tuesday after being suspended for trading earlier.\n\nAir Berlin's decision comes three and a half months after another Etihad-backed European carrier, Alitalia, entered its second round of bankruptcy protection in a decade.\n\nEtihad said at the time that Alitalia needed a \"fundamental and far-reaching restructuring\" and it was not prepared to keep pumping money into the struggling Italian airline.\n\n____\n\nKirsten Grieshaber in Berlin and Adam Schreck in Dubai contributed to this story.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"timeCrawl": "13:47:00", "uri": "709793974", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T13:43:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"title": "Associated Press", "uri": "hosted2.ap.org", "id": "566"}, "url": "http://hosted2.ap.org/CARIE/0260ea4c3e85456b80715585ba3c7b5b/Article_2017-08-15-EU--Germany-Air%20Berlin/id-f30691abe2f043e28b9597f0bbc1534a", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "BERLIN (AP) -- Germany's second largest airline, Air Berlin, is filing for bankruptcy protection after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad, said it would make no more financing available following years of unsuccessful turnaround attempts.\n\nThe loss-making airline, which carries some 80,000 people a day mostly on short-haul destinations, will get a 150 million euro ($177 million) government loan to keep flights running and not leave travelers stranded during the peak summer season.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travelers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the German Economy and Transport Ministries said in a statement Tuesday. \"The return flights of these travelers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nThe loan cash is expected to last for three months, the government said, after which the airline's future is uncertain. Rival Lufthansa, which is Germany's biggest carrier, and another unidentified airline are in talks to take over some operations, the government said.\n\nUnion ver.di called it a \"severe blow\" for the more-than 7,000 employees of Air Berlin.\n\n\"Our priority now lies with securing the jobs,\" said Christine Behle, a union board director. \"Air Berlin must proceed with transparency and provide all important information.\"\n\nEconomy Minister Brigitte Zypries said that the bridge loan should give Air Berlin enough time to wrap up talks on the sale of some operations.\n\nThe bankruptcy filing was prompted by the decision by Etihad, which holds a 29.2 percent stake, to stop funneling money into the airline after years of propping it up.\n\nAir Berlin said that in light of Etihad's decision, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin.\"\n\nAlready the carrier had been trying to ease its costs and lighten its debt load of 1.2 billion euros. In December, it reached a deal to lease 38 plans to Lufthansa's units Eurowings and Austrian Airlines.\n\nEtihad Airways said the bankruptcy filing was \"extremely disappointing for all parties,\" especially as it had supported the airline over six years, but that it could not continue pumping money into a loss-making business.\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" it said.\n\nIt said it had injected 250 million euros of additional funding into Air Berlin as recently as April and helped it \"explore strategic options\" for its business. But it said the carrier's business \"deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\nThe Emirati national airline said it continues to have codeshares and other business relationships with Air Berlin and will support its management.\n\nShares in Air Berlin plunged 39 percent on Tuesday after being suspended for trading earlier.\n\nAir Berlin's decision comes three and a half months after another Etihad-backed European carrier, Alitalia, entered its second round of bankruptcy protection in a decade.\n\nEtihad said at the time that Alitalia needed a \"fundamental and far-reaching restructuring\" and it was not prepared to keep pumping money into the struggling Italian airline.\n\n____\n\nKirsten Grieshaber in Berlin and Adam Schreck in Dubai contributed to this story.", "id": "9289310", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Air Berlin files for bankruptcy {"timeCrawl": "17:55:00", "uri": "709904422", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T17:55:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/air-berlin-files-for-insolvency-after-etihad-withdraws-support/articleshow/60077320.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "* Shareholder Etihad withdraws financial support\n\n* Lufthansa says in talks for take over of parts of group\n\n* Government provides bridging loan, flights continue\n\n* Shares in Lufthansa, budget rivals rise (Adds Ryanair lodging complaint with antitrust authorities)\n\nBy Victoria Bryan and Maria Sheahan\n\nBERLIN, Aug 15 (Reuters) - Air Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses, leaving valuable runway slots up for grabs.\n\nThe move offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against expansion by low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nLufthansa confirmed it was in talks to take over parts of the business, while a source said easyJet was the second airline referred to by the government as being in talks with Air Berlin. The British budget carrier declined to comment.\n\nThe insolvency comes as thousands of Germans enjoy their summer holidays and just ahead of a September general election.\n\nBerlin has granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($176 million) to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations continue.\n\nThe government said it expected decisions to result from these negotiations in the coming weeks.\n\nLufthansa has already leased Air Berlin planes to provide flights by its Eurowings budget airline and has made no secret of its interest in taking on more of Air Berlin's business while being mindful of the potential obstacles posed by debts and anti-trust issues.\n\n\"Lufthansa has played a canny waiting game over a number of years and is now well placed to cherry pick those parts of Air Berlin's operation that suit it best without buying the whole loss-making enterprise,\" Jonathan Wober, analyst at CAPA-Centre for Aviation, said.\n\nRECORD LOSS\n\nRyanair said Air Berlin was being prepared for Lufthansa's takeover, which it said would breach competition laws. But German transport minister Alexander Dobrindt said he was confident there would be no anti-trust issues because the business would be sold off in bits.\n\nIn a statement published after trading hours, the Irish carrier said it had lodged a complaint with the German and European competition authorities regarding \"the obvious conspiracy\" playing out in Germany over Air Berlin.\n\n\"This manufactured insolvency is clearly being set up to allow Lufthansa to take over a debt-free Air Berlin which will be in breach of all known German and EU competition rules,\" Ryanair said.\n\nAir Berlin, which became famous for its \"Mallorca shuttle\" services, piled up debt after a series of takeovers and bookings have been hit in recent months by concerns over its finances.\n\nIt made a net loss in almost every year since 2008 and in 2016 reported a record deficit of 782 million euros ($915 million), equivalent to more than 2 million euros a day.\n\nFunding from Etihad Airways, which bought into the airline in 2011, has helped to keep it afloat and the Abu Dhabi-based airline provided an additional 250 million euros in April.\n\nBut Etihad has been reviewing its European investments after they failed to bring in the profits expected. Alitalia , another of Etihad's investments, is also in administration and is seeking bidders.\n\nMeanwhile talks between Etihad and TUI, Europe's largest tour operator, about forming a joint venture holiday airline by merging TUIfly with Air Berlin's leisure airline Niki collapsed earlier this year.\n\nShares in Air Berlin last traded down 34 percent at 0.51 euros on Tuesday, valuing the airline at about 60 million euros. Ten years ago the carrier was worth around 1 billion euros.\n\nLufthansa shares were up 4.7 percent at 20.59 euros.\n\nPilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) blamed the shortcomings of past management at Air Berlin for its woes and expressed anger with Etihad. \"It is a scandal that Etihad is dodging its responsibility and is leaving Air Berlin's staff out in the cold,\" VC President Ilja Schulz said in a statement. ($1 = 0.8548 euros) (Reporting by Victoria Bryan, Maria Sheahan; and Gernot Heller. Additional reporting by Andreas Cremer.; Editing by David Holmes, Greg Mahlich)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your {"timeCrawl": "10:25:00", "uri": "710250716", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T00:49:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"title": "The Mainichi", "uri": "mainichi.jp", "id": "14931"}, "url": "https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170816/p2g/00m/0bu/005000c", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "BERLIN (AP) -- Germany's second largest airline, Air Berlin, has filed for bankruptcy protection after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad, said it would make no more financing available following years of unsuccessful turnaround attempts.\n\nThe loss-making airline, which carries some 80,000 people a day mostly on short-haul destinations, will get a 150 million euro ($177 million) government loan to keep flights running and not leave travelers stranded during the peak summer season.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travelers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the German Economy and Transport Ministries said in a statement Tuesday. \"The return flights of these travelers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nThe loan will allow Air Berlin to operate until the end of November, its CEO Thomas Winkelmann said.\n\nAfter that the airline's future is uncertain. Rival Lufthansa, which is Germany's biggest carrier, and another unidentified airline are in talks to take over some operations. Winkelmann said the talks were \"very well advanced.\"\n\nUnion ver.di called the bankruptcy a \"severe blow\" for Air Berlin's more than 7,000 employees.\n\n\"Our priority now lies with securing the jobs,\" said Christine Behle, a union board director. \"Air Berlin must proceed with transparency and provide all important information.\"\n\nEconomy Minister Brigitte Zypries said that the bridge loan should give Air Berlin enough time to wrap up talks on the sale of some operations.\n\nThe bankruptcy filing was prompted by the decision by Etihad, which holds a 29.2 percent stake, to stop funneling money into the airline after years of propping it up.\n\nAir Berlin said that in light of Etihad's decision, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin.\"\n\nAlready the carrier had been trying to ease its costs and lighten its debt load of 1.2 billion euros after reporting a record loss of 782 million euros last year. In December, it reached a deal to lease 38 plans to Lufthansa's units Eurowings and Austrian Airlines.\n\nEtihad Airways said the bankruptcy filing was \"extremely disappointing for all parties,\" especially as it had supported the airline over six years, but that it could not continue pumping money into a loss-making business.\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" it said.\n\nIt said it had injected 250 million euros of additional funding into Air Berlin as recently as April and helped it \"explore strategic options\" for its business. But it said the carrier's business \"deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\nShares in Air Berlin plunged 34 percent on Tuesday to 51 euro cents.\n\nThe Emirati national airline said it continues to have codeshares and other business relationships with Air Berlin and will support its management.\n\nAir Berlin's decision comes three and a half months after another Etihad-backed European carrier, Alitalia, entered its second round of bankruptcy protection in a decade.\n\nEtihad said at the time that Alitalia needed a \"fundamental and far-reaching restructuring\" and it was not prepared to keep pumping money into the struggling Italian airline.", "id": "9454049", "details": {}, {"timeCrawl": "15:50:00", "uri": "709847635", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T15:50:00Z", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "source": {"title": "lethbridgeherald.com", "uri": "lethbridgeherald.com", "id": "6076"}, "url": "http://lethbridgeherald.com/business/2017/08/15/air-berlin-files-for-bankruptcy-after-shareholder-pulls-plug/", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "BERLIN - Germany's second largest airline, Air Berlin, has filed for bankruptcy protection after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad, said it would make no more financing available following years of unsuccessful turnaround attempts.\n\nThe loss-making airline, which carries some 80,000 people a day mostly on short-haul destinations, will get a 150 million euro ($177 million) government loan to keep flights running and not leave travellers stranded during the peak summer season.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travellers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the German Economy and Transport Ministries said in a statement Tuesday. \"The return flights of these travellers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nThe loan will allow Air Berlin to operate until the end of November, its CEO Thomas Winkelmann said.\n\nAfter that the airline's future is uncertain. Rival Lufthansa, which is Germany's biggest carrier, and another unidentified airline are in talks to take over some operations. Winkelmann said the talks were \"very well advanced.\"\n\nUnion ver.di called the bankruptcy a \"severe blow\" for Air Berlin's more than 7,000 employees.\n\n\"Our priority now lies with securing the jobs,\" said Christine Behle, a union board director. \"Air Berlin must proceed with transparency and provide all important information.\"\n\nEconomy Minister Brigitte Zypries said that the bridge loan should give Air Berlin enough time to wrap up talks on the sale of some operations.\n\nThe bankruptcy filing was prompted by the decision by Etihad, which holds a 29.2 per cent stake, to stop funneling money into the airline after years of propping it up.\n\nAir Berlin said that in light of Etihad's decision, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin.\"\n\nAlready the carrier had been trying to ease its costs and lighten its debt load of 1.2 billion euros. In December, it reached a deal to lease 38 plans to Lufthansa's units Eurowings and Austrian Airlines.\n\nEtihad Airways said the bankruptcy filing was \"extremely disappointing for all parties,\" especially as it had supported the airline over six years, but that it could not continue pumping money into a loss-making business.\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" it said.\n\nIt said it had injected 250 million euros of additional funding into Air Berlin as recently as April and helped it \"explore strategic options\" for its business. But it said the carrier's business \"deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\nThe Emirati national airline said it continues to have codeshares and other business relationships with Air Berlin and will support its management.\n\nShares in Air Berlin plunged 39 per cent on Tuesday after being suspended for trading earlier.\n\nAir Berlin's decision comes three and a half months after another Etihad-backed European carrier, Alitalia, entered its second round of bankruptcy protection in a decade.\n\nEtihad said at the time that Alitalia needed a \"fundamental and far-reaching restructuring\" and it was not prepared to keep pumping money into the struggling Italian airline.\n\n____\n\nKirsten Grieshaber in Berlin and Adam Schreck in Dubai contributed to this story.", "id": "9310341", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Air Berlin files for bankruptcy {"timeCrawl": "16:50:00", "uri": "709876143", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T16:50:00Z", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "source": {"title": "KHNL TV 8", "uri": "hawaiinewsnow.com", "id": "11710"}, "url": "http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/36137040/air-berlin-files-for-bankruptcy-after-shareholder-pulls-plug", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "BERLIN (AP) - Germany's second largest airline, Air Berlin, has filed for bankruptcy protection after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad, said it would make no more financing available following years of unsuccessful turnaround attempts.\n\nThe loss-making airline, which carries some 80,000 people a day mostly on short-haul destinations, will get a 150 million euro ($177 million) government loan to keep flights running and not leave travelers stranded during the peak summer season.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travelers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the German Economy and Transport Ministries said in a statement Tuesday. \"The return flights of these travelers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nThe loan will allow Air Berlin to operate until the end of November, its CEO Thomas Winkelmann said.\n\nAfter that the airline's future is uncertain. Rival Lufthansa, which is Germany's biggest carrier, and another unidentified airline are in talks to take over some operations. Winkelmann said the talks were \"very well advanced.\"\n\nUnion ver.di called the bankruptcy a \"severe blow\" for Air Berlin's more than 7,000 employees.\n\n\"Our priority now lies with securing the jobs,\" said Christine Behle, a union board director. \"Air Berlin must proceed with transparency and provide all important information.\"\n\nEconomy Minister Brigitte Zypries said that the bridge loan should give Air Berlin enough time to wrap up talks on the sale of some operations.\n\nThe bankruptcy filing was prompted by the decision by Etihad, which holds a 29.2 percent stake, to stop funneling money into the airline after years of propping it up.\n\nAir Berlin said that in light of Etihad's decision, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin.\"\n\nAlready the carrier had been trying to ease its costs and lighten its debt load of 1.2 billion euros after reporting a record loss of 782 million euros last year. In December, it reached a deal to lease 38 plans to Lufthansa's units Eurowings and Austrian Airlines.\n\nEtihad Airways said the bankruptcy filing was \"extremely disappointing for all parties,\" especially as it had supported the airline over six years, but that it could not continue pumping money into a loss-making business.\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" it said.\n\nIt said it had injected 250 million euros of additional funding into Air Berlin as recently as April and helped it \"explore strategic options\" for its business. But it said the carrier's business \"deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\nShares in Air Berlin plunged 34 percent on Tuesday to 51 euro cents.\n\nThe Emirati national airline said it continues to have codeshares and other business relationships with Air Berlin and will support its management.\n\nAir Berlin's decision comes three and a half months after another Etihad-backed European carrier, Alitalia, entered its second round of bankruptcy protection in a decade.\n\nEtihad said at the time that Alitalia needed a \"fundamental and far-reaching restructuring\" and it was not prepared to keep pumping money into the struggling Italian airline.\n\n____\n\nKirsten Grieshaber and Frank Jordans in Berlin, and Adam Schreck in Dubai contributed to this story.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. another unidentified airline are in talks to take over some operations, the government said.\n\nThe loss-making airline, which carries some 80,000 people a day mostly on short-haul destinations, will {"timeCrawl": "08:56:00", "uri": "710780403", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:56:00Z", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "source": {"title": "sunnewsonline.com", "uri": "sunnewsonline.com", "id": "3501"}, "url": "http://sunnewsonline.com/air-berlin-files-for-insolvency-after-etihad-withdraws-support/", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Air Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses, leaving valuable runway slots up for grabs.\n\nThe move offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against expansion by low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nLufthansa confirmed it was in talks to take over parts of the business, while a source said easyJet was the second airline referred to by the government as being in talks with Air Berlin. The British budget carrier declined to comment.\n\nThe insolvency comes as thousands of Germans enjoy their summer holidays and just ahead of a September general election.\n\nBerlin has granted a bridging loan of \u20ac150 million ($176 million) to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations continue.\n\nThe government said it expected decisions from these negotiations in coming weeks.\n\nLufthansa has already leased Air Berlin planes to provide flights by its Eurowings budget airline and has made no secret of its interest in taking on more of Air Berlin's business, although debts and anti-trust issues were potential obstacles.\n\n\"Lufthansa has played a canny waiting game over a number of years and is now well placed to cherry pick those parts of Air Berlin's operation that suit it best without buying the whole lossmaking enterprise,\" Jonathan Wober, analyst at CAPA-Center for Aviation, said.\n\nRyanair said Lufthansa was being set up to take over Air Berlin, which it said would breach competition laws. But German transport minister Alexander Dobrindt said he was confident there would be no anti-trust issues because the business would be sold off in bits.\n\nAir Berlin, which became famous for its \"Mallorca shuttle\" services, piled up debt after a series of takeovers and bookings have been hit in recent months by concerns over its finances.\n\nIt made a net loss in almost every year since 2008 and in 2016 reported a record deficit of \u20ac782 million, equivalent to more than \u20ac2 million a day.\n\nFunding from Etihad Airways, which bought into the airline in 2011, has helped to keep it afloat and the Abu Dhabi-based airline provided an additional \u20ac250 million in April.\n\nBut Etihad has been reviewing its European investments after they failed to bring in expected profits. Alitalia, another of Etihad's investments, is also in administration and is seeking bidders.\n\nMeanwhile talks between Etihad and TUI, Europe's largest tour operator, about forming a joint venture holiday airline by merging TUIfly with Air Berlin's leisure airline Niki collapsed earlier this year.\n\nShares in Air Berlin were down 32 percent at \u20ac0.53 by 2.18 p.m. GMT, valuing the airline at roughly \u20ac60 million. Ten years ago the carrier was worth around \u20ac1 billion.\n\nLufthansa shares were up 4.1 percent at \u20ac20.47.\n\nPilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) blamed the shortcomings of past management at Air Berlin for its woes and expressed anger with Etihad. \"It is a scandal that Etihad is dodging its responsibility and is leaving Air Berlin's staff out in the cold,\" VC President Ilja Schulz said in a statement. Struggling German carrier Air Berlin says it's filing for bankruptcy after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad, said it would make no more financing available. The Economy Ministry and Transport Ministry said Tuesday Aug. 15, 2017 in a statement that the airline would get a loan of 150 million euros ($177 million) so that it can continue flights for the time being. (Bernd Thissen/dpa via AP,file)\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travelers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the ministries said. \"The return flights of these travelers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nLoss-making Air Berlin has been restructuring to try and stay in business and has been kept aloft in recent years by Etihad, which holds a 29.2 percent share.\n\nIn December, German rival Lufthansa's Eurowings and Austrian Airlines units reached a deal to lease 38 planes from Air Berlin.\n\nFollowing the bankruptcy announcement, Lufthansa said it was \"supporting the restructuring efforts of the airline jointly with the German government\" and that its leased aircraft would continue operating as before.\n\nLufthansa, Germany's largest airline, said it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the Air Berlin group and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff.\"\n\nThe ministries said Air Berlin had been in negotiations with Lufthansa \"and another airline\" for a long time.\n\n\"Securing the flight operations and the ongoing positive contract negotiations with other airlines to work together with Air Berlin to continue the flight operations under different ownership were the main reasons for the government's decision to provide a bridge loan,\" the ministries said.\n\n____\n\nKirsten Grieshaber contributed to this story.", "id": "9271194", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "German carrier Air Berlin filing for {"timeCrawl": "17:45:00", "uri": "709899286", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T15:56:00Z", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "source": {"title": "CBC News", "uri": "cbc.ca", "id": "668"}, "url": "http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/air-berlin-bankruptcy-protection-1.4247874", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Germany's second largest airline, Air Berlin, has filed for bankruptcy protection after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad, said it would make no more financing available following years of unsuccessful turnaround attempts.\n\nThe loss-making airline, which carries some 80,000 people a day mostly on short-haul destinations, will get a 150 million euro ($224 million Cdn) government loan to keep flights running and not leave travellers stranded during the peak summer season.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travellers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the German Economy and Transport Ministries said in a statement Tuesday. \"The return flights of these travellers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nThe loan will allow Air Berlin to operate until the end of November, its CEO Thomas Winkelmann said.\n\nAfter that, the airline's future is uncertain. Rival Lufthansa, which is Germany's biggest carrier, and another unidentified airline are in talks to take over some operations. Winkelmann said the talks were \"very well advanced.\"\n\nUnion ver.di called the bankruptcy a \"severe blow\" for Air Berlin's more than 7,000 employees.\n\n\"Our priority now lies with securing the jobs,\" said Christine Behle, a union board director. \"Air Berlin must proceed with transparency and provide all important information.\"\n\nEconomy Minister Brigitte Zypries said that the bridge loan should give Air Berlin enough time to wrap up talks on the sale of some operations.\n\nThe bankruptcy filing was prompted by the decision by Etihad, which holds a 29.2-per-cent stake, to stop funnelling money into the airline after years of propping it up.\n\nAir Berlin said that in light of Etihad's decision, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin.\"\n\nAlready the carrier had been trying to ease its costs and lighten its debt load of 1.2 billion euros. In December, it reached a deal to lease 38 plans to Lufthansa's units Eurowings and Austrian Airlines.\n\nEtihad Airways said the bankruptcy filing was \"extremely disappointing for all parties,\" especially as it had supported the airline over six years, but that it could not continue pumping money into a loss-making business.\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" it said.\n\nIt said it had injected 250 million euros of additional funding into Air Berlin as recently as April and helped it \"explore strategic options\" for its business. But it said the carrier's business \"deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\nThe Emirati national airline said it continues to have codeshares and other business relationships with Air Berlin and will support its management.\n\nShares in Air Berlin plunged 39 per cent on Tuesday after being suspended for trading earlier.\n\nAir Berlin's decision comes three and a half months after another Etihad-backed European carrier, Alitalia, entered its second round of bankruptcy protection in a decade.\n\nEtihad said at the time that Alitalia needed a \"fundamental and far-reaching restructuring\" and it was not prepared to keep pumping money into the struggling Italian Struggling German carrier Air Berlin says it's filing for bankruptcy after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad, said it would make no more financing available. The Economy Ministry and Transport Ministry said Tuesday Aug. 15, 2017 in a statement that the airline would get a loan of 150 million euros ($177 million) so that it can continue flights for the time being. Struggling German carrier Air Berlin says it's filing for bankruptcy after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad, said it would make no more financing available. The Economy Ministry and Transport Ministry said Tuesday Aug. 15, 2017 in a statement that the airline would get a loan of 150 million euros ($177 million) so that it can continue flights for the time being. (Michael Kappeler/dpa via AP)\n\nThe loan cash is expected to last for three months, the government said, after which the airline's future is uncertain. Rival Lufthansa, which is Germany's biggest carrier, and another unidentified airline are in talks to take over some operations, the government said.\n\nUnion ver.di called it a \"severe blow\" for the more-than 7,000 employees of Air Berlin.\n\n\"Our priority now lies with securing the jobs,\" said Christine Behle, a union board director. \"Air Berlin must proceed with transparency and provide all important information.\"\n\nEconomy Minister Brigitte Zypries said that the bridge loan should give Air Berlin enough time to wrap up talks on the sale of some operations.\n\nThe bankruptcy filing was prompted by the decision by Etihad, which holds a 29.2 percent stake, to stop funneling money into the airline after years of propping it up.\n\nAir Berlin said that in light of Etihad's decision, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin.\"\n\nAlready the carrier had been trying to ease its costs and lighten its debt load of 1.2 billion euros. In December, it reached a deal to lease 38 plans to Lufthansa's units Eurowings and Austrian Airlines.\n\nEtihad Airways said the bankruptcy filing was \"extremely disappointing for all parties,\" especially as it had supported the airline over six years, but that it could not continue pumping money into a loss-making business.\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" it said.\n\nIt said it had injected 250 million euros of additional funding into Air Berlin as recently as April and helped it \"explore strategic options\" for its business. But it said the carrier's business \"deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\nThe Emirati national airline said it continues to have codeshares and other business relationships with Air Berlin and will support its management.\n\nShares in Air Berlin plunged 39 percent on Tuesday after being suspended for trading earlier.\n\nAir Berlin's decision comes three and a half months after another Etihad-backed European carrier, Alitalia, entered its second round of bankruptcy protection in a decade.\n\nEtihad said at the time that Alitalia needed a \"fundamental and far-reaching restructuring\" and it was not prepared to keep pumping money into the struggling Italian airline.\n\nKirsten Grieshaber in Berlin and Adam Schreck in Dubai contributed to this story.", "id": "9323639", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Air Berlin files for bankruptcy after {"timeCrawl": "17:06:00", "uri": "709883017", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T17:06:00Z", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "source": {"title": "thewillnigeria.com", "uri": "thewillnigeria.com", "id": "2050"}, "url": "http://thewillnigeria.com/news/air-berlin-files-for-insolvency-after-etihad-withdraws-support/", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Air Berlin (AB1.DE), Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses, leaving valuable runway slots up for grabs.\n\nThe move offers Lufthansa (LHAG.DE) and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against expansion by low-cost rival Ryanair (RYA.I).\n\nLufthansa confirmed it was in talks to take over parts of the business, while a source said easyJet (EZJ.L) was the second airline referred to by the government as being in talks with Air Berlin. The British budget carrier declined to comment.\n\nThe insolvency comes as thousands of Germans enjoy their summer holidays and just ahead of a September general election.\n\nBerlin has granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($176 million) to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations continue.\n\nThe government said it expected decisions from these negotiations in coming weeks.\n\nLufthansa has already leased Air Berlin planes to provide flights by its Eurowings budget airline and has made no secret of its interest in taking on more of Air Berlin's business, although debts and anti-trust issues were potential obstacles.\n\n\"Lufthansa has played a canny waiting game over a number of years and is now well placed to cherry pick those parts of Air Berlin's operation that suit it best without buying the whole loss-making enterprise,\" Jonathan Wober, analyst at CAPA-Centre for Aviation, said.\n\nRyanair said Lufthansa was being set up to take over Air Berlin, which it said would breach competition laws. But German transport minister Alexander Dobrindt said he was confident there would be no anti-trust issues because the business would be sold off in bits.\n\nAir Berlin, which became famous for its \"Mallorca shuttle\" services, piled up debt after a series of takeovers and bookings have been hit in recent months by concerns over its finances.\n\nIt made a net loss in almost every year since 2008 and in 2016 reported a record deficit of 782 million euros ($915 million), equivalent to more than 2 million euros a day.\n\nFunding from Etihad Airways, which bought into the airline in 2011, has helped to keep it afloat and the Abu Dhabi-based airline provided an additional 250 million euros in April.\n\nBut Etihad has been reviewing its European investments after they failed to bring in expected profits. Alitalia [CAITLA.UL], another of Etihad's investments, is also in administration and is seeking bidders.\n\nMeanwhile talks between Etihad and TUI (TUIT.L), Europe's largest tour operator, about forming a joint venture holiday airline by merging TUIfly with Air Berlin's leisure airline Niki collapsed earlier this year.\n\nShares in Air Berlin were down 32 percent at 0.53 euros by 1418 GMT, valuing the airline at roughly 60 million euros. Ten years ago the carrier was worth around 1 billion euros.\n\nLufthansa shares were up 4.1 percent at 20.47 euros.\n\nPilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) blamed the shortcomings of past management at Air Berlin for its woes and expressed anger with Etihad. \"It is a scandal that Etihad is dodging its responsibility and is leaving Air Berlin's staff out in the cold,\" VC President Ilja Schulz {"timeCrawl": "14:51:00", "uri": "709821286", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T14:51:00Z", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "source": {"title": "Economic Times", "uri": "http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/business/air-berlin-files-for-insolvency-lufthansa-waits-in-the-wings/articleshow/60074868.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "BERLIN: Air Berlin, Germany's second largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday following years of losses and after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding, with bigger rival Lufthansa saying it is in talks to take over parts of the business.\n\nThe insolvency comes as thousands of Germans are enjoying their summer holidays and just ahead of a September general election.\n\nBut Berlin said it has granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($176 million) which will allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secures jobs for its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations continue.\n\nAir Berlin is in talks with Lufthansa and another airline about selling its assets, the government said, adding that it expected a decision in the coming weeks.\n\nLufthansa has already leased crewed planes from Air Berlin to provide flights by its Eurowings budget airline and has made no secret of its interest in taking on more of Air Berlin's business, although it has said debts and anti-trust issues were potential obstacles.\n\n\"Lufthansa has played a canny waiting game over a number of years and is now well-placed to cherry pick those parts of Air Berlin's operation that suit it best without buying the whole loss-making enterprise,\" Jonathan Wober, analyst at CAPA-Centre for Aviation, said.\n\nMALLORCA SHUTTLE\n\nAir Berlin, which became famous for its \"Mallorca shuttle\" services, piled up debt after a series of takeovers and concerns over its finances have hit bookings in recent months.\n\nIt has made a net loss in almost every year since 2008 and in 2016 reported a record loss of 782 million euros ($915 million), equivalent to a loss of more than 2 million euros a day.\n\nFunding from Etihad Airways, which bought into the airline in 2011, has helped to keep it afloat in recent years, but the Abu Dhabi-based airline has been reviewing its European investments after they failed to bring in the profit it expected.\n\nItalian national airline Alitalia, another of Etihad's investments, is also in administration and seeking bidders for its business.\n\nMeanwhile talks between Etihad and TUI, Europe's largest tour operator, about forming a joint venture holiday airline by merging TUIfly with Air Berlin's leisure airline Niki collapsed earlier this year.\n\nEtihad last provided additional funding of 250 million euros to Air Berlin in April.\n\n\"However, Air Berlin's business has deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions,\" Etihad said in a statement on Tuesday.\n\nShares in Air Berlin were down 39 percent at 0.47 euros by 1248 GMT, valuing the airline at around 45 million euros. Ten years ago the carrier was worth around 1 billion euros.\n\nLufthansa's shares were up 2.5 percent at 20.15 euros.\n\nPilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) blamed the shortcomings of past management at Air Berlin for the airline's financial woes and expressed anger with Etihad.\n\n\"It is a scandal that Etihad is dodging its responsibility and is leaving Air Berlin's staff out in the cold,\" VC President Ilja Schulz said in a statement.", "id": "9299926", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Air Berlin files for insolvency, Lufthansa waits in the wings", "image": announcement it was in talks with Air Berlin to take over parts of the group.\n\nAir Berlin has booked losses amounting to 1.2 billion euros ($1.3 billion) over the last two years, and has been relying on cash infusions from Etihad for survival.\n\nThe carrier had recently applied to the German states of Berlin and North Rhine-Westphalia for a public guarantee.\n\n\"The board of directors of of Berlin-Charlottenburg.\n\n\"The reason for this conclusion is that its main shareholder Etihad Airways PJSC has notified Air Berlin PLC of the fact that it will not provide any further financial support to the Air Berlin group,\" the group said.\n\nIt added that two members of the board of directors, who joined after being nominated by Etihad, had resigned.\n\n\"The German federal government "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "BERLIN -- Germany's second largest carrier, Air Berlin, is filing for bankruptcy after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad, said it would make no more financing available.\n\nThe airline said Tuesday in a statement that after Etihad pulled funding, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin,\" Germany's dpa news agency reported.\n\nThe Economy Ministry and Transport Ministry immediately announced in a joint statement to allay travellers' fears that they could be stranded on summer holiday, saying the government would provide a loan of 150 million euros ($177 million) so the airline it can continue flights for the time being.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travellers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the ministries said. \"The return flights of these travellers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nLoss-making Air Berlin has been restructuring to try and stay in business and has been kept aloft in recent years by Etihad, which holds a 29.2 per cent share.\n\nIn December, German rival Lufthansa's Eurowings and Austrian Airlines units reached a deal to lease 38 planes from Air Berlin.\n\nFollowing the bankruptcy announcement, Lufthansa said it was \"supporting the restructuring efforts of the airline jointly with the German government\" and that its leased aircraft would continue operating as before.\n\nLufthansa, Germany's largest airline, said it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the Air Berlin group and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff.\"\n\nThe ministries said Air Berlin had been in negotiations with Lufthansa \"and another airline\" for a long time.\n\n\"Securing the flight operations and the ongoing positive contract negotiations with other airlines to work together with Air Berlin to continue the flight operations under different ownership were the main reasons for the government's decision to provide a bridge loan,\" the ministries said.\n\n-- -- -\n\nKirsten announcement it was in talks with Air Berlin to take over parts of the group.\n\nAir Berlin has booked losses amounting to 1.2 billion euros (USD 1.3 billion) over the last two years, and has been relying on cash infusions from Etihad for survival.\n\nThe carrier had recently applied to the German states of Berlin and North Rhine-Westphalia for a public guarantee.\n\n\"The board of directors of Air Berlin PLC has, after close evaluation, determined that Air Berlin PLC has no longer a positive continuation prognosis,\" the airline said, adding that it had filed for insolvency with the court of Berlin- Charlottenburg.\n\n\"The reason for this conclusion is that its main shareholder Etihad Airways PJSC has notified Air Berlin PLC of the fact that it will not provide any further financial support to the Air Berlin group,\" the group said.\n\nIt added that two members of the board of directors, who joined after being nominated by Etihad, had resigned.\n\n\"The German federal government is supporting Air Berlin with a bridging loan secured by a federal guarantee to maintain flight operations,\" Air Berlin said.\n\nIn a bid turn to the tide, Germany's second-largest airline embarked on a massive restructuring plan in September 2016 that included renting 38 aircraft with crew to Lufthansa and slashing 1,200 jobs -- or one in seven of its workforce.\n\nAmid the restructuring, it was hit by a series of flight cancellations and severe delays, leading to a flood of complaints.\n\nLufthansa for its part announced that it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over {"timeCrawl": "15:29:00", "uri": "709838834", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T15:29:00Z", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/air-berlin-files-for-insolvency-after-etihad-withdraws-support/articleshow/60075692.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "* Shareholder Etihad withdraws financial support\n\n* Lufthansa says in talks for take over of parts of group\n\n* Government provides bridging loan, flights continue\n\n* Shares in Lufthansa, budget rivals rise (Adds details on assets, airlines)\n\nBy Victoria Bryan and Maria Sheahan\n\nBERLIN, Aug 15 (Reuters) - Air Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses, leaving valuable runway slots up for grabs.\n\nThe move offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against expansion by low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nLufthansa confirmed it was in talks to take over parts of the business, while a source said easyJet was the second airline referred to by the government as being in talks with Air Berlin. The British budget carrier declined to comment.\n\nThe insolvency comes as thousands of Germans enjoy their summer holidays and just ahead of a September general election.\n\nBerlin has granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($176 million) to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations continue.\n\nThe government said it expected decisions from these negotiations in coming weeks.\n\nLufthansa has already leased Air Berlin planes to provide flights by its Eurowings budget airline and has made no secret of its interest in taking on more of Air Berlin's business, although debts and anti-trust issues were potential obstacles.\n\n\"Lufthansa has played a canny waiting game over a number of years and is now well placed to cherry pick those parts of Air Berlin's operation that suit it best without buying the whole loss-making enterprise,\" Jonathan Wober, analyst at CAPA-Centre for Aviation, said.\n\nRECORD LOSS\n\nRyanair said Lufthansa was being set up to take over Air Berlin, which it said would breach competition laws. But German transport minister Alexander Dobrindt said he was confident there would be no anti-trust issues because the business would be sold off in bits.\n\nAir Berlin, which became famous for its \"Mallorca shuttle\" services, piled up debt after a series of takeovers and bookings have been hit in recent months by concerns over its finances.\n\nIt made a net loss in almost every year since 2008 and in 2016 reported a record deficit of 782 million euros ($915 million), equivalent to more than 2 million euros a day.\n\nFunding from Etihad Airways, which bought into the airline in 2011, has helped to keep it afloat and the Abu Dhabi-based airline provided an additional 250 million euros in April.\n\nBut Etihad has been reviewing its European investments after they failed to bring in expected profits. Alitalia, another of Etihad's investments, is also in administration and is seeking bidders.\n\nMeanwhile talks between Etihad and TUI, Europe's largest tour operator, about forming a joint venture holiday airline by merging TUIfly with Air Berlin's leisure airline Niki collapsed earlier this year.\n\nShares in Air Berlin were down 32 percent at 0.53 euros by 1418 GMT, valuing the airline at roughly 60 million euros. Ten years ago the carrier was worth around 1 billion euros.\n\nLufthansa shares were up 4.1 percent at 20.47 euros.\n\nPilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) blamed the shortcomings of past management at Air Berlin for its woes and expressed anger with Etihad. \"It is a scandal that Etihad is dodging its responsibility and is leaving Air Berlin's staff out in the cold,\" VC President Ilja Schulz said in a statement.\n\n($1 = 0.8548 euros) (Reporting by Victoria Bryan, Maria Sheahan; and Gernot Heller; Editing by Greg Mahlich and David Holmes)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on {"timeCrawl": "21:20:00", "uri": "709980624", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T21:20:00Z", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "source": {"title": "WHBQ", "uri": "fox13memphis.com", "id": "114"}, "url": "http://www.fox13memphis.com/news/german-carrier-air-berlin-filing-for-bankruptcy/592195063", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "The loss-making airline, which carries some 80,000 people a day mostly on short-haul destinations, will get a 150 million euro ($177 million) government loan to keep flights running and not leave travelers stranded during the peak summer season.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travelers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the German Economy and Transport Ministries said in a statement Tuesday. \"The return flights of these travelers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nThe loan will allow Air Berlin to operate until the end of November, its CEO Thomas Winkelmann said.\n\nAfter that the airline's future is uncertain. Rival Lufthansa, which is Germany's biggest carrier, and another unidentified airline are in talks to take over some operations. Winkelmann said the talks were \"very well advanced.\"\n\nUnion ver.di called the bankruptcy a \"severe blow\" for Air Berlin's more than 7,000 employees.\n\n\"Our priority now lies with securing the jobs,\" said Christine Behle, a union board director. \"Air Berlin must proceed with transparency and provide all important information.\"\n\nEconomy Minister Brigitte Zypries said that the bridge loan should give Air Berlin enough time to wrap up talks on the sale of some operations.\n\nThe bankruptcy filing was prompted by the decision by Etihad, which holds a 29.2 percent stake, to stop funneling money into the airline after years of propping it up.\n\nAir Berlin said that in light of Etihad's decision, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin.\"\n\nAlready the carrier had been trying to ease its costs and lighten its debt load of 1.2 billion euros after reporting a record loss of 782 million euros last year. In December, it reached a deal to lease 38 plans to Lufthansa's units Eurowings and Austrian Airlines.\n\nEtihad Airways said the bankruptcy filing was \"extremely disappointing for all parties,\" especially as it had supported the airline over six years, but that it could not continue pumping money into a loss-making business.\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" it said.\n\nIt said it had injected 250 million euros of additional funding into Air Berlin as recently as April and helped it \"explore strategic options\" for its business. But it said the carrier's business \"deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\nShares in Air Berlin plunged 34 percent on Tuesday to 51 euro cents.\n\nThe Emirati national airline said it continues to have codeshares and other business relationships with Air Berlin and will support its management.\n\nAir Berlin's decision comes three and a half months after another Etihad-backed European carrier, Alitalia, entered its second round of bankruptcy protection in a decade.\n\nEtihad said at the time that Alitalia needed a \"fundamental and far-reaching restructuring\" and it was not prepared to keep pumping money into the struggling Italian airline.\n\n____\n\nKirsten Grieshaber and false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "* Shareholder Etihad withdraws financial support\n\n* Lufthansa says in talks for take over of parts of group\n\n* Government provides bridging loan, flights continue (Adds details from Lufthansa, comments by government, analyst)\n\nBy Victoria Bryan and Maria Sheahan\n\nBERLIN, Aug 15 (Reuters) - Air Berlin, Germany's second largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday following years of losses and after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding, with bigger rival Lufthansa saying it is in talks to take over parts of the business.\n\nThe insolvency comes as thousands of Germans are enjoying their summer holidays and just ahead of a September general election.\n\nBut Berlin said it has granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($176 million) which will allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secures jobs for its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations continue.\n\nAir Berlin is in talks with Lufthansa and another airline about selling its assets, the government said, adding that it expected a decision in the coming weeks.\n\nLufthansa has already leased crewed planes from Air Berlin to provide flights by its Eurowings budget airline and has made no secret of its interest in taking on more of Air Berlin's business, although it has said debts and anti-trust issues were potential obstacles.\n\n\"Lufthansa has played a canny waiting game over a number of years and is now well-placed to cherry pick those parts of Air Berlin's operation that suit it best without buying the whole loss-making enterprise,\" Jonathan Wober, analyst at CAPA-Centre for Aviation, said.\n\nMALLORCA SHUTTLE\n\nAir Berlin, which became famous for its \"Mallorca shuttle\" services, piled up debt after a series of takeovers and concerns over its finances have hit bookings in recent months.\n\nIt has made a net loss in almost every year since 2008 and in 2016 reported a record loss of 782 million euros ($915 million), equivalent to a loss of more than 2 million euros a day.\n\nFunding from Etihad Airways, which bought into the airline in 2011, has helped to keep it afloat in recent years, but the Abu Dhabi-based airline has been reviewing its European investments after they failed to bring in the profit it expected.\n\nItalian national airline Alitalia, another of Etihad's investments, is also in administration and seeking bidders for its business.\n\nMeanwhile talks between Etihad and TUI, Europe's largest tour operator, about forming a joint venture holiday airline by merging TUIfly with Air Berlin's leisure airline Niki collapsed earlier this year.\n\nEtihad last provided additional funding of 250 million euros to Air Berlin in April.\n\n\"However, Air Berlin's business has deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions,\" Etihad said in a statement on Tuesday.\n\nShares in Air Berlin were down 39 percent at 0.47 euros by 1248 GMT, valuing the airline at around 45 million euros. Ten years ago the carrier was worth around 1 billion euros.\n\nLufthansa's shares were up 2.5 percent at 20.15 euros.\n\nPilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) blamed the shortcomings of past management at Air Berlin for the airline's financial woes and expressed anger with Etihad.\n\n\"It is a scandal that Etihad is dodging its responsibility and is leaving Air Berlin's staff out in the cold,\" VC President Ilja Schulz said in a statement. The strategy has not worked, as Etihad reported a $1.87 billion loss in 2016.\n\nEtihad also stopped funding another airline in which it invested, Italy's Alitalia, in May.\n\nAir Berlin lost one-quarter of its customers in the past year, and has been forced to pay millions of euros in compensation for delays and cancelled flights.\n\nIt will receive a loan from the German government totaling $176 million. {"timeCrawl": "12:16:00", "uri": "709752347", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T11:14:00Z", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "source": {"title": "Deutsche Welle (English)", "uri": "dw.com", "id": "430"}, "url": "http://www.dw.com/en/air-berlin-files-for-bankruptcy-protection/a-40095964", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Crisis-stricken German airline Air Berlin is seeking protection from its creditors after running out of cash to stay solvent. But the airline says it wants to remain in operation following a government bailout.\n\nCrisis-stricken German airline Air Berlin is seeking protection from its creditors after running out of cash to stay solvent. But the airline says it wants to remain in operation following a government bailout.\n\nIn a stock market filing Tuesday, Germany's second largest airline said it had filed for bankruptcy protection after its main shareholder, Gulf carrier Etihad, had withdrawn funding for Air Berlin.\n\nUnder these circumstances, Air Berlin had come to the conclusion that there was no \"positive prognosis for continuing the airline,\" the filing said. It added that two members of the board of directors, who joined after being nominated by Etihad, had resigned.\n\nHowever, the airline requested the right to carry out insolvency proceedings under its own management, which would \"facilitate negotiations with Lufthansa and other interested parties about a possible sale of Air Berlin operations,\" the airline said.\n\nAccording to German government sources, Berlin will support the plan with a bridge loan of 150 million euros ($176.2 million), ensuring that Air Berlin flights would continue according to schedule.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travelers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the Economics Ministry and Transportation Ministry said in a joint statement. \"The return flights of these travelers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nThe government funding also makes sure that Air Berlin aircraft currently under lease from rivals Eurowings and Austrian Airlines can stay in operation.\n\nLosses forever?\n\nStill in June, the German airline insisted it had sufficient cash to stay solvent despite suffering heavy losses and a string of flight cancellations. \"Insolvency is not an issue for us. We have sufficient liquidity and a reliable partner, Etihad, which has pledged its support through to October 2018,\" a spokeswoman said at the time.\n\nAir Berlin booked losses amounting to 1.2 billion euros for the last two years, and has depended on cash infusions from key shareholder Etihad for many years. Except for two quarters, Air Berlin has never turned a profit since 2008.\n\nIn a bid turn to the tide, the budget carrier has embarked on a massive restructuring plan in September 2016 that included renting 38 aircraft with crew to Lufthansa and slashing 1,200 jobs - about one in seven of its workforce.\n\nAmid the restructuring, it was hit by a series of flight cancellations and severe delays, leading to a flood of complaints. This has led to a massive drop in customers.\n\nBetween January and July, a total of 13.79 million passengers flew on the airline, marking a decrease of 16 per cent compared to the same period in 2016. In July alone, the total number of passengers served by Air Berlin fell by 24 percent compared to the same month last year.\n\nNow, Germany's flagship carrier, Lufthansa, appears to become Air Berlin's savior. Germany's biggest airline said Tuesday that it was \"already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the Airberlin Group and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff.\"", {"timeCrawl": "13:15:00", "uri": "709779142", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T13:15:00Z", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/air-berlin-files-for-insolvency-lufthansa-waits-in-the-wings/articleshow/60074472.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "By Victoria Bryan and Maria Sheahan\n\nBERLIN (Reuters) - Air Berlin, Germany's second largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday following years of losses and after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding, with bigger rival Lufthansa saying it is in talks to take over parts of the business.\n\nThe insolvency comes as thousands of Germans are enjoying their summer holidays and just ahead of a September general election.\n\nBut Berlin said it has granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($176 million) which will allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secures jobs for its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations continue.\n\nAir Berlin is in talks with Lufthansa and another airline about selling its assets, the government said, adding that it expected a decision in the coming weeks.\n\nLufthansa has already leased crewed planes from Air Berlin to provide flights by its Eurowings budget airline and has made no secret of its interest in taking on more of Air Berlin's business, although it has said debts and anti-trust issues were potential obstacles.\n\n\"Lufthansa has played a canny waiting game over a number of years and is now well-placed to cherry pick those parts of Air Berlin's operation that suit it best without buying the whole loss-making enterprise,\" Jonathan Wober, analyst at CAPA-Centre for Aviation, said.\n\nMALLORCA SHUTTLE\n\nAir Berlin, which became famous for its \"Mallorca shuttle\" services, piled up debt after a series of takeovers and concerns over its finances have hit bookings in recent months.\n\nIt has made a net loss in almost every year since 2008 and in 2016 reported a record loss of 782 million euros ($915 million), equivalent to a loss of more than 2 million euros a day.\n\nFunding from Etihad Airways, which bought into the airline in 2011, has helped to keep it afloat in recent years, but the Abu Dhabi-based airline has been reviewing its European investments after they failed to bring in the profit it expected.\n\nItalian national airline Alitalia, another of Etihad's investments, is also in administration and seeking bidders for its business.\n\nMeanwhile talks between Etihad and TUI, Europe's largest tour operator, about forming a joint venture holiday airline by merging TUIfly with Air Berlin's leisure airline Niki collapsed earlier this year.\n\nEtihad last provided additional funding of 250 million euros to Air Berlin in April.\n\n\"However, Air Berlin's business has deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions,\" Etihad said in a statement on Tuesday.\n\nShares in Air Berlin were down 39 percent at 0.47 euros by 1248 GMT, valuing the airline at around 45 million euros. Ten years ago the carrier was worth around 1 billion euros.\n\nLufthansa's shares were up 2.5 percent at 20.15 euros.\n\nPilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) blamed the shortcomings of past management at Air Berlin for the airline's financial woes and expressed anger with Etihad.\n\n\"It is a scandal that Etihad is dodging its responsibility and is leaving Air Berlin's staff out in the cold,\" VC President Ilja Schulz said in a statement.\n\n($1 = 0.8548 euros)\n\n(Reporting by Victoria Bryan, Maria Sheahan; and Gernot Heller; Editing by Greg Mahlich)\n\nGet latest news & live "eng-3363010", "body": "Air Berlin aircraft planning to land at Geneva's airport will have to pay landing fees in advance now that the German airline has entered insolvency, Swiss officials said on Tuesday.\n\nSwiss spokesman Bertrand Staempfli said that the company will have to make a payment of 500 francs (514 dollars) for every Air Berlin plane that lands at the Geneva airport.\n\n\"If advance payments are not possible, the airport would expect the payment be made by the pilot in cash, as has been the case with other airline bankruptcies.\n\n\"The pilot can make the payment in cash or by credit card at the airport terminal,'' Staempfli said.\n\nNineteen Air Berlin flights from Dusseldorf to Geneva are currently scheduled for the next seven days.\n\nThe Air Berlin, Germany's second biggest airline, filed for insolvency on Tuesday after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad Airways, withdrew financial aid for the loss-making carrier.\n\nThe move by the struggling airline forced the German government to step in to provide it with a temporary credit of 150 million euros (176 million dollars) to help it continue operating.\n\n\"Air Berlin operations can be carried on to its full extent, as a result avoiding a discontinuation of the airline operation,\" the Ministry for Economic Affairs said in a statement.\n\nREAD: International Drinks Festival Comes To Lagos\n\nThe Berlin-based court where the company filed for insolvency appointed Lucas Floether as trustee for the insolvency under self-administration later on Tuesday.\n\nAir Berlin said that it had applied for insolvency after it was told by Etihad that the Abu Dhabi company was ending its financial support for the company.\n\n\"This development is extremely disappointing for all parties, especially as Etihad has provided extensive support to airberlin for its previous liquidity challenges and restructuring efforts over the past six years,\" Etihad said in a statement.\n\nAir Berlin has operated at a loss every year since 2008, except for 2012, when it sold off its frequent flyer programme.\n\nEtihad acquired a 29.2 per cent stake in Air Berlin in 2012, becoming its largest shareholder and providing injections of capital to keep the airline afloat.\n\nGermany's biggest airline, Lufthansa, is now in talks with Air Berlin to take over sections of operations as part of a wider restructuring of Air Berlin, which ran up a loss last year of about 782 million euros and has debts totalling nearly 1.2 billion euros.\n\n\"Negotiations are very advanced, particularly with Lufthansa,\" German Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt said on Tuesday in Berlin, noting that other companies are also looking to acquire parts of Air Berlin.\n\nThe transport minister wouldn't expect a deal between Germany's two largest airlines to result in antitrust problems, because Lufthansa isn't interested in buying the entire company, but rather only parts of the insolvent resigned.\n\nIt said that the German federal government would support Air Berlin with a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($176.3 million) secured by a federal guarantee to maintain flight
