{"timeCrawl": "12:03:00", "uri": "710863122", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:03:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"title": "Handelsblatt Global Edition", "uri": "global.handelsblatt.com", "id": "17733"}, "url": "https://global.handelsblatt.com/companies-markets/air-berlins-state-rescue-sparks-turbulence-813610", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Lawmakers warn that taxpayers will never see their money back, while Ryanair's CEO accuses Berlin of a conspiracy to sell the airline to Lufthansa. There are also antitrust concerns.\n\nWith the holiday season at its height and the general election just five weeks away, Chancellor Angela Merkel could not have afforded to let the country's second-largest airline collapse.\n\n\"80,000 stranded holidaymakers, that's almost 80,000 voters. The political calculation is that simple,\" said one official in Berlin.\n\nBut the government's decision on Tuesday to grant a bridging loan of \u20ac150 million (\u20ac177 million) has caused controversy. The aim of the loan is to keep Air Berlin, which on Tuesday filed for bankruptcy protection after its biggest shareholder Etihad refused to make further funds available, operational for three months pending talks to sell it.\n\nMs. Merkel tried to limit the political fallout on Wednesday. Asked in a YouTube interview how big the risk was that taxpayers would pay for a rescue, Ms. Merkel said: \"That is quite low, otherwise we would not have been allowed to grant this bridge loan ... We can say that in all likelihood the taxpayer will not have to pay for that.\"\n\n\"Air Berlin isn't a systemically relevant company. I ask myself why the government has gotten involved.\"\n\nBut even members of her own party doubt that. \"We're never going to see those \u20ac150 million again,\" said Michael Fuchs, economic policy spokesman for Ms. Merkel's conservatives.\n\nIn the first quarter, Air Berlin lost \u20ac23.5 million a month. Analysts expect even bigger losses in the second quarter which was beset by delays and cancellations as the airline's troubles deepened. The second-quarter results haven't been published yet.\n\nEconomics Minister Brigitte Zypries and Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt are pinning their hopes for a repayment of the loan on the sale of its attractive take-off and landing slots in Germany.\n\nThe problem is that Air Berlin's management recently revised down the value of those slots to \u20ac80 million from \u20ac176 million.\n\nOpposition politicians have scented blood. \"Economics Minister Brigitte Zypries has failed on all levels,\" said Michael Theurer of the pro-business Free Democratic Party.\n\nDieter Janecek, economic policy spokesman of the Greens, said: \"Air Berlin isn't a systemically relevant company. I ask myself why the government has gotten involved.\"\n\nNational carrier Lufthansa is likely to clinch many of those prized slots because its long-running presence at the airports affected will make it eligible for preferential treatment in their allocation. Such a deal, however, might be subject to strict conditions to prevent Lufthansa from gaining a dominant position at these airports, the head of Germany's antitrust watchdog, Achim Wambach, told newspaper Rheinische Post.\n\nTransport Minister Alexander Dobrindt said antitrust issues should not narrowed down to market positions in individual, regional airports.\n\n\"We need a German champion in international air travel,\" Mr. Dobrindt was quoted as saying by Rheinische Post on Thursday. \"Therefore it is of the utmost importance that Lufthansa is able to buy substantial parts of Air Berlin.\"\n\nThere's an alternative scenario in which Lufthansa would obtain the slots by acquiring parts of the airline. Air Berlin already flies 38 planes for Lufthansa and that business has been placed in a separate company, Air Berlin Aeronautics GmbH, to shield it from an insolvency. In theory, Lufthansa could place other parts of Air Berlin that it's interested in, such as its long-haul jets, into that company and then wholly acquire it. Or it could buy the individual planes and their crews one by one.\n\nIn addition to Lufthansa, two other carriers are interested in buying parts of Air Berlin, the insolvent firm's Chief Executive Thomas Winkelmann told newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine. Travel agency Thomas cook and its airline subsidiary Condor have expressed interest in Air Berlin's operations, while insiders told news agency Reuters that Easyjet was also among the parties eyeing assets.\n\nIrish budget rival Ryanair has lodged a complaint with the German antitrust regulator, the Bundeskartellamt, and the European Commission, accusing the German government of providing \"unlawful state aid\" and of conspiring with Lufthansa to carve up Air Berlin.\n\n\"There's nobody out there at the moment speaking for German consumers or for visitors to Germany who will be paying much higher air fares.\"\n\nIn an interview with Handelsblatt, Ryanair Chief Executive Michael O'Leary said the government was providing the loan so that Lufthansa can take over Air Berlin.\n\n\"This will involve the number one airline in Germany taking over the number two airline in Germany, eliminating almost all competition on German domestic routes so that Lufthansa can increase air fares even higher and penalize German consumers even more,\" Mr. O'Leary said.\n\n\"And there's nobody out there at the moment speaking for German consumers or for visitors to Germany who will be paying much higher air fares. If Lufthansa wants to acquire Air Berlin, why didn't Lufthansa lend Air Berlin \u20ac150 million? They're going to break almost every known German and EU competition rule on the basis of 'Air Berlin is in financial difficulty and we've got to protect German passengers.' It shows yet again that there's one rule for the Germans and a different rule for everybody else.\"\n\nHe added that Ryanair and other airlines would be interested in buying parts of Air Berlin if it went through a \"normal and fair\" liquidation process.\n\nThe German government said its support for Air Berlin did not breach antitrust rules. And a spokeswoman for the EU Commission said she was \"confident that solutions can be found in keeping with EU law.\" She said complaints such as the one lodged by Ryanair would not delay the process.\n\nThis isn't, of course, the first time that the German government has intervened to shore up a struggling company. In 1999, then-Chancellor Gerhard Schr\u00f6der boosted his failing approval ratings by arranging a state loan to save construction group Holzmann. The company went bust before the loan was paid out, however.\n\nIn 2002, cellphone company Mobilcom came knocking and got \u20ac50 million in assistance from state-owned development bank KfW, \u20ac270 million less than it had requested.\n\nIn the financial crisis, Germany used KfW to make \u20ac40 billion available for firms that were healthy but couldn't get credit. Only a fraction of that money was every used.\n\nAir Berlin's staff, meanwhile, will be watching developments even more anxiously than holidaymakers. Flight crews have the best chance of keeping their jobs, but they will face salary cuts because Lufthansa will likely employ them under the contract of its budget unit Eurowings which pays less than Air Berlin.\n\nBut the future looks gloomy for Air Berlin's ground staff such as maintenance crews and administrative employees.", "id": "9680942", "details": {"liCnt": 12}, "date": "2017-08-17", {"timeCrawl": "13:17:00", "uri": "710898577", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T13:17:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"title": "Agence France Presse (AFP)", "uri": "afp.com", "id": "2391"}, "url": "https://www.afp.com/en/news/2266/three-airlines-jostling-air-berlin-assets-ceo", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "He did not name the other two airlines, but German media have speculated that EasyJet and Thomas Cook subsidiary Condor are the other parties.\n\nContacted by AFP, Condor said it stood ready to play \"an active role\" in the restructuring of Air Berlin. EasyJet declined to comment.\n\nAir Berlin filed for insolvency on Tuesday after main shareholder Etihad Airways suddenly pulled the plug on years of financial support for the loss-making airline.\n\nIn a controversial move, the government stepped in with a 150-million-euro ($170-million) bridging loan to keep Germany's second-largest airline flying for the next three months, saying it did not want to leave holidaymakers stranded.\n\nGerman flagship carrier Lufthansa is aiming to take over 90 of Air Berlin's 140 planes and operate them under its low-cost Eurowings brand, the Sueddeutsche Zeitung reported, citing sources close to the talks.\n\nThe number includes the 38 aircraft Lufthansa is already leasing from Air Berlin, as well as the roughly 20 planes operated by Austrian subsidiary Niki, the newspaper said, adding that a deal could be sealed \"in coming weeks\".\n\nSpeaking to the Frankfurter Allgemeine, Winkelmann said he aimed to reach agreements with at least two of the interested buyers in September, with Air Berlin's landing rights considered particularly valuable.\n\n\"But we won't be able to save all jobs,\" the paper quoted Winkelmann as saying.\n\nThe airline, sometimes dubbed the \"Mallorca shuttle\" for its popularity with German tourists headed for Spanish beaches, employs some 8,000 people.\n\nIt has long battled for survival, booking losses amounting to 1.2 billion euros over the past two years and relying on cash infusions from Abu-Dhabi-based Etihad.\n\nAn Air Berlin spokesman told AFP the company could not immediately say when it would announce its first-half results, originally scheduled to be released on Friday.\n\n- 'Conspiracy' -\n\nThe government's intervention, just weeks before a September 24 general election, to keep Air Berlin in the air for now has come in for criticism.\n\nIrish budget rival Ryanair has lodged complaints with German and European competition regulators, slamming what it called a \"conspiracy\" between the government, Lufthansa and Air Berlin to carve up the insolvent carrier's assets.\n\n\"If this unlawful take over goes ahead, we may struggle to get slots in major airports such as Berlin, Munich and Frankfurt where Lufthansa will have control on over 80 percent of the slots,\" Ryanair said in a statement.\n\nThe head of Germany's anti-trust commission, Achim Wambach, told the Rheinische Post newspaper that Lufthansa could expect \"tough conditions\" over its acquisition plans given that the country's largest carrier and Air Berlin were \"direct competitors\" on many routes.\n\nThe German government has fiercely defended its decision to help Air Berlin, with Foreign Minister Sigmar Gabriel saying the financial lifeline was needed to prevent 80,000 travellers a day from being stranded during the busy holiday period.\n\nBut a government official told the Handelsblatt financial daily the state aid was a clear example of electioneering.\n\n\"Eighty thousand stranded holidaymakers are almost 80,000 voters. That's how simple the political calculation is,\" the unnamed source said.", "id": "9695507", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Three airlines jostling for Air Berlin assets: CEO", {"timeCrawl": "13:17:00", "uri": "710898573", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T13:17:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"title": "GULF NEWS", "uri": "gulfnews.com", "id": "3935"}, "url": "http://gulfnews.com/business/aviation/air-berlin-aims-for-asset-sales-to-at-least-two-buyers-by-end-sept-ceo-1.2075795", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Frankfurt: Insolvent German airline Air Berlin aims to strike deals to sell assets to two or more buyers by the end of September, before a government loan keeping its planes in the air runs out, its chief executive said.\n\nThe group is in talks with a total of three aviation firms, including Lufthansa, German newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung (FAZ) quoted Thomas Winkelmann as saying in its Thursday edition.\n\nAll three are \"reputable in terms of their finances, sufficiently large to offer Air Berlin a secure future and are interested in keeping Germany as a base of operations\", he said, without naming any of the interested parties.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses, leaving valuable runway slots up for grabs.\n\nThe insolvency comes with thousands of Germans enjoying summer holidays, and just ahead of a September general election.\n\nThe German government granted a bridging loan of \u20ac150 million (Dh644 million) to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations go on.\n\nThe move offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against expansion by low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nAccording to Winkelmann, the negotiations also include assets of Air Berlin unit Niki, which Etihad had agreed to buy for \u20ac300 million ($354 million) earlier this year.\n\nSeizing opportunities\n\nRedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND), a group which represents German newspapers, cited government sources as saying that Lufthansa, its budget carrier Eurowings and Condor would likely snap up Air Berlin's most valuable landing slots.\n\nIt said a few slots could also go to Ryanair, which has filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nLufthansa has confirmed it is in talks to take over parts of Air Berlin's business, while a source has said easyJet was also part of the negotiations.\n\nThomas Cook's German airline Condor said on Wednesday it was ready to play \"an active role\" in Air Berlin's restructuring, without being more specific.\n\nGermany's Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt said the asset sales were an opportunity for the country's aviation sector to bolster its footprint.\n\n\"The opportunity should be seized to strategically position the 140 aircraft, the capacities and the employees of Air Berlin and strengthen the position of Germany's aviation sector in the international market,\" German daily Bild quoted him as saying.", "id": "9695508", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "body": "A first round of formal talks for the sale of insolvent German airline Air Berlin's assets will be held with its bigger local rival Lufthansa on Friday.\n\nThese talks will take place ahead of other prospective bidders, a senior labour union official told Reuters.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.\n\nWith many Germans travelling on their summer holidays and a September general election looming, Berlin has granted a bridging loan of \u20ac150 million to keep Air Berlin's planes in the air for up to three months while buyers for its assets are found.\n\nThat means that the race is on to carve up the airline and obtain anti-trust approval for any deals before Air Berlin runs out of cash.\n\nTransport Minister Alexander Dobrindt has called for Lufthansa to buy a major part of the assets, saying Germany needs a \"national champion\" in international aviation.\n\nHis comments came after rival European airline Ryanair filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the handling of the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nOne scenario Lufthansa Chief Executive Carsten Spohr has presented to the flagship carrier's supervisory board is that it could take on as many as 90 of Air Berlin's roughly 140 leased planes, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters.\n\nThat would include the 38 aircraft that Lufthansa is already leasing from Air Berlin and its leisure airline Niki, which is not part of the insolvency proceedings.\n\nAir Berlin has been in preliminary talks with a total of three aviation firms, including Lufthansa, over the sale of its assets, Chief Executive Thomas Winkelmann told Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung (FAZ), and aims to strike deals with at least two of them by the end of September.\n\nEarlier this week a source familiar with the matter said easyJet was among those in talks, and Thomas Cook's German airline Condor said it was ready to play \"an active role\" in Air Berlin's restructuring.\n\nThe airline's demise also offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire coveted runway slots at Air Berlin's hub airports, Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position {"timeCrawl": "15:06:00", "uri": "709828051", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T15:06:00Z", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "source": {"title": "Clearfield Gant Daily", "uri": "gantdaily.com", "id": "537"}, "url": "http://gantdaily.com/2017/08/15/german-airline-goes-bust-after-etihad-pulls-plug/", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Air Berlin has gone bust, but passengers needn't panic just yet.\n\nGermany's second biggest airline filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday after Abu Dhabi's Etihad -- its leading shareholder -- refused to finance another bailout.\n\nAir Berlin will continue flying for the time being thanks to a loan of \u20ac150 million ($176 million) from the German government. That should also allow all 7,200 employees to keep their jobs while executives try to restructure or sell the company.\n\n\"Air Berlin's business has deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions,\" Etihad said in a statement.\n\n\"Under these circumstances, as a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure.\"\n\nAir Berlin has struggled for years to turn a profit despite serving more than 2 million passengers a month.\n\nIt has been squeezed by bigger European low cost carriers such as Ryanair and EasyJet, and competition from the no-frills divisions of national carriers.\n\nOne such rival, Germany's Lufthansa, said Tuesday it was in talks to buy parts of Air Berlin.\n\nThe failure of Air Berlin is a major setback for Etihad, which has invested just over \u20ac1.8 billion ($2.2 billion) in the carrier since 2011, according to an Etihad source who asked to remain anonymous.\n\nEtihad's once novel strategy of investing in other airlines has weighed heavily on the company's bottom line. Last year, it reported a hefty loss after booking an $808 million charge for its exposure to Alitalia, Air Berlin and other \"equity partners.\"\n\nIt pulled the plug on Alitalia earlier this year, prompting the Italian national carrier to enter administration. The Italian government is now trying to find a buyer.\n\n-John Defterios and Chris Burns contributed to this report.", "id": "9302614", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "German airline {"timeCrawl": "14:56:00", "uri": "710381990", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T14:56:00Z", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "source": {"title": "BBC News", "uri": "bbc.co.uk", "id": "264"}, "url": "http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-40949243", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Ryanair has accused Lufthansa and the German government of conspiring to carve up collapsed airline Air Berlin.\n\nAir Berlin filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday, after the Abu Dhabi-based airline Etihad ended its financial support for the airline.\n\nHowever, Air Berlin planes are still flying, thanks to a \u20ac150m German government loan.\n\nRyanair said there was an \"obvious conspiracy\" between Germany, Lufthansa and Air Berlin to carve up the assets.\n\nAir Berlin's passenger numbers have been in freefall. Last month the airline - Germany's second-biggest carrier - lost a quarter of its customers compared with July last year.\n\nGermany's economy minister, Brigitte Zypries, said that a deal whereby Lufthansa took over part of the insolvent airline should be struck in the next few months.\n\nRyanair said: \"This manufactured insolvency is clearly being set up to allow Lufthansa to take over a debt-free Air Berlin which will be in breach of all known German and EU competition rules.\n\n\"Now even the German government is supporting this Lufthansa-led monopoly with 150m euros of state aid so that Lufthansa can acquire Air Berlin and drive domestic air fares in Germany even higher than they already are.\"\n\nRyanair has lodged competition complaints with the German regulator, the Bundeskartellamt, and the European Commission.\n\nLufthansa said it was already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the company and is exploring the possibility of hiring additional staff. \"Lufthansa intends to conclude these negotiations successfully in due time.\"\n\nRyanair has in the past made other criticisms of the relationship between Air Berlin and Lufthansa.\n\nLufthansa has been operating 38 Air Berlin Airbus jets on its behalf under a \"wet lease\" arrangement. In January Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary described the deal as a \"joke\".\n\nHe told the German magazine WirtschaftsWoche that the deal was \"a takeover with the aim of dominating the market. Lufthansa controls the capacities of its most important competitor, sets the prices and decides where aircraft will start. The German authorities are doing nothing\".\n\nHowever, the demise of Air Berlin could open up the German market to more competition.\n\nRyanair and EasyJet have only managed to get a toehold at airports such as Berlin, Cologne/Bonn, D\u00fcsseldorf and Frankfurt.\n\nGerald Khoo, transport analyst at Liberium Capital, said: \"Based on August schedules, Germany currently represents just 9% of EasyJet's capacity and 7% of Ryanair's, compared with 76% of Lufthansa's, highlighting the relative importance of that market to each carrier.\"\n\nRyanair has been targeting the German market, with new routes to and from Frankfurt.\n\nMr Khooo said: \"We would expect German airports to move up the list of priorities for next summer for both major low cost carriers, whether or not they attempt to pick up assets and/or staff from Air Berlin's bankruptcy process.\"\n\nReuters reported on Tuesday that Easyjet was in talks to buy assets from Air Berlin. {"timeCrawl": "17:44:00", "uri": "710463596", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T17:44:00Z", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "source": {"title": "headlinesnews.net", "uri": "headlinesnews.net", "id": "1397"}, "url": "http://headlinesnews.net/ryanair-accuses-lufthansa-of-air-berlin-conspiracy/", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Ryanair has accused Lufthansa and the German government of conspiring to carve up collapsed airline Air Berlin.\n\nLufthansa is negotiating over buying Air Berlin planes, which are still flying following a 150m euro German government loan.\n\nRyanair said there was an \"obvious conspiracy\" between Germany, Lufthansa and Air Berlin to carve up the assets.\n\nThe German government rejected the accusation and said its support for Air Berlin did not breach anti-trust rules.\n\nAir Berlin filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday, after its biggest shareholder, the Abu Dhabi-based airline Etihad, withdraw its financial support.\n\nOver the past year Air Berlin's passenger numbers have been in freefall. Last month the airline - Germany's second-biggest carrier - lost a quarter of its customers compared with July last year.\n\n'Manufactured insolvency'\n\nGermany's economy minister, Brigitte Zypries, said that a deal whereby Lufthansa took over part of the insolvent airline should be struck in the next few months.\n\nRyanair said: \"This manufactured insolvency is clearly being set up to allow Lufthansa to take over a debt-free Air Berlin which will be in breach of all known German and EU competition rules.\n\n\"Now even the German government is supporting this Lufthansa-led monopoly with 150m euros of state aid so that Lufthansa can acquire Air Berlin and drive domestic air fares in Germany even higher than they already are.\"\n\nA German economy spokeswoman said: \"I reject the accusation by Ryanair today that it was a staged insolvency application.\"\n\nRyanair has lodged a complaint with the German regulator, the Bundeskartellamt, and the European Commission.\n\nLufthansa said it was already in negotiations with Air Berlin to take over parts of the company and was considering hiring more staff: \"Lufthansa intends to conclude these negotiations successfully in due time.\"\n\nOther criticisms\n\nRyanair has in the past made other criticisms of the relationship between Air Berlin and Lufthansa.\n\nLufthansa has been operating 38 Air Berlin Airbus jets on its behalf under a \"wet lease\" arrangement. In January Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary described the deal as a \"joke\".\n\nHe told the German magazine WirtschaftsWoche that the deal was \"a takeover with the aim of dominating the market. Lufthansa controls the capacities of its most important competitor, sets the prices and decides where aircraft will start. The German authorities are doing nothing\".\n\nLufthansa's interest in Air Berlin has also upset its own staff.\n\nAt its Eurowings subsidiary, unions are balloting cabin crew about industrial action after pay talks broke down - something the unions blame on Air Berlin's collapse.\n\nGerman cabin crew union UFO said: \"The reasons why no solution could be worked out with Eurowings management became clear yesterday: the Lufthansa group can obtain cheap aircraft through Air Berlin's insolvency and doesn't need to take on its staff or their wage agreements.\"\n\nMore competition\n\nHowever, the demise of Air Berlin could open up the German market to more competition.\n\nRyanair and EasyJet have only managed to get a toehold at airports such as Berlin, Cologne/Bonn, D\u00fcsseldorf and Frankfurt.\n\nGerald Khoo, transport analyst at Liberium Capital, said: \"Based on August schedules, Germany currently represents just 9% of EasyJet's capacity and 7% of Ryanair's, compared with 76% of Lufthansa's, highlighting the relative importance of that market to each carrier.\"\n\nRyanair has been targeting the German market, with new routes to and from Frankfurt.\n\nMr Khooo said: \"We would expect German airports to move up the list of priorities for next summer for both major low cost carriers, whether or not they attempt to pick up assets and/or staff from Air Berlin's bankruptcy process.\"\n\nReuters reported on Tuesday that Easyjet was in talks to buy assets from Air Berlin. {"timeCrawl": "12:17:00", "uri": "709752451", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T12:17:00Z", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "source": {"title": "Zawya", "uri": "zawya.com", "id": "3109"}, "url": "http://www.zawya.com/mena/en/story/German_Air_Berlin_files_for_insolvency_after_UAEs_Etihad_Airways_withdraws_support-TR20170815nL8N1L12WGX2/", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "BERLIN, Aug 15 (Reuters) - Struggling German airline Air Berlin filed for insolvency on Tuesday after years of losses caught up with it and shareholder Etihad withdrew funding, with rival Lufthansa saying it was in talks to take over parts of its business.\n\nAir Berlin, whose debt piled up after a series of takeovers, has seen speculation over its finances hit bookings. Funding from Etihad, which bought into the airline in 2011, has helped to keep it afloat in recent years, but the Abu Dhabi-based airline has been reviewing its European investments after they failed to bring it the profit it expected.\n\nEtihad last provided additional funding of 250 million euros ($293 million) to Air Berlin in April.\n\n\"However, Air Berlin's business has deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions,\" Etihad said in a statement.\n\nAir Berlin said its flights were continuing. The German government said it had provided a bridge loan of 150 million euros.\n\nAdvertisement Shares in Air Berlin were suspended from trade until 1205 GMT. Lufthansa's stock extended gains to trade 2.2 percent higher at 20.09 euros by 1140 GMT.\n\n($1 = 0.8520 euros)\n\n(Reporting by Victoria Bryan; Editing by Maria Sheahan) {"timeCrawl": "07:47:00", "uri": "711316984", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T07:47:00Z", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "source": {"title": "RTE.ie", "uri": "rte.ie", "id": "1151"}, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2017/0818/898236-air-berlin-lufthansa/", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "A first round of formal talks for the sale of insolvent German airline Air Berlin's assets will be held with its bigger local rival Lufthansa today, ahead of other prospective bidders, a senior labour union official has said.\n\n\"Only Lufthansa will initially be part of the talks ... As far as I know, the other bidders will be invited for talks afterward and then an overall package will be put together,\" said Lufthansa's deputy chair Christine Behle, who represents labour union Verdi on the company's supervisory board.\n\nShe also told Reuters negotiations would begin on Friday and she expected them to continue through the weekend.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.\n\nWith many Germans travelling on their summer holidays and a September general election looming, Berlin has granted a bridging loan of \u20ac150m to keep Air Berlin's planes in the air for up to three months and secure 7,200 jobs in Germany while buyers for its assets are found.\n\nThat means that the race is on to carve up the airline and obtain anti-trust approval for any deals before Air Berlin runs out of cash.\n\nTransport Minister Alexander Dobrindt has called for Lufthansa to buy a major part of the assets, saying Germany needs a \"national champion\" in international aviation.\n\n\"That is why it is urgently necessary that Lufthansa can take over significant parts of Air Berlin,\" he told daily newspaper Rheinische Post.\n\nHis comments came after rival Ryanair filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the handling of the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nGermany's transport ministry already faces allegations by the European Commission of maintaining a cosy relationship with its domestic industry and questions about whether authorities did enough to uncover an emissions scandal at carmaker Volkswagen, which is partially state-owned.\n\nOne scenario Lufthansa Chief Executive Carsten Spohr has presented to the flagship carrier's supervisory board is that it could take on as many as 90 of Air Berlin's roughly 140 leased planes, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters.\n\nThat would include the 38 aircraft that Lufthansa is already leasing from Air Berlin and its leisure airline Niki, which is not part of the insolvency proceedings.\n\n\"These are ideas that Lufthansa is bringing into the talks,\" the source said, adding no decisions had been made yet. Another source said the number of aircraft Lufthansa wanted to take was smaller.\n\nAir Berlin has been in preliminary talks with a total of three aviation firms, including Lufthansa, over the sale of its assets, Chief Executive Thomas Winkelmann told Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, and aims to strike deals with at least two of them by the end of September.\n\nEarlier this week a source familiar with the matter said Easyjet was among those in talks, and Thomas Cook's German airline Condor said it was ready to play \"an active role\" in Air Berlin's restructuring.\n\nThe airline's demise also offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire coveted runway slots at Air Berlin's hub airports, Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "FRANKFURT (Reuters) - Insolvent German airline Air Berlin aims to strike deals to sell assets to two or more buyers by the end of September, before a government loan keeping its planes in the air runs out, its chief executive said.\n\nThe group is in talks with a total of three aviation firms, including Lufthansa, German newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung (FAZ) quoted Thomas Winkelmann as saying in its Thursday edition.\n\nAll three are \"reputable in terms of their finances, sufficiently large to offer Air Berlin a secure future and are interested in keeping Germany as a base of operations\", he said, without naming any of the interested parties.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses, leaving valuable runway slots up for grabs.\n\nThe insolvency comes with thousands of Germans enjoying summer holidays, and just ahead of a September general election.\n\nThe German government granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations go on.\n\nThe move offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against expansion by low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nAccording to Winkelmann, the negotiations also include assets of Air Berlin unit Niki, which Etihad had agreed to buy for 300 million euros ($354 million) earlier this year.\n\nSEIZING OPPORTUNITIES\n\nRedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND), a group which represents German newspapers, cited government sources as saying that Lufthansa, its budget carrier Eurowings and Condor would likely snap up Air Berlin's most valuable landing slots.\n\nIt said a few slots could also go to Ryanair, which has filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nLufthansa has confirmed it is in talks to take over parts of Air Berlin's business, while a source has said easyJet was also part of the negotiations.\n\nThomas Cook's German airline Condor said on Wednesday it was ready to play \"an active role\" in Air Berlin's restructuring, without being more specific.\n\nGermany's Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt said the asset sales were an opportunity for the country's aviation sector to bolster its footprint.\n\n\"The opportunity should be seized to strategically position the 140 aircraft, the capacities and the employees of Air Berlin and strengthen the position of Germany's aviation sector in the international market,\" German daily Bild quoted him as saying.($1 = 0.8485 euros)\n\n(Reporting by Maria Sheahan; editing by Robert Birsel and Alexander {"timeCrawl": "10:38:00", "uri": "710824825", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:38:00Z", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/air-berlin-aims-for-asset-sales-to-at-least-two-buyers-by-end-sept-ceo/articleshow/60102173.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "FRANKFURT (Reuters) - Insolvent German airline Air Berlin aims to strike deals to sell assets to two or more buyers by the end of September, before a government loan keeping its planes in the air runs out, its chief executive said.\n\nThe group is in talks with a total of three aviation firms, including Lufthansa, German newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung (FAZ) quoted Thomas Winkelmann as saying in its Thursday edition.\n\nAll three are \"reputable in terms of their finances, sufficiently large to offer Air Berlin a secure future and are interested in keeping Germany as a base of operations\", he said, without naming any of the interested parties.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses, leaving valuable runway slots up for grabs.\n\nThe insolvency comes with thousands of Germans enjoying summer holidays, and just ahead of a September general election.\n\nThe German government granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations go on.\n\nThe move offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against expansion by low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nAccording to Winkelmann, the negotiations also include assets of Air Berlin unit Niki, which Etihad had agreed to buy for 300 million euros ($354 million) earlier this year.\n\nSEIZING OPPORTUNITIES\n\nRedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND), a group which represents German newspapers, cited government sources as saying that Lufthansa, its budget carrier Eurowings and Condor would likely snap up Air Berlin's most valuable landing slots.\n\nIt said a few slots could also go to Ryanair, which has filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nLufthansa has confirmed it is in talks to take over parts of Air Berlin's business, while a source has said easyJet was also part of the negotiations.\n\nThomas Cook's German airline Condor said on Wednesday it was ready to play \"an active role\" in Air Berlin's restructuring, without being more specific.\n\nGermany's Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt said the asset sales were an opportunity for the country's aviation sector to bolster its footprint.\n\n\"The opportunity should be seized to strategically position the 140 aircraft, the capacities and the employees of Air Berlin and strengthen the position of Germany's aviation sector in the international market,\" German daily Bild quoted him as saying.($1 = 0.8485 euros)\n\n(Reporting by Maria Sheahan; editing {"timeCrawl": "16:45:00", "uri": "709873015", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T16:43:00Z", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "source": {"title": "The Guardian", "uri": "theguardian.com", "id": "260"}, "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/business/2017/aug/15/easyjet-air-berlin-adminstration-lufthansa-etihad", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "EasyJet could spread its wings in Germany as it emerged as a potential buyer for parts of Air Berlin, which filed for administration on Tuesday.\n\nThe German government has provided an emergency \u20ac150m (\u00a3137m) loan to Air Berlin to enable it to keep flying its schedules.\n\nAir Berlin is the second largest airline in Germany, but has struggled financially for years. It was propped up by its main shareholder, Etihad, but the Gulf airline announced it was no longer willing to invest.\n\nLufthansa is in talks and would be well placed to take over most of its ailing competitor - prompting criticism from rival Ryanair.\n\nEasyJet would be keen to acquire slots to boost its small presence in Germany, where Lufthansa dominates. However, it is unlikely to countenance a full takeover: Air Berlin operates a large Airbus fleet similar to easyJet's but also has more than 100 Boeing planes, as well as high costs and pension liabilities.\n\nAn easyJet spokesman said it would not comment on speculation.\n\nAir Berlin made losses of \u20ac782m in 2016. Etihad, which owns almost 30% of Air Berlin, said the developments were \"extremely disappointing\" but it could not keep injecting cash, after investing an additional \u20ac250m in April.\n\nAn Etihad spokesman said: \"Air Berlin's business has deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions. Under these circumstances, as a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure.\"\n\nThe Gulf airline had also invested heavily in the perennially loss-making Alitalia before deciding to stem the cashflow earlier this year, pushing the Italian carrier similarly into administration.\n\nThe German government, like Italy's before it with Alitalia, is now helping to find a solution to protect jobs. Ryanair, which has bid for Alitalia, is not believed to be seeking any part of Air Berlin.\n\nA Ryanair spokesman said: \"This is clearly being set up for Lufthansa to take over Air Berlin, which will be in breach of all known German and EU competition rules. Now even the German government is supporting this Lufthansa-led deal with \u20ac150m of state aid. German customers and visitors will suffer higher air fares to pay for this Lufthansa monopoly.\"\n\nAnalysts said that a Lufthansa takeover would indeed mainly be to thwart the likes of Ryanair. Damian Brewer of RBS said: \"For Lufthansa we see any moves as defensive - blocking other more competitive airlines from expanding. If acquired, Air Berlin's Dusseldorf airport slots would likely be a valuable asset to Lufthansa while freezing new entrants out of the 'full' airport, unless the German authorities require slots to {"timeCrawl": "00:47:00", "uri": "711184829", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:47:00Z", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "source": {"title": "Irish Examiner", "uri": "irishexaminer.com", "id": "817"}, "url": "http://www.irishexaminer.com/business/lufthansa-may-buy-bulk-of-air-berlin-fleet-457274.html", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Air Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.\n\nGerman Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt has backed Lufthansa to buy a major portion of Air Berlin's assets, saying Germany needed a \"national champion\" in international aviation. Berlin has granted a bridging loan of \u20ac150m that will keep Air Berlin's planes in the air for up to three months, securing 7,200 jobs in Germany while buyers for its assets are found.\n\nAir Berlin's demise offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nAccording to sources, one scenario Lufthansa's chief executive Carsten Spohr has presented to the flagship carrier's supervisory board is that it could take on as many as 90 of Air Berlin's roughly 140 planes. Air Berlin has said it is in talks with three aviation firms and aims to strike deals with at least two of them by the end of September.\n\nGerman media has cited government sources as saying that Lufthansa, its budget carrier Eurowings, and Thomas Cook's German airline Condor would likely snap up Air Berlin's most valuable landing slots.\n\nSources suggest a few slots could also go to Ryanair, which has filed a complaint with German and EU competition authorities over the insolvency process, which it describes as a \"conspiracy\".", "id": "9801722", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-18", {"timeCrawl": "15:09:00", "uri": "709829089", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T15:09:00Z", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "source": {"title": "erienewsnow.com", "uri": "erienewsnow.com", "id": "2128"}, "url": "http://www.erienewsnow.com/story/36138907/german-airline-goes-bust-after-etihad-pulls-plug", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "LONDON (CNNMoney) -- Air Berlin has gone bust, but passengers needn't panic just yet.\n\nGermany's second biggest airline filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday after Abu Dhabi's Etihad -- its leading shareholder -- refused to finance another bailout.\n\nAir Berlin will continue flying for the time being thanks to a loan of \u20ac150 million ($176 million) from the German government. That should also allow all 7,200 employees to keep their jobs while executives try to restructure or sell the company.\n\n\"Air Berlin's business has deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions,\" Etihad said in a statement.\n\n\"Under these circumstances, as a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure.\"\n\nAir Berlin has struggled for years to turn a profit despite serving more than 2 million passengers a month.\n\nIt has been squeezed by bigger European low cost carriers such as Ryanair and EasyJet, and competition from the no-frills divisions of national carriers.\n\nOne such rival, Germany's Lufthansa, said Tuesday it was in talks to buy parts of Air Berlin.\n\nThe failure of Air Berlin is a major setback for Etihad, which has invested just over \u20ac1.8 billion ($2.2 billion) in the carrier since 2011, according to an Etihad source who asked to remain anonymous.\n\nEtihad's once novel strategy of investing in other airlines has weighed heavily on the company's bottom line. Last year, it reported a hefty loss after booking an $808 million charge for its exposure to Alitalia, Air Berlin and other \"equity partners.\"\n\nIt pulled the plug on Alitalia earlier this year, prompting the Italian national carrier to enter administration. The Italian government is now trying to find a buyer.\n\n--John Defterios and Chris Burns contributed to this report.\n\nTM & \u00a9 2017 Cable News Network, Inc., a Time Warner Company. {"timeCrawl": "17:17:00", "uri": "711017610", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T17:17:00Z", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/germanys-lufthansa-gets-first-say-on-air-berlin-asset-sale-union/articleshow/60107682.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "By Victoria Bryan and Maria Sheahan\n\nBERLIN/FRANKFURT (Reuters) - A first round of formal talks for the sale of insolvent German airline Air Berlin's assets will be held with its bigger local rival Lufthansa on Friday, ahead of other prospective bidders, a senior labour union official said.\n\n\"Only Lufthansa will initially be part of the talks ... As far as I know, the other bidders will be invited for talks afterward and then an overall package will be put together,\" said Lufthansa's deputy chair Christine Behle, who represents labour union Verdi on the company's supervisory board.\n\nShe also told Reuters negotiations would begin on Friday and she expected them to continue through the weekend.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.\n\nWith many Germans travelling on their summer holidays and a September general election looming, Berlin has granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($176 million) to keep Air Berlin's planes in the air for up to three months and secure 7,200 jobs in Germany while buyers for its assets are found.\n\nThat means that the race is on to carve up the airline and obtain anti-trust approval for any deals before Air Berlin runs out of cash.\n\nTransport Minister Alexander Dobrindt has called for Lufthansa to buy a major part of the assets, saying Germany needs a \"national champion\" in international aviation.\n\n\"That is why it is urgently necessary that Lufthansa can take over significant parts of Air Berlin,\" he told daily newspaper Rheinische Post.\n\nHis comments came after rival European airline Ryanair filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the handling of the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nGermany's transport ministry already faces allegations by the European Commission of maintaining a cosy relationship with its domestic industry and questions about whether authorities did enough to uncover an emissions scandal at carmaker Volkswagen, which is partially state-owned.\n\nAIRCRAFT DEAL\n\nOne scenario Lufthansa Chief Executive Carsten Spohr has presented to the flagship carrier's supervisory board is that it could take on as many as 90 of Air Berlin's roughly 140 leased planes, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters.\n\nThat would include the 38 aircraft that Lufthansa is already leasing from Air Berlin and its leisure airline Niki, which is not part of the insolvency proceedings.\n\n\"These are ideas that Lufthansa is bringing into the talks,\" the source said, adding no decisions had been made yet. Another source said the number of aircraft Lufthansa wanted to take was smaller.\n\nAir Berlin has been in preliminary talks with a total of three aviation firms, including Lufthansa, over the sale of its assets, Chief Executive Thomas Winkelmann told Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung (FAZ), and aims to strike deals with at least two of them by the end of September.\n\nEarlier this week a source familiar with the matter said easyJet was among those in talks, and Thomas Cook's German airline Condor said it was ready to play \"an active role\" in Air Berlin's restructuring.\n\nThe airline's demise also offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire coveted runway slots at Air Berlin's hub airports, Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against the incursion of low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nRedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND), a group which represents German newspapers, cited government sources as saying that Lufthansa, its budget carrier Eurowings and Condor would likely snap up Air Berlin's most valuable slots.\n\nRND said a few slots could also go to Ryanair.\n\n($1 = 0.8548 euros)\n\n(Additional reporting by Sabine Wollrab; Editing by Alexander Smith, Greg Mahlich)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your device.", "id": "9742448", Lufthansa declined to comment on the report.\n\nAir Berlin CEO Thomas Winkelmann said earlier that the carrier was in talks with three aviation firms and aimed to strike deals with at least two of them by the end of September.\n\nHe declined to say in an interview with Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung which companies other than Lufthansa were part of the talks, saying only that they were \"sufficiently large to offer Air Berlin a secure future and are interested in keeping Germany as a base of operations\".\n\nRedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND), a group which represents German newspapers, cited government sources as saying that Lufthansa, its budget carrier Eurowings and Condor would likely snap up Air Berlin's most valuable landing slots.\n\nIt said a few slots could also go to Ryanair, which has filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nA source has said easyJet was also part of the negotiations, and Thomas Cook's German airline Condor said it was ready to play \"an active role\" in restructuring.\n\nGerman Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt backed Lufthansa to buy a major portion of Air Berlin's assets, saying the country needed a \"national champion\" in international aviation.\n\n\"That is why it is urgently necessary that Lufthansa {"timeCrawl": "17:07:00", "uri": "711013186", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T17:07:00Z", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "source": {"title": "The Irish Times", "uri": "irishtimes.com", "id": "1154"}, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/business/transport-and-tourism/lufthansa-to-get-first-shot-at-bidding-for-insolvent-air-berlin-1.3189803", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "A first round of formal talks for the sale of insolvent German airline Air Berlin's assets will be held with its bigger local rival Lufthansa on Friday, ahead of other prospective bidders, a senior labour union official said.\n\n\"Only Lufthansa will initially be part of the talks ... As far as I know, the other bidders will be invited for talks afterward and then an overall package will be put together,\" said Lufthansa's deputy chair Christine Behle, who represents labour union Verdi on the company's supervisory board.\n\nShe also said negotiations would begin on Friday and she expected them to continue through the weekend.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.\n\nWith many Germans travelling on their summer holidays and a September general election looming, Berlin has granted a bridging loan of \u20ac150 million to keep Air Berlin's planes in the air for up to three months and secure 7,200 jobs in Germany while buyers for its assets are found.\n\nThat means that the race is on to carve up the airline and obtain anti-trust approval for any deals before Air Berlin runs out of cash.\n\nTransport Minister Alexander Dobrindt has called for Lufthansa to buy a major part of the assets, saying Germany needs a \"national champion\" in international aviation.\n\n\"That is why it is urgently necessary that Lufthansa can take over significant parts of Air Berlin,\" he told daily newspaper Rheinische Post.\n\nHis comments came after rival Ryanair filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the handling of the insolvency process, which its chief executive Michael O'Leary describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nGermany's transport ministry already faces allegations by the European Commission of maintaining a cosy relationship with its domestic industry and questions about whether authorities did enough to uncover an emissions scandal at carmaker Volkswagen, which is partially state-owned.\n\nOne scenario Lufthansa chief executive Carsten Spohr has presented to the flagship carrier's supervisory board is that it could take on as many as 90 of Air Berlin's roughly 140 leased planes, a source said.\n\nThat would include the 38 aircraft that Lufthansa is already leasing from Air Berlin and its leisure airline Niki, which is not part of the insolvency proceedings.\n\n\"These are ideas that Lufthansa is bringing into the talks,\" the source said, adding no decisions had been made yet. Another source said the number of aircraft Lufthansa wanted to take was smaller.\n\nAir Berlin has been in preliminary talks with a total of three aviation firms, including Lufthansa, over the sale of its assets, chief executive Thomas Winkelmann told Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung (FAZ), and aims to strike deals with at least two of them by the end of September.\n\nEarlier this week a source familiar with the matter said Easyjet was among those in talks, and Thomas Cook's German airline Condor said it was ready to play \"an active role\" in Air Berlin's restructuring.\n\nThe airline's demise also offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire coveted runway slots at Air Berlin's hub airports, Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against the incursion of low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nRedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND), a group which represents German newspapers, cited government sources as saying that Lufthansa, its {"timeCrawl": "18:50:00", "uri": "710490619", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:50:00Z", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "source": {"title": "Business Standard", "uri": "business-standard.com", "id": "405"}, "url": "http://www.business-standard.com/article/international/national-disaster-avoided-thanks-to-government-loan-air-berlin-ceo-117081601628_1.html", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "ALSO READ Air Berlin files for insolvency after Etihad withdrawal Lufthansa taking over Air Berlin to halt our expansion: Ryanair CEO Etihad calls off JV to create new leisure airline with TUI in Germany German's Air Berlin grounded for 10 days after rat boards in Florida Foreign creditors will have to wait to stake claims in insolvent companies\n\nInsolvent Air Berlin's chief executive said a national disaster had been avoided thanks to a government loan that keeps its planes in the air, after earlier blaming long delays in the opening of a new Berlin airport for some of its problems.\n\nThe comments came a day after Air Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.\n\nThe German government granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($176 million) to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations continue.\n\n\"The speed with which all parties in the government worked impressed me. We avoided a national disaster,\" German daily Bild quoted CEO Thomas Winkelmann as saying.\n\nStill, the Air Berlin brand is likely to disappear, he said, with the carrier's assets set to be divided up and sold to rivals.\n\nWinkelmann also said Air Berlin's woes were partly down to constant delays to the opening of the capital's new airport, which was meant to open in 2011, replacing Air Berlin's home airport Tegel and Schoenefeld.\n\n\"We have Berlin in our name, are the prime carrier here and have designed our whole concept based on transfer traffic at this new airport. That is not possible at Tegel, my predecessors had that painful experience,\" he said in comments to weekly Die Zeit.\n\nSeveral opening dates for the planned new airport have been postponed as the {"timeCrawl": "07:33:00", "uri": "710742379", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:33:00Z", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4798356/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "FRANKFURT, Aug 17 (Reuters) - Insolvent German airline Air Berlin aims to strike deals to sell assets to two or more buyers by the end of September, before a government loan keeping its planes in the air runs out, its chief executive said.\n\nThe group is in talks with a total of three aviation firms, including Lufthansa, German newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung (FAZ) quoted Thomas Winkelmann as saying in its Thursday edition.\n\nAll three are \"reputable in terms of their finances, sufficiently large to offer Air Berlin a secure future and are interested in keeping Germany as a base of operations\", he said, without naming any of the interested parties.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses, leaving valuable runway slots up for grabs.\n\nThe insolvency comes with thousands of Germans enjoying summer holidays, and just ahead of a September general election.\n\nThe German government granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations go on.\n\nThe move offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against expansion by low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nAccording to Winkelmann, the negotiations also include assets of Air Berlin unit Niki, which Etihad had agreed to buy for 300 million euros ($354 million) earlier this year.\n\nSEIZING OPPORTUNITIES\n\nRedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND), a group which represents German newspapers, cited government sources as saying that Lufthansa, its budget carrier Eurowings and Condor would likely snap up Air Berlin's most valuable landing slots.\n\nIt said a few slots could also go to Ryanair, which has filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nLufthansa has confirmed it is in talks to take over parts of Air Berlin's business, while a source has said easyJet was also part of the negotiations.\n\nThomas Cook's German airline Condor said on Wednesday it was ready to play \"an active role\" in Air Berlin's restructuring, without being more specific.\n\nGermany's Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt said the asset sales were an opportunity for the country's aviation sector to bolster its footprint.\n\n\"The opportunity should be seized to strategically position the 140 aircraft, the capacities and the employees of Air Berlin and strengthen the position of Germany's aviation sector in the international market,\" German daily Bild quoted him as saying. Lufthansa is the sole major player remaining.\n\nGerman magazine Capital earlier reported that Woehrl was thinking of teaming up with other investors to make a takeover offer for Air Berlin, citing people familiar with the matter.\n\n\"INTRO already declared its interest years ago to take a majority stake in the Air Berlin group jointly with additional investors. This interest still exists,\" the spokeswoman said in an emailed statement, adding other investors were involved.\n\n\"We think Air Berlin is meaningful only as a whole, because that is the only way to prevent a monopoly at the expense of passengers in Germany.\"\n\nWoehrl made a name for himself in Germany's aviation world when he bought German airline Deutsche BA from British Airways -- now part of IAG - for 1 euro ($1.17) in 2003.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.\n\nThe German government has granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations continue.\n\n\"No offer has been submitted so far because there are concerns that the loan by the government is meant to deliberately promote a monopoly structure that seeks to block offers from investors right from the start,\" the INTRO spokeswoman said.\n\nAir Berlin has been in preliminary talks with a total of three aviation firms, including Lufthansa, over the sale of its assets, Chief Executive Thomas Winkelmann told a newspaper.\n\nA source has said easyJet was also part of the negotiations, while Thomas Cook's German airline Condor said it was ready to play \"an active role\" in Air Berlin's restructuring, without being more specific. {"timeCrawl": "10:25:00", "uri": "710250734", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T13:49:00Z", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "source": {"title": "khaleejtimes.com", "uri": "khaleejtimes.com", "id": "17167"}, "url": "http://www.khaleejtimes.com/business/aviation/etihad-terms-air-berlins-insolvency-move-extremely-disappointing", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "In April this year, Etihad provided 250 million euros in additional funds to the airline, as well as offer support for the airline to \"explore strategic options\" for the business.\n\nAir Berlin's Tuesday filing for insolvency is \"extremely disappointing\", Etihad Airways said in a statement.\n\nOn Tuesday, discount carrier Air Berlin filed for insolvency in a local Berlin court.\n\n\"We have been informed that Air Berlin has filed for administration,\" Etihad said in a statement. \"This development is extremely disappointing for all parties, especially as Etihad has provided extensive support to Air Berlin for its previous liquidity challenges and restructuring efforts over the past six years.\"\n\nIn April this year, Etihad provided 250 million euros in additional funds to the airline, as well as offer support for the airline to \"explore strategic options\" for the business.\n\n\"However, Air Berlin's business has deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions,\" Etihad added.\n\n\"Under these circumstances, as a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties.\"\n\nEtihad noted that Air Berlin operations are expected to continue during administration, and that the Abu Dhabi-based carrier has a commercial relationship with Air Berlin across a number of areas, including codeshare operations.\n\n\"We will support Air Berlin's management during these difficult times,\" the statement added. \"Germany is an important market for Etihad and Abu Dhabi, and we remain committed to providing comprehensive air links as a key enabler of trade and tourism.\"\n\nSaj Ahmad, an analyst with the London-based StrategicAero Research, said that Air Berlin's collapse \"underscores the immense difficulties and challenges that Etihad endured in trying to get the airline to restructure, change and become a viable competitor to Lufthansa\".\n\nAhmad added that it appears that Etihad is \"re-evaluating its position and is probably better off concentrating on its own organic expansion, as opposed to being side-tracked by equity stakes that have not delivered the rewards that had been envisioned\".\n\n\"With that in mind, the new leadership at Etihad, in my mind, has to wipe the slate clean from this sort of troublesome exposure and get back to showcasing Etihad's premium offerings, which are undeniably beyond the rest of it's rivals,\" he added. \"It's a bad day in the Etihad office, that's for sure, but now Etihad is arguably free from Air Berlin, it can get back to business as it looks to turn around its losses.\"\n\nbusiness@khaleejtimes.com", "id": {"timeCrawl": "12:11:00", "uri": "710866047", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:11:00Z", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/lufthansa-in-talks-to-buy-most-of-air-berlin-planes-media/articleshow/60103691.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "By Maria Sheahan\n\nFRANKFURT (Reuters) - Germany's Lufthansa is in talks to buy a majority of insolvent Air Berlin's aircraft, with the backing of Berlin, which is pushing for a national aviation champion, media reports said on Thursday.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.\n\nThe insolvency comes as many Germans enjoy summer holidays, and just ahead of a September general election, both factors which have put pressure on the German government to help minimise travel disruptions and job losses.\n\nBerlin granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($175.5 million) to allow the airline to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while buyers for its assets are found.\n\nAir Berlin's demise offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against expansion by low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nThe Sueddeutsche Zeitung newspaper cited company sources as saying that Lufthansa wants to take on as many as 90 of Air Berlin's roughly 140 planes, including the 38 aircraft that it is already leasing from Germany's second-biggest carrier and all of the planes in its Niki division.\n\nLufthansa Chief Executive Carsten Spohr is due to hold talks with Air Berlin's administrator and its management on Friday, the newspaper said. Lufthansa declined to comment on the report.\n\nAir Berlin CEO Thomas Winkelmann said earlier that the carrier was in talks with three aviation firms and aimed to strike deals with at least two of them by the end of September.\n\nHe declined to say in an interview with Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung which companies other than Lufthansa were part of the talks, saying only that they were \"sufficiently large to offer Air Berlin a secure future and are interested in keeping Germany as a base of operations\".\n\nSAFE LANDINGS\n\nRedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND), a group which represents German newspapers, cited government sources as saying that Lufthansa, its budget carrier Eurowings and Condor would likely snap up Air Berlin's most valuable landing slots.\n\nIt said a few slots could also go to Ryanair, which has filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nA source has said easyJet was also part of the negotiations, and Thomas Cook's German airline Condor said it was ready to play \"an active role\" in restructuring.\n\nGerman Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt backed Lufthansa to buy a major portion of Air Berlin's assets, saying the country needed a \"national champion\" in international aviation.\n\n\"That is why it is urgently necessary that Lufthansa can take over significant parts of Air Berlin,\" he told daily Rheinische Post.\n\n($1 = 0.8548 euros)\n\n(Additional reporting by Sabine Wollrab; editing by Robert Birsel and Alexander Smith)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your device.", "id": "9682453", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "17:17:00", "uri": "711017613", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T17:17:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/germanys-lufthansa-gets-first-say-on-air-berlin-asset-sale-union/articleshow/60107681.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "* First round of talks only with Lufthansa - deputy chair\n\n* Other bidders to be invited afterward - deputy chair\n\n* Lufthansa considers taking up to 90 aircraft - source\n\n* Air Berlin aims for deal with at least two buyers\n\n* Transport minister wants most assets to go to Lufthansa (Releads on first formal talks)\n\nBy Victoria Bryan and Maria Sheahan\n\nBERLIN/FRANKFURT, Aug 17 (Reuters) - A first round of formal talks for the sale of insolvent German airline Air Berlin's assets will be held with its bigger local rival Lufthansa on Friday, ahead of other prospective bidders, a senior labour union official said.\n\n\"Only Lufthansa will initially be part of the talks ... As far as I know, the other bidders will be invited for talks afterward and then an overall package will be put together,\" said Lufthansa's deputy chair Christine Behle, who represents labour union Verdi on the company's supervisory board.\n\nShe also told Reuters negotiations would begin on Friday and she expected them to continue through the weekend.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.\n\nWith many Germans travelling on their summer holidays and a September general election looming, Berlin has granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($176 million) to keep Air Berlin's planes in the air for up to three months and secure 7,200 jobs in Germany while buyers for its assets are found.\n\nThat means that the race is on to carve up the airline and obtain anti-trust approval for any deals before Air Berlin runs out of cash.\n\nTransport Minister Alexander Dobrindt has called for Lufthansa to buy a major part of the assets, saying Germany needs a \"national champion\" in international aviation.\n\n\"That is why it is urgently necessary that Lufthansa can take over significant parts of Air Berlin,\" he told daily newspaper Rheinische Post.\n\nHis comments came after rival European airline Ryanair filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the handling of the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nGermany's transport ministry already faces allegations by the European Commission of maintaining a cosy relationship with its domestic industry and questions about whether authorities did enough to uncover an emissions scandal at carmaker Volkswagen, which is partially state-owned.\n\nAIRCRAFT DEAL\n\nOne scenario Lufthansa Chief Executive Carsten Spohr has presented to the flagship carrier's supervisory board is that it could take on as many as 90 of Air Berlin's roughly 140 leased planes, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters.\n\nThat would include the 38 aircraft that Lufthansa is already leasing from Air Berlin and its leisure airline Niki, which is not part of the insolvency proceedings.\n\n\"These are ideas that Lufthansa is bringing into the talks,\" the source said, adding no decisions had been made yet. Another source said the number of aircraft Lufthansa wanted to take was smaller.\n\nAir Berlin has been in preliminary talks with a total of three aviation firms, including Lufthansa, over the sale of its assets, Chief Executive Thomas Winkelmann told Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung (FAZ), and aims to strike deals with at least two of them by the end of September.\n\nEarlier this week a source familiar with the matter said easyJet was among those in talks, and Thomas Cook's German airline Condor said it was ready to play \"an active role\" in Air Berlin's restructuring.\n\nThe airline's demise also offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire coveted runway slots at Air Berlin's hub airports, Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against the incursion of low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nRedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND), a group which represents German newspapers, cited government sources as saying that Lufthansa, its budget carrier Eurowings and Condor would likely snap up Air Berlin's most valuable slots.\n\nRND said a few slots could also go to Ryanair.\n\n($1 = 0.8548 euros) (Additional reporting by Sabine {"timeCrawl": "21:02:00", "uri": "710542401", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T21:02:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"title": "The Irish Times", "uri": "irishtimes.com", "id": "1154"}, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/business/transport-and-tourism/germans-dismiss-ryanair-claim-over-air-berlin-as-absurd-1.3188495", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Berlin has dismissed as \"absurd\" Ryanair claims that its \u20ac150 million bridging loan to the insolvent Air Berlin is a \"conspiracy\" to distort the market and handicap the Irish budget airline in Germany.\n\nChancellor Angela Merkel said the chances were \"relatively small\" that the loan - to keep Air Berlin flying until the company is broken up - would not be repaid.\n\n\"Otherwise we wouldn't have been allowed give this bridging loan,\" she said, adding it was \"very, very likely that the taxpayer will not have to pay\".\n\nWithout the loan, she said, the airline could not have paid for fuel, and tickets would have been void.\n\nRyanair has filed a complaint with European Commission and German cartel authorities over the loan, saying it is an illegal move to carve up Air Berlin's assets and allow Lufthansa take over the company, minus its debts.\n\nOn Wednesday, German officials said they were confident the loan was not illegal state aid as it was of a fixed duration to ensure hundreds of thousands of Air Berlin passengers would not be stranded on holidays abroad.\n\n\"We checked and there was no capacity to get these people back home,\" said Matthias Machnig, state secretary in Germany's economics ministry.\n\nThe ailing Air Berlin is already in advanced talks with German flag-carrier Lufthansa for it to take over parts of the airline, possibly to merge it with its own Eurowings subsidiary. Meanwhile, \"another airline\" - rumoured to be Easyjet or Condor - is likely to swallow the rest.\n\n\"The [airport] slots in Germany, that is the actual value of Air Berlin,\" said Mr Machnig, \"and many will endeavour to secure them to have a certain position in the German market\".\n\nAir Berlin employs 7,200 people and among its few remaining assets are its slots in major German airports, including Munich, Frankfurt, D\u00fcsseldorf and Berlin.\n\nAccording to the federal transport ministry, the takeover will be concluded next week. Until then the day-to-day costs of the airline will be financed by the loan from the state-owned KfW bank, backed by a state guarantee.\n\nThe Irish airline said it doubted Germany's cartel authority would stop the deal, making it \"all the more important\" that Brussels take \"immediate and decisive action\".\n\nThe European Commission confirmed it was studying the loan.\n\nThe airline's chief executive Thomas Winkelmann said Air Berlin was a \"victim of constant postponements\" of Berlin's new airport, now six years behind schedule and still not open.\n\nBut critics blame a revolving door of managers and their competing, contradictory strategies for crashing the airline.\n\nThe final blow came when major shareholder Etihad from Abu Dhabi refused to extend the loss-making airline any further credit.\n\nHeinrich Grossbongardt, a German aviation analyst, named Lufthansa the big winner of Air Berlin's collapse, Easyjet a possible runner-up and Ryanair the big loser.\n\n\"And it's a bad loser,\" he said. \"When airlines collapsed elsewhere it moved in quickly and aggressively with its own capacity, but the slots aren't free this time.\"", "id": "9564018", "details": {}, "date":
