{"timeCrawl": "20:21:00", "uri": "711098362", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:21:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/airline-investor-woehrl-interested-in-air-berlin/articleshow/60110871.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "FRANKFURT, Aug 17 (Reuters) - Airline entrepreneur Hans Rudolf Woehrl is interested in insolvent Air Berlin, a spokeswoman for his company INTRO-Verwaltungs GmbH told Reuters, responding to a media report saying he was planning a bid.\n\nShe said it was the only way to avoid creating a German monopoly. Lufthansa is the sole major player remaining.\n\nGerman magazine Capital earlier reported that Woehrl was thinking of teaming up with other investors to make a takeover offer for Air Berlin, citing people familiar with the matter.\n\n\"INTRO already declared its interest years ago to take a majority stake in the Air Berlin group jointly with additional investors. This interest still exists,\" the spokeswoman said in an emailed statement, adding other investors were involved.\n\n\"We think Air Berlin is meaningful only as a whole, because that is the only way to prevent a monopoly at the expense of passengers in Germany.\"\n\nWoehrl made a name for himself in Germany's aviation world when he bought German airline Deutsche BA from British Airways -- now part of IAG - for 1 euro ($1.17) in 2003.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.\n\nThe German government has granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations continue.\n\n\"No offer has been submitted so far because there are concerns that the loan by the government is meant to deliberately promote a monopoly structure that seeks to block offers from investors right from the start,\" the INTRO spokeswoman said.\n\nAir Berlin has been in preliminary talks with a total of three aviation firms, including Lufthansa, over the sale of its assets, Chief Executive Thomas Winkelmann told a newspaper.\n\nA source has said easyJet was also part of the negotiations, while Thomas Cook's German airline Condor said it was ready to play \"an active role\" in Air Berlin's restructuring, without being more specific. {"timeCrawl": "12:05:00", "uri": "710864119", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:05:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"title": "Sify", "uri": "sify.com", "id": "186"}, "url": "http://www.sify.com/finance/lufthansa-in-talks-to-buy-most-of-air-berlin-planes---media-news-debt-rirrxcafedjej.html", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "By Maria Sheahan\n\nFRANKFURT (Reuters) - Germany's Lufthansa is in talks to buy a majority of insolvent Air Berlin's aircraft, with the backing of Berlin, which is pushing for a national aviation champion, media reports said on Thursday.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.\n\nThe insolvency comes as many Germans enjoy summer holidays, and just ahead of a September general election, both factors which have put pressure on the German government to help minimise travel disruptions and job losses.\n\nBerlin granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($175.5 million) to allow the airline to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while buyers for its assets are found.\n\nAir Berlin's demise offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against expansion by low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nThe Sueddeutsche Zeitung newspaper cited company sources as saying that Lufthansa wants to take on as many as 90 of Air Berlin's roughly 140 planes, including the 38 aircraft that it is already leasing from Germany's second-biggest carrier and all of the planes in its Niki division.\n\nLufthansa Chief Executive Carsten Spohr is due to hold talks with Air Berlin's administrator and its management on Friday, the newspaper said. Lufthansa declined to comment on the report.\n\nAir Berlin CEO Thomas Winkelmann said earlier that the carrier was in talks with three aviation firms and aimed to strike deals with at least two of them by the end of September.\n\nHe declined to say in an interview with Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung which companies other than Lufthansa were part of the talks, saying only that they were \"sufficiently large to offer Air Berlin a secure future and are interested in keeping Germany as a base of operations\".\n\nSAFE LANDINGS\n\nRedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND), a group which represents German newspapers, cited government sources as saying that Lufthansa, its budget carrier Eurowings and Condor would likely snap up Air Berlin's most valuable landing slots.\n\nIt said a few slots could also go to Ryanair, which has filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nA source has said easyJet was also part of the negotiations, and Thomas Cook's German airline Condor said it was ready to play \"an active role\" in restructuring.\n\nGerman Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt backed Lufthansa to buy a major portion of Air Berlin's assets, saying the country needed a \"national champion\" in international aviation.\n\n\"That is why it is urgently necessary that Lufthansa can take over significant parts of Air Berlin,\" he told daily Rheinische Post.\n\n($1 = 0.8548 euros)\n\n(Additional reporting by Sabine Wollrab; editing by {"timeCrawl": "16:37:00", "uri": "710999707", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T16:37:00Z", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "source": {"title": "Yahoo Finance", "uri": "finance.yahoo.com", "id": "5636"}, "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/lufthansa-talks-buy-most-air-130442396.html", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "By Victoria Bryan and Maria Sheahan\n\nBERLIN/FRANKFURT (Reuters) - A first round of formal talks for the sale of insolvent German airline Air Berlin's (AB1.DE) assets will be held with its bigger local rival Lufthansa (LHAG.DE) on Friday, ahead of other prospective bidders, a senior labour union official said.\n\n\"Only Lufthansa will initially be part of the talks ... As far as I know, the other bidders will be invited for talks afterward and then an overall package will be put together,\" said Lufthansa's deputy chair Christine Behle, who represents labour union Verdi on the company's supervisory board.\n\nShe also told Reuters negotiations would begin on Friday and she expected them to continue through the weekend.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.\n\nWith many Germans travelling on their summer holidays and a September general election looming, Berlin has granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($176 million) to keep Air Berlin's planes in the air for up to three months and secure 7,200 jobs in Germany while buyers for its assets are found.\n\nThat means that the race is on to carve up the airline and obtain anti-trust approval for any deals before Air Berlin runs out of cash.\n\nTransport Minister Alexander Dobrindt has called for Lufthansa to buy a major part of the assets, saying Germany needs a \"national champion\" in international aviation.\n\n\"That is why it is urgently necessary that Lufthansa can take over significant parts of Air Berlin,\" he told daily newspaper Rheinische Post.\n\nHis comments came after rival European airline Ryanair (RYA.I) filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the handling of the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nGermany's transport ministry already faces allegations by the European Commission of maintaining a cosy relationship with its domestic industry and questions about whether authorities did enough to uncover an emissions scandal at carmaker Volkswagen (VOWG_p.DE), which is partially state-owned.\n\nAIRCRAFT DEAL\n\nOne scenario Lufthansa Chief Executive Carsten Spohr has presented to the flagship carrier's supervisory board is that it could take on as many as 90 of Air Berlin's roughly 140 leased planes, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters.\n\nThat would include the 38 aircraft that Lufthansa is already leasing from Air Berlin and its leisure airline Niki, which is not part of the insolvency proceedings.\n\n\"These are ideas that Lufthansa is bringing into the talks,\" the source said, adding no decisions had been made yet. Another source said the number of aircraft Lufthansa wanted to take was smaller.\n\nAir Berlin has been in preliminary talks with a total of three aviation firms, including Lufthansa, over the sale of its assets, Chief Executive Thomas Winkelmann told Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung (FAZ), and aims to strike deals with at least two of them by the end of September.\n\nEarlier this week a source familiar with the matter said easyJet (EZJ.L) was among those in talks, and Thomas Cook's (TCG.L) German airline Condor said it was ready to play \"an active role\" in Air Berlin's restructuring.\n\nThe airline's demise also offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire coveted runway slots at Air Berlin's hub airports, Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against the incursion of low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nRedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND), a group which represents German newspapers, cited government sources as saying that Lufthansa, its budget carrier Eurowings and Condor would likely snap up Air Berlin's most valuable slots.\n\nRND said a few slots could also go to Ryanair.\n\n($1 = 0.8548 euros)\n\n(Additional reporting by Sabine Wollrab; Editing by Alexander Smith, Greg Mahlich)", "id": "9735029", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Germany's Lufthansa gets first say on Air them by the end of September.\n\nHe declined to say in an interview with Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung which companies other than Lufthansa were part of the talks, saying only that they were The loan will also help secure the jobs of the company's 7,200 employees.\n\nRead: UAE email leaks reveal Emirati ambitions\n\nAir Berlin has long battled for survival, booking losses amounting to \u20ac1.2 billion over the past two years and relying on cash infusions from Etihad.\n\nEtihad, which holds a 30 per cent stake in Air Berlin, said that the carrier's business \"deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\nThe Emirati national carrier noted that the announcement of bankruptcy was \"extremely disappointing for all parties\", especially after the six years of financial support it had provided to the airline, stressing that it could not continue pumping money into a \"loss-making business\".\n\n\"As a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. prompting the German government via its state development bank to keep it afloat via a \u20ac150m bridging loan.\n\n\"All this is down to prevent Ryanair growing in Germany, but it won't stop us,\" Mr O'Leary said yesterday.\n\n\"A merger will take Lufthansa from 68% to 95% of the German domestic market and from 47% to 60% control of the total German market, which would be in breach of every known competition threshold rule and guideline in Germany and the EU,\" he said.\n\nRyanair has an 8% share of the German market and wants to reach around 20% in the medium term.\n\nRegarding the potential for Ryanair to bid for assets held by Air Berlin, Mr O'Leary said he expected a deal would go through too quickly to give it a chance to bid and that only unattractive airport slots would be offered up.\n\nMr O'Leary said he hoped the EU authorities would step in to force competition remedies, such as giving up airport slots to rivals.\n\nThe German government has rejected any conspiracy claims, saying it expects no competition issues as Air Berlin will be sold off in parts. It has also said it is unlikely the German state will have to foot the bill for any Air Berlin rescue.\n\n\"We can say that in all likelihood the taxpayer will not have to pay for that,\" chancellor Angela Merkel said.\n\nMeanwhile, Air Berlin has blamed long delays in the opening of a new airport in the German capital for its insolvency.\n\nBerlin's new airport was meant to open in 2011, replacing Air Berlin's home airport Tegel and Schoenefeld. {"timeCrawl": "07:57:00", "uri": "710752909", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:57:00Z", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/air-berlin-aims-for-asset-sales-to-at-least-two-buyers-by-end-sept-ceo/articleshow/60099782.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "* Air Berlin CEO says in talks with three aviation firms\n\n* Aims for deal with at least two buyers by end-September\n\n* Lufthansa, Eurowings, Condor to get best slots - RND\n\n* Transport minister sees opportunity for German firms (Recasts, adds German transport minister comment, details on slot auction)\n\nFRANKFURT, Aug 17 (Reuters) - Insolvent German airline Air Berlin aims to strike deals to sell assets to two or more buyers by the end of September, before a government loan keeping its planes in the air runs out, its chief executive said.\n\nThe group is in talks with a total of three aviation firms, including Lufthansa, German newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung (FAZ) quoted Thomas Winkelmann as saying in its Thursday edition.\n\nAll three are \"reputable in terms of their finances, sufficiently large to offer Air Berlin a secure future and are interested in keeping Germany as a base of operations\", he said, without naming any of the interested parties.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses, leaving valuable runway slots up for grabs.\n\nThe insolvency comes with thousands of Germans enjoying summer holidays, and just ahead of a September general election.\n\nThe German government granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations go on.\n\nThe move offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against expansion by low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nAccording to Winkelmann, the negotiations also include assets of Air Berlin unit Niki, which Etihad had agreed to buy for 300 million euros ($354 million) earlier this year.\n\nSEIZING OPPORTUNITIES\n\nRedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND), a group which represents German newspapers, cited government sources as saying that Lufthansa, its budget carrier Eurowings and Condor would likely snap up Air Berlin's most valuable landing slots.\n\nIt said a few slots could also go to Ryanair, which has filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nLufthansa has confirmed it is in talks to take over parts of Air Berlin's business, while a source has said easyJet was also part of the negotiations.\n\nThomas Cook's German airline Condor said on Wednesday it was ready to play \"an active role\" in Air Berlin's restructuring, without being more specific.\n\nGermany's Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt said the asset sales were an opportunity for the country's aviation sector to bolster its footprint.\n\n\"The opportunity should be seized to strategically position the 140 aircraft, the capacities and the employees of Air Berlin and strengthen the position of Germany's aviation sector in the international market,\" German daily Bild quoted him as saying. {"timeCrawl": "12:11:00", "uri": "710866046", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:11:00Z", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/lufthansa-in-talks-to-buy-most-of-air-berlin-planes-media/articleshow/60103692.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "* Lufthansa wants 90 Air Berlin aircraft - Sueddeutsche\n\n* Talks with Lufthansa CEO due on Friday - Sueddeutsche\n\n* Air Berlin aims for deal with at least two buyers\n\n* Transport minister wants most assets to go to Lufthansa (Recasts, adds details of Sueddeutsche Zeitung report, transport minister comment)\n\nBy Maria Sheahan\n\nFRANKFURT, Aug 17 (Reuters) - Germany's Lufthansa is in talks to buy a majority of insolvent Air Berlin's aircraft, with the backing of Berlin, which is pushing for a national aviation champion, media reports said on Thursday.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.\n\nThe insolvency comes as many Germans enjoy summer holidays, and just ahead of a September general election, both factors which have put pressure on the German government to help minimise travel disruptions and job losses.\n\nBerlin granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($175.5 million) to allow the airline to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while buyers for its assets are found.\n\nAir Berlin's demise offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against expansion by low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nThe Sueddeutsche Zeitung newspaper cited company sources as saying that Lufthansa wants to take on as many as 90 of Air Berlin's roughly 140 planes, including the 38 aircraft that it is already leasing from Germany's second-biggest carrier and all of the planes in its Niki division.\n\nLufthansa Chief Executive Carsten Spohr is due to hold talks with Air Berlin's administrator and its management on Friday, the newspaper said. Lufthansa declined to comment on the report.\n\nAir Berlin CEO Thomas Winkelmann said earlier that the carrier was in talks with three aviation firms and aimed to strike deals with at least two of them by the end of September.\n\nHe declined to say in an interview with Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung which companies other than Lufthansa were part of the talks, saying only that they were \"sufficiently large to offer Air Berlin a secure future and are interested in keeping Germany as a base of operations\".\n\nSAFE LANDINGS\n\nRedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND), a group which represents German newspapers, cited government sources as saying that Lufthansa, its budget carrier Eurowings and Condor would likely snap up Air Berlin's most valuable landing slots.\n\nIt said a few slots could also go to Ryanair, which has filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nA source has said easyJet was also part of the negotiations, and Thomas Cook's German airline Condor said it was ready to play \"an active role\" in restructuring.\n\nGerman Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt backed Lufthansa to buy a major portion of Air Berlin's assets, saying the country needed a \"national champion\" in international aviation.\n\n\"That is why it is urgently necessary that Lufthansa can take over significant parts of Air Berlin,\" he told daily Rheinische Post. losses.\n\nThe insolvency comes as many Germans enjoy summer holidays, and just ahead of a September general election, both factors which have put pressure on the German government to help minimize travel disruptions and job losses.\n\nTransport Minister Alexander Dobrindt backed Lufthansa to buy a major portion of Air Berlin's assets, saying Germany needed a \"national champion\" in That should also allow all 7,200 employees to keep their jobs while executives try to restructure or sell the company.\n\n\"Air Berlin's business has deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions,\" Etihad said in a statement.\n\n\"Under these circumstances, as a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure.\"\n\nAir Berlin has struggled for years to turn a profit despite serving more than 2 million passengers a month.\n\nRelated: Etihad CEO steps down amid strategic rethink\n\nThe failure of Air Berlin is a major setback for Etihad, which has invested just over \u20ac1.8 billion ($2.2 billion) in the carrier since 2011, according to an Etihad source who asked to remain anonymous.\n\nEtihad's once novel strategy of investing in other airlines has weighed heavily on the company's bottom line. "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Germany's Lufthansa is considering buying a majority of insolvent Air Berlin's aircraft, two people familiar with the matter said, as the government and rivals race to carve it up.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.\n\nThe insolvency comes as many Germans enjoy summer holidays, and just ahead of a September general election, both factors which have put pressure on the German government to help minimise travel disruptions and job losses.\n\nTransport Minister Alexander Dobrindt backed Lufthansa to buy a major portion of Air Berlin's assets, saying Germany needed a \"national champion\" in international aviation.\n\n\"That is why it is urgently necessary that Lufthansa can take over significant parts of Air Berlin,\" he told daily newspaper Rheinische Post.\n\nBerlin has granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($176 million) that will keep Air Berlin's planes in the air for up to three months, bringing holidaymakers home and securing 7,200 jobs in Germany while buyers for its assets are found.\n\nAir Berlin's demise offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nOne scenario Lufthansa's Chief Executive Carsten Spohr has presented to the flagship carrier's supervisory board is that it could take on as many as 90 of Air Berlin's roughly 140 planes, all of which are leased, one of the people said on Thursday.\n\nThat would include the 38 aircraft that Lufthansa is already leasing from Air Berlin and its Niki division.\n\n\"These are ideas that Lufthansa is bringing into the talks,\" the source said, adding that no decisions had been made yet and that it was ultimately up to Air Berlin's administrator.\n\nThe other source said the number of aircraft that Lufthansa could take on was lower than 90.\n\nThe Sueddeutsche Zeitung newspaper earlier cited company sources as saying that Lufthansa CEO Spohr was due to hold talks with Air Berlin's administrator and its management on Friday. Lufthansa declined to comment on the matter.\n\nAir Berlin itself has said it is in talks with three aviation firms and aims to strike deals with at least two of them by the end of September.\n\nRedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND), a group which represents German newspapers, cited government sources as saying that Lufthansa, its budget carrier Eurowings and Thomas Cook's German airline Condor would likely snap up Air Berlin's most valuable landing slots.\n\nA source has said easyJet was also part of the negotiations.\n\nRND said a few slots could also go to Ryanair, which has filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nGermany faces allegations by the European Commission of maintaining a cosy relationship with its domestic industry and questions about whether authorities did enough to uncover an emissions scandal at carmaker Volkswagen, which is "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Home and Garden/Climate Control", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Home_and_Garden/Climate_Control"}], "time": "13:46:00"}
{"timeCrawl": "18:04:00", "uri": "710472493", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:04:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"title": "Yahoo Finance", "uri": "finance.yahoo.com", "id": "5636"}, "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/one-american-delta-uniteds-most-143815050.html", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "(An Etihad Airbus A380.Etihad)\n\nEtihad Aviation Group holds equity stakes in seven airlines. Two of them, Air Berlin and Alitalia, are now bankrupt.The CEO behind the strategy has left Etihad.But some investments have paid off.\n\nEtihad's grand plan for global domination looks to be in deep trouble.\n\nIn July, the Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates-based aviation giant announced a staggering $1.87 billion loss for 2016. This after posting a $103 million profit the previous year.\n\nEtihad blames $808 million of losses on financial exposure to partner airlines such as Air Berlin and Alitalia.\n\nNow things have gone from bad to worse.\n\nOn Tuesday, Air Berlin entered into administration, declaring itself insolvent and initiating a major restructuring. Air Berlin's financial implosion happened just three months after Alitalia's bankruptcy in May.\n\nTogether, Etihad's total financial exposure to the two troubled European carriers edges north of $4.5 billion.\n\n\"Etihad had a very ambitious and creative but very risky strategy, which was to invest in airlines in different countries to gain a proxy presence as an airline group, and two of its riskiest investments were Air Berlin and Alitalia,\" Henry Harteveldt, a travel analyst for Atmosphere Research Group, told Business Insider.\n\nIn July, the chief architect of the plan, former Etihad CEO James Hogan, exited the company he helped build.\n\n\"This development is extremely disappointing for all parties, especially as Etihad has provided extensive support to Air Berlin for its previous liquidity challenges and restructuring efforts over the past six years,\" Etihad said in a statement. \"However, Air Berlin's business has deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\nThe company declined to comment further on what effect Air Berlin's and Alitalia's financial troubles will have on Etihad Aviation Group.\n\n(REUTERS/Fabian Bimmer)\n\nGoing global\n\nOver the past few years, Etihad embarked on an equity-acquisition spree that has seen the carrier take substantial ownership stakes in a series of \"partner airlines.\" This includes 49% of Alitalia; 29.2% of Air Berlin; 49% of Air Serbia; 24% of Jet Airways; 21.8% of Virgin Australia; 40% of Air Seychelles; 49.8% of Niki; and 33% of Swiss-based Etihad Regional. But Etihad sold its stake in Etihad Regional in July.\n\nLast September, these partner airlines along with Etihad Airways and its accompanying subsidiaries were reconfigured to form Etihad Aviation Group.\n\nIn theory, Hogan's partnership concept makes a tremendous amount of sense. Investing in or taking over struggling airlines in advantageous markets for pennies on the dollar while simultaneously growing Etihad's global reach is strategically sound. The approach also allows Etihad to enter potentially hostile markets free of political opposition and without the need to launch an operation from scratch.\n\nIn practice, the partnership strategy is much more complex. Some have worked out well for Etihad. For instance, Air Serbia has relaunched and become a solid feeder into the Etihad network. The investment in Jet Airways has helped Etihad unlock the potentially lucrative Indian market. And Virgin Australia has become a viable competitor for Qantas.\n\n(An Air Serbia Airbus A330.AP)\n\nAt the same time, Germany's Air Berlin and Italy's national carrier, Alitalia, have not fared so well. Both airlines were acquired to help Etihad increase its reach into the prized European and transatlantic markets, and to a certain extent, they have done exactly that. Operationally, though, Air Berlin and Alitalia have continued to bleed money.\n\nRead More\n\nOn the face of it, the $2.35 billion Alitalia investment seemed like a solid deal. For the cost of a few Airbus A380 superjumbos, the company acquired a major airline with a fleet of 100 planes, Hogan told Business Insider in 2015.\n\nThe same goes for the Air Berlin deal.\n\n\"Air Berlin, on paper, looked like it would be very beneficial for Etihad,\" Harteveldt said. \"It gave Etihad access to a major European market that's arguably the strongest in terms of economic strength and demand for air travel.\"\n\nSo what happened?\n\n\"These two investments have turned out to be sort of Etihad biting off more than it can chew,\" Airways senior business analyst Vinay Bhaskara told Business Insider.\n\nWhat went wrong\n\nAccording to Bhaskara, there are two types of reclamation projects that tend to succeed in the airline industry. The first is an airline that is underperforming simply because it is \"making boneheaded strategic errors\" to the point the airline is essentially its own worst enemy. These are easier to fix because they tend to be in good markets with good fundamentals. So a management change should do the trick, Bhaskara said. Jet Airways falls into this category.\n\n(AP)\n\nThe second is an underperforming airline that is government-owned or struggling with an incredible amount of internal dysfunction. These turnarounds can be successful if an outside force such as Etihad is \"handed the keys to the kingdom\" to tear down and rebuild the airline after making wholesale changes. This is exactly what Etihad was able to do at Air Serbia, Bhaskara added.\n\nTechnically, Air Berlin and Alitalia should have gone into this second category. But Etihad was never given the chance to implement the same type of full rebuild as Air Serbia.\n\nWith Alitalia, Etihad brought in new management, revamped its product, and improved its service. Many of the old problems that plagued the \"Old Alitalia,\" however, still plague the \"New Alitalia\" today. Bhaskara said one of the major issues the airline ran into was the powerful labor unions that prevented Etihad from making drastic changes that could have made the airline profitable.\n\nIn April, Alitalia entered into administration after workers rejected a management-restructuring plan that would have cut salaries and jobs at the airline.\n\nAccording to the Financial Times, the last time Alitalia generated an annual profit was in 2002 -- one year before the founding of Etihad Airways.\n\n(An Air Berlin Airbus A330.Andreas Wiese / airberlin)\n\nAir Berlin's situation is different than Alitalia's but equally dysfunctional.\n\nAir Berlin's downfall\n\nAccording to Harteveldt, Air Berlin faced myriad issues ranging from a delayed airport to a disjointed product strategy. First, the airport. Even though Berlin is one of the largest and most important cities in Europe, it doesn't actually have a world-class airport. The state-of-the-art Berlin Brandenburg Airport was scheduled to open in 2010. But delays have now pushed to as late as 2020.\n\nAs a result, Air Berlin hasn't been able to develop the mega hub it had hoped for in its hometown. Instead, it has to settle for a smaller hub, in Dusseldorf. But that pales in comparison to the hubs Lufthansa has in larger markets like Frankfurt and Munich, Harteveldt told us.\n\nAt the same time, Air Berlin has been facing stiff competition from low-cost carriers like RyanAir, EasyJet, WizzAir, and other carriers. And then there was the airlines own \"basket case\" business strategy.\n\n\"Air Berlin just didn't have a clear strategy,\" Harteveldt said. \"It was a low-cost, bare-bones airline for its short-haul European flights, but it tried to be a traditional full-service airline on its long-haul flights. It didn't accomplish either objective very well.\"\n\n(Airbus/Etihad)\n\nEven though the labor situation at Air Berlin was less contentious than Alitalia, it still plagued the airline.\n\n\"In Europe, airlines are high-profile industries that are highly unionized, and the unions work very hard to protect their workers' jobs,\" Harteveldt said. \"Compared to the United States, for example, it very difficult for an airline in Europe to gain the labor efficiency that it needs, whether that be wages or productivity or anything else.\"\n\nSo where does that leave Air Berlin?\n\nWhat's next for Etihad's partners\n\nWhile Etihad is willing to explore commercial opportunities with the airline, it has made it clear that after $2.3 billion in investment its coffers are now off limits to Air Berlin.\n\n\"You can hear the sound of Etihad wiping its hands of Air Berlin all the way from Abu Dhabi to California,\" Harteveldt said.\n\nAlthough Harteveldt believes the Alitalia will likely fly on, the analyst thinks Air Berlin is effectively done as an airline. But Bhaskara believes it's still too early to say whether Air Berlin's fate is sealed.\n\n(An Alitalia crew member walks past Alitalia employees who take part in a strike at Fiumicino international airport in Rome.Thomson Reuters)\n\nAir Berlin CEO Thomas Winkelmann has spoken out publicly to reassure his customers that the airline's flights will operate as usual with the help of a bridging loan worth $176 million.\n\nAll is not lost for the Etihad partner airline strategy.\n\n\"In some cases, it looks like Etihad bet on some winning horses,\" Harteveldt said. \"Alitalia is still on the track and so we can't call that race yet.\"\n\nWhile it seems as if the Etihad partnership strategy will probably live on to fight another day, Air Berlin and Alitalia have proved to be two painful and expensive speed bumps along the way.\n\nNOW WATCH: This $41K plane ticket comes with a shower, bed, and butler service\n\nMore From Business Insider\n\nGermany's second largest airline is in grave danger of going bust\n\nThe original Tesla Model S rival has returned, and it's as stunning as ever\n\nThe company that invented Post-It notes is hiding invisible messages in signs to help self-driving cars see the world", "id": "9538308", "details": {"liCnt": 5}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "One of American, Delta, and United's most feared rivals just suffered a major blow", {"timeCrawl": "14:14:00", "uri": "710925733", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T14:14:00Z", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/germanys-lufthansa-looking-to-buy-majority-of-air-berlin-planes/articleshow/60105246.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "* Lufthansa considers taking up to 90 aircraft - source\n\n* Talks with Lufthansa CEO due on Friday - Sueddeutsche\n\n* Air Berlin aims for deal with at least two buyers\n\n* Transport minister wants most assets to go to Lufthansa (Changes sourcing, adds details)\n\nBy Victoria Bryan and Maria Sheahan\n\nBERLIN/FRANKFURT, Aug 17 (Reuters) - Germany's Lufthansa is considering buying a majority of insolvent Air Berlin's aircraft, two people familiar with the matter said, as the government and rivals race to carve it up.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.\n\nThe insolvency comes as many Germans enjoy summer holidays, and just ahead of a September general election, both factors which have put pressure on the German government to help minimise travel disruptions and job losses.\n\nTransport Minister Alexander Dobrindt backed Lufthansa to buy a major portion of Air Berlin's assets, saying Germany needed a \"national champion\" in international aviation.\n\n\"That is why it is urgently necessary that Lufthansa can take over significant parts of Air Berlin,\" he told daily newspaper Rheinische Post.\n\nBerlin has granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($176 million) that will keep Air Berlin's planes in the air for up to three months, bringing holidaymakers home and securing 7,200 jobs in Germany while buyers for its assets are found.\n\nAir Berlin's demise offers Lufthansa and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against low-cost rival Ryanair.\n\nOne scenario Lufthansa's Chief Executive Carsten Spohr has presented to the flagship carrier's supervisory board is that it could take on as many as 90 of Air Berlin's roughly 140 planes, all of which are leased, one of the people said on Thursday.\n\nThat would include the 38 aircraft that Lufthansa is already leasing from Air Berlin and its Niki division.\n\n\"These are ideas that Lufthansa is bringing into the talks,\" the source said, adding that no decisions had been made yet and that it was ultimately up to Air Berlin's administrator.\n\nThe other source said the number of aircraft that Lufthansa could take on was lower than 90.\n\nThe Sueddeutsche Zeitung newspaper earlier cited company sources as saying that Lufthansa CEO Spohr was due to hold talks with Air Berlin's administrator and its management on Friday. Lufthansa declined to comment on the matter.\n\nAir Berlin itself has said it is in talks with three aviation firms and aims to strike deals with at least two of them by the end of September.\n\nSAFE LANDINGS\n\nRedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND), a group which represents German newspapers, cited government sources as saying that Lufthansa, its budget carrier Eurowings and Thomas Cook's German airline Condor would likely snap up Air Berlin's most valuable landing slots.\n\nA source has said easyJet was also part of the negotiations.\n\nRND said a few slots could also go to Ryanair, which has filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nGermany faces allegations by the European Commission of maintaining a cosy relationship with its domestic industry and questions about whether authorities did enough to uncover an emissions scandal at carmaker Volkswagen, which is partially state-owned. Lufthansa (LHAG.DE) is the sole major player remaining.\n\nGerman magazine Capital earlier reported that Woehrl was thinking of teaming up with other investors to make a takeover offer for Air Berlin, citing people familiar with the matter.\n\n\"INTRO already declared its interest years ago to take a majority stake in the Air Berlin group jointly with additional investors. This interest still exists,\" the spokeswoman said in an emailed statement, adding other investors were involved.\n\n\"We think Air Berlin is meaningful only as a whole, because that is the only way to prevent a monopoly at the expense of passengers in Germany.\"\n\nWoehrl made a name for himself in Germany's aviation world when he bought German airline Deutsche BA from British Airways -- now part of IAG (ICAG.L) - for 1 euro ($1.17) in 2003.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding workers in Germany while negotiations continue.\n\n\"No offer has been submitted so far because there are concerns that the loan by the government is meant to deliberately promote a monopoly structure {"timeCrawl": "09:53:00", "uri": "711368991", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T09:53:00Z", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "source": {"title": "DailySabah", "uri": "dailysabah.com", "id": "1235"}, "url": "https://www.dailysabah.com/business/2017/08/18/air-berlin-postpones-financial-results-after-filing-for-bankruptcy", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Air Berlin has indefinitely postponed the release of its financial results for the first six months of 2017, a spokesman said, days after the airline filed for insolvency.\n\nThe results were originally expected to be made public on Friday. However, the company spokesman said the figures would need to be reassessed in light of recent events.\n\nGermany's second-largest commercial airline filed for insolvency on Tuesday after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad Airways, withdrew financial aid for the loss-making carrier.\n\nThe German government has provided the company with a temporary credit of 150 million euros (176 million dollars) to help it continue operating for around three more months.\n\nBy law, Air Berlin has until early October to release the financial data.\n\nTransport Minister Alexander Dobrindt has called for Lufthansa to buy a major part of the assets, saying Germany needs a \"national champion\" in international aviation.\n\n\"That is why it is urgently necessary that Lufthansa can take over significant parts of Air Berlin,\" he told daily newspaper Rheinische Post.\n\nGerman flagship carrier Lufthansa has expressed an interest in buying a large share of assets in the bankrupt airline. Air Berlin officials are also in talks with two other interested parties.\n\nEuropean airline Ryanair filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the handling of the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nGermany's transport ministry already faces allegations by the European Commission of maintaining a cosy relationship with its domestic industry and questions about whether authorities did enough to uncover an emissions scandal at carmaker Volkswagen, which is partially state-owned.", "id": "9865908", "details": {}, {"timeCrawl": "15:08:00", "uri": "710388708", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T15:08:00Z", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "source": {"title": "Business Insider", "uri": "businessinsider.com", "id": "711"}, "url": "http://www.businessinsider.com/etihad-airline-trouble-airberlin-bankrupt-2017-8", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Etihad's grand plan for global domination looks to be in deep trouble.\n\nIn July, the Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates-based aviation giant announced a staggering $1.87 billion loss for 2016. This after posting a $103 million profit the previous year.\n\nEtihad blames $808 million of losses on financial exposure to partner airlines such as Air Berlin and Alitalia.\n\nNow things have gone from bad to worse.\n\nOn Tuesday, Air Berlin entered into administration, declaring itself insolvent and initiating a major restructuring. Air Berlin's financial implosion happened just three months after Alitalia's bankruptcy in May.\n\nTogether, Etihad's total financial exposure to the two troubled European carriers edges north of $4.5 billion.\n\n\"Etihad had a very ambitious and creative but very risky strategy, which was to invest in airlines in different countries to gain a proxy presence as an airline group, and two of its riskiest investments were Air Berlin and Alitalia,\" Henry Harteveldt, a travel analyst for Atmosphere Research Group, told Business Insider.\n\nIn July, the chief architect of the plan, former Etihad CEO James Hogan, exited the company he helped build.\n\nREUTERS/Fabian Bimmer\n\nOver the past few years, Etihad embarked on an equity-acquisition spree that has seen the carrier take substantial ownership stakes in a series of \"partner airlines.\" This includes 49% of Alitalia; 29.2% of Air Berlin; 49% of Air Serbia; 24% of Jet Airways; 21.8% of Virgin Australia; 40% of Air Seychelles; 49.8% of Niki; and 33% of Swiss-based Etihad Regional. But Etihad sold its stake in Etihad Regional in July.\n\nLast September, these partner airlines along with Etihad Airways and its accompanying subsidiaries were reconfigured to form Etihad Aviation Group.\n\nIn theory, Hogan's partnership concept makes a tremendous amount of sense. Investing in or taking over struggling airlines in advantageous markets for pennies on the dollar while simultaneously growing Etihad's global reach is strategically sound. The approach also allows Etihad to enter potentially hostile markets free of political opposition and without the need to launch an operation from scratch.\n\nIn practice, the partnership strategy is much more complex. Some have worked out well for Etihad. For instance, Air Serbia has relaunched and become a solid feeder into the Etihad network. The investment in Jet Airways has helped Etihad unlock the potentially lucrative Indian market. And Virgin Australia has become a viable competitor for Qantas.\n\nAir Serbia Airbus A330.AP\n\nAt the same time, Germany's Air Berlin and Italy's national carrier, Alitalia, have not fared so well. Both airlines were acquired to help Etihad increase its reach into the prized European and transatlantic markets, and to a certain extent, they have done exactly that. Operationally, however, Air Berlin and Alitalia have continued to bleed money.\n\nOn the face of it, the $2.35 billion Alitalia investment seemed like a solid deal. For the cost of a few Airbus A380 superjumbos, the company acquired a major airline with a fleet of 100 planes, Hogan told Business Insider in 2015.\n\nThe same goes for the Air Berlin deal.\n\n\"Air Berlin, on paper, looked like it would be very beneficial for Etihad,\" Harteveldt said. \"It gave Etihad access to a major European market that's arguably the strongest in terms of economic strength and demand for air travel.\"\n\nSo what happened?\n\n\"These two investments have turned out to be sort of Etihad biting off more than it can chew,\" Airways senior business analyst Vinay Bhaskara told Business Insider.\n\nAccording to Bhaskara, there are two types of reclamation projects that tend to succeed in the airline industry. The first is an airline that is underperforming simply because it is \"making boneheaded strategic errors\" to the point at which the airline is essentially its own worst enemy. These are easier to fix because they tend to be in good markets with good fundamentals. Thus, a management change should do the trick, Bhaskara said. Jet Airways falls into this category.\n\nAP\n\nThe second is an underperforming airline that is government owned or struggling with an incredible amount of internal dysfunction. These turnarounds can be successful if an outside force such as Etihad is \"handed the keys to the kingdom\" to tear down and rebuild the airline after making wholesale changes. This is exactly what Etihad was able to do at Air Serbia, Bhaskara added.\n\nTechnically, Air Berlin and Alitalia should have gone into this second category. But Etihad was never given the chance to implement the same type of full rebuild as Air Serbia.\n\nWith Alitalia, Etihad brought in new management, revamped its product, and improved its service. Many of the old problems that plagued the \"Old Alitalia,\" however, still plague the \"New Alitalia\" today. Bhaskara said one of the major issues the airline ran into was the powerful labor unions that prevented Etihad from making drastic changes that could have made the airline profitable.\n\nIn April, Alitalia entered into administration after workers rejected a management restructuring plan that would have cut salaries and jobs at the airline.\n\nAccording to the Financial Times, the last time Alitalia generated an annual profit was in 2002 -- one year before the founding of Etihad Airways.\n\nAir Berlin Airbus A330. Andreas Wiese / airberlin\n\nThe Air Berlin situation is slightly different than Alitalia, but equally dysfunctional.\n\nAccording to Harteveldt, Air Berlin faced a myriad of issues ranging from a delayed airport to a disjointed product strategy.\n\nFirst, the airport. Even though Berlin is one of the largest and most important cities in Europe, it doesn't actually have a world class airport.\n\nThe state-of-the-art Berlin Brandenburg Airport was scheduled to open in 2010. However, persistent delays have now pushed that day to as late as 2020.\n\nAs a result, Air Berlin hasn't been able to develop the mega hub it had hoped for in its home town. Instead, it has to settle for a smaller hub in Dusseldorf. However, that pales in comparison to the hubs Lufthansa has in larger markets like Frankfurt and Munich, Harteveldt told us.\n\nAt the same time, Air Berlin has been facing stiff competition from low-cost carriers like RyanAir, EasyJet, WizzAir, and other carriers.\n\nAnd then there was the airlines own \"basket case\" business strategy.\n\n\"Air Berlin just didn't have a clear strategy,\" Harteveldt said. \"It was a low cost, bare bones airline for its short haul European flights, but it tried to be a traditional full-service airline on its long-haul flights.\"\n\n\"It didn't accomplish either objective very well,\" the analyst added.\n\nAirbus/Etihad\n\nEven though the labor situation at Air Berlin was less contentious than Alitalia, it was still an issue that plagued the airline.\n\n\"In Europe, airlines are high profile industries that are highly unionized and the unions work very hard to protect their workers' jobs,\" Harteveldt said. \"Compared to the United States, for example, it very difficult for an airline in Europe to gain the labor efficiency that it needs whether that be wages or productivity or anything else.\"\n\nSo where does that leave Air Berlin?\n\nWhile Etihad is willing to explore commercial opportunities with the airline, it has made it clear that after $2.3 billion in investment its coffers are now off limits to Air Berlin.\n\n\"You can hear the sound of Etihad wiping its hands of Air Berlin all the way from Abu Dhabi to California,\" Harteveldt said.\n\nAlthough Harteveldt believes the Alitalia will likely fly on, the analyst thinks Air Berlin is effectively done as an airline. However, Bhaskara believes it's still too early to say whether Air Berlin's fate is sealed.\n\nAn Alitalia crew member walks past Alitalia employees who take part in a strike at Fiumicino international airport in Rome Thomson Reuters\n\nAir Berlin CEO Thomas Winkelmann has spoken out publicly to ensure his customers that the airline's flights will operate as usual with the help of a bridging loan worth $176 million.\n\nAt the end of the day, all is not lost for the Etihad partner airline strategy.\n\n\"In some cases, it looks like Etihad bet on some winning horses,\" Harteveldt said. \"Alitalia is still on the track and so we can't call that race yet.\"\n\nWhile it seems like the Etihad partnership strategy will probably live on to fight another day, Air Berlin and Alitalia have proven to be two very painful and expensive speed bumps along the way.", "id": "9505941", "details": {"liCnt": 13}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "One of American, Delta, and United's most feared rivals just suffered a major blow", "image": "http://static4.businessinsider.com/image/58dbef7777bb701a008b4ba1-1190-625/one-of-american-delta-and-uniteds-most-feared-rivals-just-suffered-a-major-blow.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "dateCrawl": {"timeCrawl": "15:20:00", "uri": "709834635", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T15:20:00Z", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "source": {"title": "Deutsche Welle (English)", "uri": "dw.com", "id": "430"}, "url": "http://www.dw.com/en/opinion-air-berlins-turbulent-journey/a-40104322", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "After years on the edge of bankruptcy, Germany's second-largest airline is over the cliff. A state loan will only keep it afloat for some weeks. DW's Henrik B\u00f6hme hopes for wise decisions in the interest of employees.\n\nWhen a previously agreed tranche of 50 million euros ($59 million) from Etihad was not transferred to Air Berlin's account last Friday, alarm bells rang at the headquarters of Germany's second-biggest carrier. It finally dawned on the airline's management that the sheiks of Etihad Airways had cut off their money supply.\n\nThis didn't really come as a big surprise, since Etihad, once a major player among Gulf airlines alongside Emirates and Qatar Airways, has enough problems of its own. Etihad's strategy of buying into troubled competitors has failed miserably.\n\nGigantic debt levels\n\nPerhaps Etihad's underlying strategy was to lull rivals into a sense of security and then let them die slowly, whilst collecting the valuable bits and pieces and taking over important routes. But with Air Berlin and Alitalia, Etihad has had to grapple with two formidable money-burners, which are now being bailed out by the taxpayer.\n\nRead also: Air Berlin files for bankcruptcy protection\n\nAir Berlin's debts currently amount to 1.2 billion euros. Since 2011, i.e. since its first investment in the German carrier, Etihad has pumped over 1.5 billion euros into its ailing subsidiary. Etihad pledged in the spring of this year that it would continue to provide additional financial support for at least another one and a half years. But in the end, it decided against it.\n\nPassengers who have flown Air Berlin in recent months have been able to see for themselves what a terrible state the airline has been in. There have been many cancellations, massive delays, and ticket transfers to dubious carriers. I wouldn't be surprised if damage claims to the tune of millions of euros are on their way.\n\nEverything under control? Forget it!\n\nAt its London shareholders meeting in June, Air Berlin executives bent over backward to present an optimistic outlook, despite earlier speculation about the carrier's desolate situation and the need for public guarantees. But shareholders were told that everything was under control and that the situation wasn't nearly as bad as portrayed. There was no talk about possible insolvency procedures.\n\nAnd now, only two months later, we have a complete admission of failure. How blind must executives have been to not be aware of Etihad's own problems?\n\nThe taxpayer is now once again called upon to come to the rescue, with a 150-million-euro loan to prevent Air Berlin from stopping operations immediately, in the middle of the holiday season. The government may have reasoned it might not be a bright idea to cause chaos for travelers by declining to provide a shot in the arm.\n\nAir Berlin, for its part, is now suffering from the many strategic blunders it has made over the past few years. It got worse with every decision taken and every management reshuffle. Whenever a hole was plugged, two new problems seemed to appear elsewhere.\n\nDomestic rival Lufthansa, which has already taken over 38 Air Berlin planes and concomitant staff, will look over what's left of its erstwhile competitor and will most likely boost its own no-frills subsidiary, Eurowings, with the pickings.\n\nIt remains to be hoped that many of Air Berlin's 8,500 employees will keep their jobs. After all, the vast majority of them cannot be blamed for the corporate disaster at hand. If that happens, the government's new loan guarantee will be money well spent.", "id": "9305260", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Opinion: Air Berlin's turbulent journey | Business | DW {"timeCrawl": "10:20:00", "uri": "710816567", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:20:00Z", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "source": {"title": "thelocal.de", "uri": "thelocal.de", "id": "3884"}, "url": "https://www.thelocal.de/20170817/insolvent-air-berlin-says-its-in-talks-with-three-potential-buyers", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Air Berlin is in talks with three competitors about buying up its assets, the insolvent airline's boss said on Thursday, warning that not all jobs would be saved.\n\n\"Aside from Lufthansa, we are in contact with two other interested parties from the aviation industry,\" Air Berlin chief executive Thomas Winkelmann told the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung newspaper.\n\nThe negotiations have been going on for weeks, he said, and all three airlines were financially sound and large enough \"to offer Air Berlin a secure future\" while keeping Germany as an operations hub.\n\nHe did not name the other two airlines, but EasyJet has long been eyeing Air Berlin and German media have speculated that Thomas Cook subsidiary Condor is the third party.\n\nREAD MORE: Five things you need to know after the Air Berlin insolvency\n\nAir Berlin was forced to file for insolvency on Tuesday after main shareholder Etihad suddenly ended its financial support for the loss-making airline.\n\nThe government stepped in with a \u20ac150-million ($170-million) bridging loan to keep Germany's second-largest airline flying for the next three months, saying it did not want to leave tens of thousands of holidaymakers stranded.\n\nWinkelmann said he aimed to strike a deal with at least two of the interested buyers by the end of September, with Air Berlin's landing rights considered particularly valuable and the fate of Austrian subsidiary Niki also under discussion.\n\n\"But we won't be able to save all jobs,\" the newspaper quoted Winkelmann as telling employees in staff meetings.\n\nThe airline, sometimes dubbed the \"Mallorca shuttle\" for its popularity with German tourists headed for Spanish beaches, employs some 8,000 people.\n\nIt has long battled for survival, booking losses amounting to \u20ac1.2 billion over the past two years and relying on cash infusions from Etihad.\n\n'Conspiracy'\n\nBut the government's intervention, just weeks before a September 24th general election, to keep Air Berlin flying for now has come in for criticism.\n\nLow-cost rival Ryanair has lodged complaints with German and European competition regulators, slamming what it called a \"conspiracy\" between the government, Lufthansa and Air Berlin to carve up the insolvent carrier's assets.\n\nForeign Minister Sigmar Gabriel defended the move, saying the financial lifeline was needed to prevent 80,000 travellers a day from being stranded during the busy holiday period.\n\nBut a government official told the Handelsblatt financial daily the state aid was a clear example of electioneering.\n\n\"Eighty thousand stranded holidaymakers are almost 80,000 voters. That's how simple the political calculation is,\" the unnamed source said.", "id": "9661775", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Insolvent Air Berlin says it's in talks with three {"timeCrawl": "10:23:00", "uri": "710818116", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:23:00Z", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "source": {"title": "Bloomberg Business", "uri": "bloomberg.com", "id": "1749"}, "url": "https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-16/air-berlin-collapse-opens-way-to-lufthansa-long-haul-expansion", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "EasyJet favored to pick up short-haul slots in German capital\n\nAir Berlin Plc's insolvency could open the way for Deutsche Lufthansa AG to add new hubs for inter-continental flights while allowing short-haul discount specialist EasyJet Plc to boost its presence in the German capital.\n\nThe ailing carrier's Berlin and Dusseldorf bases provide Lufthansa's lower-cost Eurowings arm with a chance to expand a long-haul network currently limited to Cologne-Bonn airport and a fledgling operation in Munich. At the same time, slots in Berlin used for short-haul services could help EasyJet narrow the gap to Ryanair Holdings Plc in Europe's biggest economy.\n\nAir Berlin filed for insolvency Tuesday as leading shareholder Etihad Airways PJSC of Abu Dhabi pulled the plug on funding the unprofitable carrier, which will rely on a government loan to keep flying for the next three months. Lufthansa, Germany's biggest airline and the No. 3 in Europe, revealed that it was in talks about buying parts of its national rival, while EasyJet has also expressed an interest, according to people familiar with the matter.\n\nA deal could be \"very attractive\" for Lufthansa if it can acquire elements of Air Berlin, which has 8,600 workers, without taking on the company's debt or staff contracts, Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. analysts including Daniel Roeska said in a note. There's also a \"strategic rationale\" behind EasyJet making a move, and the U.K. carrier has the business model to make a transaction work, they said.\n\nWhile the 150 million-euro ($177 million) loan should get Germans home from their summer vacations, Air Berlin will likely run out of cash at the end of the three-month period, setting a deadline for negotiations, Bernstein said.\n\nLufthansa, which is unlikely to be able to buy all of Air Berlin for antitrust reasons, already has strong links to its one-time arch rival following a deal that handed it 38 of the smaller carrier's Airbus SE A320-series planes plus crews under a six-year lease deal. Some 33 of those aircraft are slated for deployment with Eurowings and five with the group's Austrian Airlines division.\n\nAt the same time, Air Berlin planned to offload its own Austrian unit Niki, which has 21 A321 jets, by combining it with 14 aircraft from TUI AG, Europe's largest tour operator. Though the plan suffered a setback in June when TUI failed to agree terms with Etihad, it said Tuesday that it's ready to participate in Air Berlin's restructuring. Thomas Cook Group Plc's Condor arm, which books seats on Air Berlin flights, also said it could play an \"active role\" in a rescue plan.\n\nAir Berlin's Swiss Belair arm, which has seven A320-family planes, is set to close at the end of the summer, according to an announcement in March, while the company was due to full control of regional affiliate LGW, with 20 Bombardier Inc. Q400 turboprops.\n\nThe restructuring steps were designed to trim the Air Berlin fleet to just 75 jets from almost 150, leaving it focused on inter-continental routes from Berlin and Dusseldorf, fed by shorter European flights, plus minor hubs in Munich and Stuttgart. It currently serves about 20 long-haul destinations with 17 Airbus A330 wide-body jets, with the focus on the U.S. and the Caribbean.\n\nAs Air Berlin's doesn't own its aircraft, the main value for suitors may be in its landing rights, which are usually distributed by a national coordinator after airlines apply for them. German Economic Minister Brigitte Zypries, though, said slots may be sold off by the insolvency administrator to raise funds.\n\nLufthansa's global strategy is increasingly built around beefing up Eurowings, initially created to defend its European turf against the likes of Ryanair by taking over short-haul routes outside of its Frankfurt and Munich hubs.\n\nWhile the unit has been swollen by the Air Berlin lease deal and the acquisition of Brussels Airlines, the transfer of existing short-haul routes from the parent airline has been slowed by union opposition, putting new emphasis on expanding long-haul services. By the end of this year Eurowings will have more than 160 aircraft spread across 11 bases, including a fleet of A330s.\n\nAt the very least, Lufthansa is likely to want to safeguard the leased Air Berlin planes, which fly mainly on Mediterranean routes, according to Bernstein, and could use that structure to add more operations from the smaller carrier.\n\nFor EasyJet, acquiring parts of the Air Berlin short-haul business would help make up lost ground in Germany, where it lags well behind Ryanair. The Luton, England-based company announced in June that it would shut a base in Hamburg, where it stations four A320-series aircraft, at the end of the summer season, leaving only its Berlin operation, which utilizes 12 planes.\n\nRyanair locates nine jets in Berlin, but also has eight other bases in Germany including Cologne-Bonn and Hamburg, as well as Frankfurt, where it will station seven planes this winter in a direct challenge to Lufthansa at its primary hub. A 10th base will open in Memmingen, outside Munich, in September.\n\nComplicating matters, EasyJet's Berlin flights operate out of Schoenefeld airport rather than the main Tegel hub used by Air Berlin. Current thinking calls for Tegel to be closed when the new and long-delayed Berlin Brandenburg hub opens, though those plans are under review.\n\nWhether EasyJet or Ryanair buys Air Berlin assets, both are likely to benefit from the German No. 2's exit, with one competitor less in the market, Per-Ola Hellgren, an analyst at Landesbank Baden-Wuerttemberg, said in an investor note. Eurowings has a higher cost base than both carriers, he said.\n\nProgress on a carve up of Air Berlin could be rapid, according to Bernstein's Roeska, with Lufthansa keen to bolster its defenses against low-cost carriers and the German government eager to protect jobs in an election year. The alternative could make Germany \"a clear target for imminent attack,\" he said.\n\n\"If there is no deal, and Air Berlin collapses, Lufthansa will be facing a large capacity gap in the German market at precisely the time Ryanair is looking to make good on its ambitious expansion.\"", "id": "9662474", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Lufthansa Swoop for Air Berlin Would Add Lower-Cost U.S. Routes", "image": "https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iViHRBj5v8Xk/v2/1200x800.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "concepts": [{"location": "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Germany's Lufthansa is considering buying a majority of insolvent Air Berlin's aircraft, two people familiar with the matter said, as the government and rivals race to carve it up.\n\nAir Berlin <AB1.DE>, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.\n\nThe insolvency comes as many Germans enjoy summer holidays, and just ahead of a September general election, both factors which have put pressure on the German government to help minimise travel disruptions and job losses.\n\nTransport Minister Alexander Dobrindt backed Lufthansa to buy a major portion of Air Berlin's assets, saying Germany needed a \"national champion\" in international aviation.\n\n\"That is why it is urgently necessary that Lufthansa can take over significant parts of Air Berlin,\" he told daily newspaper Rheinische Post.\n\nBerlin has granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($176 million) that will keep Air Berlin's planes in the air for up to three months, bringing holidaymakers home and securing 7,200 jobs in Germany while buyers for its assets are found.\n\nAir Berlin's demise offers Lufthansa <LHAG.DE> and rivals a chance to acquire slots at airports such as Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, with Germany's largest airline keen to defend its domestic position against low-cost rival Ryanair <RYA.I>.\n\nOne scenario Lufthansa's Chief Executive Carsten Spohr has presented to the flagship carrier's supervisory board is that it could take on as many as 90 of Air Berlin's roughly 140 planes, all of which are leased, one of the people said on Thursday.\n\nThat would include the 38 aircraft that Lufthansa is already leasing from Air Berlin and its Niki division.\n\n\"These are ideas that Lufthansa is bringing into the talks,\" the source said, adding that no decisions had been made yet and that it was ultimately up to Air Berlin's administrator.\n\nThe other source said the number of aircraft that Lufthansa could take on was lower than 90.\n\nThe Sueddeutsche Zeitung newspaper earlier cited company sources as saying that Lufthansa CEO Spohr was due to hold talks with Air Berlin's administrator and its management on Friday. Lufthansa declined to comment on the matter.\n\nAir Berlin itself has said it is in talks with three aviation firms and aims to strike deals with at least two of them by the end of September.\n\nRedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND), a group which represents German newspapers, cited government sources as saying that Lufthansa, its budget carrier Eurowings and Thomas Cook's <TCG.L> German airline Condor would likely snap up Air Berlin's most valuable landing slots.\n\nA source has said easyJet <EZJ.L> was also part of the negotiations.\n\nRND said a few slots could also go to Ryanair, which has filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the insolvency process, which its chief executive describes as a \"conspiracy\".\n\nGermany faces allegations by the European Commission of maintaining a cosy relationship with its domestic industry and questions about whether authorities did enough to uncover an emissions scandal at carmaker Volkswagen <VOWG_p.DE>, which is partially state-owned.\n\n(Additional reporting by Sabine Wollrab; editing by Robert Birsel and Alexander Smith)", "id": "9706137", "details": {}, "date": "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Air Berlin on Tuesday filed for insolvency after shareholder Etihad said it would not provide more funding, turning to the German government for a 150 million euro ($176 million) loan to keep planes in the air while it negotiates a sale of parts of its business to Lufthansa and one other airline.\n\nRyanair has already filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the insolvency process, which it describes as a \"conspiracy\" because it believes that Lufthansa will gain a bigger share of the German market.\n\nA German economy ministry spokeswoman said a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($175.5 million) the government had granted Air Berlin did not breach anti-trust rules.\n\nGermany faces allegations of maintaining a cosy relationship with its domestic industry and questions about whether authorities did enough to uncover an emissions scandal at carmaker Volkswagen, which is partially state-owned.\n\nAir Berlin said it had sounded out the German states of North-Rhine Westphalia and Berlin in June to see whether they would provide loan guarantees after Etihad signalled it was rethinking its strategy of holding minority investments in smaller carriers.\n\nThe German economy ministry spokeswoman said that negotiations between Lufthansa and Air Berlin had been going on for \"months\" as executives sought a long-term solution for the airline.\n\nThe German government said it expected no anti-trust issues because Air Berlin would be sold off in bits.\n\nBut O'Leary is not convinced his airline is being given a fair chance.\n\n\"A merger will take Lufthansa from 68 per cent to 95 per cent of the German domestic market and from 47 per cent to 60 per cent control of the total German market, which would be in breach of every known competition threshold rule and guideline in Germany and the EU,\" O'Leary said.\n\nHe said Alitalia's insolvency was being done on a fairer basis, with rival airlines being invited to submit offers.\n\n\"That's the process they should be going through with Air Berlin,\" he said.\n\nWhen asked if Ryanair could bid for Air Berlin assets, he said he expected a deal would go through too quickly to give Ryanair a chance to bid and that only unattractive airport slots would be offered up.\n\n\"There's nothing to bid for, it's a ready-up,\" he said. \"We will continue to grow, we're still buying more aircraft. But we will struggle to get slots, to base more aircraft in airports like Frankfurt, Berlin, Munich.\"\n\nO'Leary said he hoped the EU authorities would step in to force competition remedies, such as giving up airport slots to rivals.\n\nThe EU Commission said it was in \"constructive contact\" with Germany. \"We are confident that solutions can be found within the framework of EU law,\" a Commission spokesman said.\n\nIzzet Sinan, partner at law firm Morgan, Lewis & Bockius said it was no surprise that Ryanair had voiced its objections.\n\n\"The question is what actions will follow the words,\" Sinan said.", "id": "9545102", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Lufthansa taking over Air Berlin to halt our expansion: Ryanair CEO", "image": Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung (FAZ), without naming names.\n\nAll three are \"reputable in terms of their finances, sufficiently large to offer Air Berlin a secure future and are interested in keeping Germany as a base of operations\", the daily newspaper quoted Winkelmann as saying in its Thursday edition.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses, leaving valuable runway slots up for grabs.\n\nAccording to Winkelmann, the negotiations include assets of Air Berlin unit Niki, which Etihad had bought from the German carrier for 300 million euros ($354 million) this year.\n\nLufthansa has confirmed it is in talks to take over parts of Air Berlin's business, while a source has said easyJet was also part of the negotiations.\n\nThomas Cook's German airline Condor said on Wednesday it was ready to play \"an active role\" in Air Berlin's restructuring, without being more specific.\n\nWinkelmann aims to strike a deal with two or more buyers by the end of September, the newspaper said.\n\nThe government granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations go on.\n\n($1 = 0.8485 euros) (Reporting by Maria Sheahan; {"timeCrawl": "16:17:00", "uri": "709861320", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T11:39:00Z", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "source": {"title": "Gulf Business", "uri": "gulfbusiness.com", "id": "12184"}, "url": "http://gulfbusiness.com/etihad-expresses-disappointment-as-air-berlin-files-for-insolvency/", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "The Abu Dhabi airline said it cannot offer any additional funding to the struggling German airline\n\nAbu Dhabi airline Etihad Airways has expressed \"disappointment\" over Air Berlin's decision to file for insolvency, it said on Tuesday.\n\nThe German airline said it would continue flying with the help of government loans, while Deutsche Lufthansa said it may buy parts of the airline.\n\n\"This development is extremely disappointing for all parties, especially as Etihad has provided extensive support to Air Berlin for its previous liquidity challenges and restructuring efforts over the past six years,\" Etihad said in a statement.\n\nThe Abu Dhabi airline acquired a 29.2 per cent in Air Berlin in 2011, and has since invested heavily in the struggling German airline.\n\n\"In April this year, Etihad provided EUR250m of additional funding to Air Berlin as well as supporting the airline to explore strategic options for the business,\" it said.\n\n\"However, Air Berlin's business has deteriorated at an unprecedented pace, preventing it from overcoming its significant challenges and from implementing alternative strategic solutions.\"\n\nAir Berlin has accumulated losses worth over EUR2.7bn in over six years and has a net debt of EUR1.2bn.\n\n\"Under these circumstances, as a minority shareholder, Etihad cannot offer funding that would further increase our financial exposure. We remain open to helping find a commercially viable solution for all parties,\" the statement added.\n\nEtihad confirmed that it expects the German airline to continue operations during administration.\n\n\"We have a commercial relationship with Air Berlin across a range of areas, including codeshare operations, and we will support its management during these difficult times,\" it said.\n\nSaj Ahmad, chief analyst at StrategicAero Research, said that Air Berlin's collapse underscores the \"immense difficulties and challenges that Etihad endured in trying to get the airline to restructure, change and become a viable competitor to Lufthansa\".\n\n\"That Etihad has taken a massive financial hit in its earnings a few weeks ago highlights to good effect why they were not prepared to bail out the airline any more,\" he said.\n\nLast month, the carrier announced a net loss of $1.9bn for 2016, its first loss since Etihad started making money in 2011.\n\nEtihad booked one-off impairments of $1.9bn that included $1.06bn on aircraft and $808m on \"certain assets and financial exposures to equity partners, mainly related to Alitalia and Air Berlin,\" it said.\n\nRead more: Etihad Airways posts $1.87bn loss in 2016 amid turbulent year\n\n\"Coupled with the toxic situation at Alitalia and the sale of Darwin Airline, it looks like Etihad is re-evaluating its position and is probably better off concentrating on its own organic expansion as opposed to be side-tracked by equity stakes that have not delivered the rewards that had been envisioned,\" said Ahmad.\n\nEtihad is now restructuring operations, with its long-serving CEO James Hogan leaving the company on July 1.\n\nHogan spearheaded the airline's strategy to buy minority stakes in other airlines across the world.\n\nRead more: Abu Dhabi's Etihad Aviation Group appoints interim CEO and CFO\n\nAbu Dhabi's Etihad announces management restructuring\n\n\"The new leadership at Etihad, in my mind, has to wipe the slate clean from this sort of troublesome exposure and get back to showcasing Etihad's premium offerings,\" opined Ahmad.\n\n\"Etihad has spent too long trying to help others, it has lost ground and needs to recover that. It's a bad day in the Etihad office, that's for sure, but now that Etihad is arguably free from Air Berlin, it can get back to business as it looks to turn around its losses,\" he added.", "id": Air Berlin has recorded loss of 782 million euros last year.\n\nThe German Federal Government has offered a bridge loan, secured by a federal guarantee, to maintain flight operations. The airline has been carrying around 80 thousand passengers on a daily basis. The funding to the tune of 150 million euros from the government will help continue the services.\n\nThe filing at the local district court of Berlin-Charlottenburg is a petition for the opening of debtor-in-possession insolvency proceedings.
