{"timeCrawl": "15:42:00", "uri": "709844827", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T15:42:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"title": "thelocal.de", "uri": "thelocal.de", "id": "3884"}, "url": "https://www.thelocal.de/20170815/five-things-you-need-to-know-after-the-air-berlin-insolvency", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "After Air Berlin filed for insolvency proceedings on Tuesday, many customers and travellers are asking where this leaves them. We answer the key questions.\n\nFor the short term, yes. The German federal government has provided \u20ac150 million in loans to the stricken airline, ensuring that planes will continue to fly for the next three months, Economy Minister Brigitte Zypries announced on Tuesday.\n\nZypries also did not rule out providing more funds for the company at the end of that three-month period.\n\nWhat about the long term?\n\nThe government hopes that Lufthansa will buy up parts of Air Berlin during the next three months, thus ensuring that by the time the state loan has run out, new owners will be in place who can keep on running services on the Air Berlin lines. One of those owners is likely to be Lufthansa, who announced on Tuesday that they were in talks to buy up parts of their competitor.\n\nAre my tickets still valid?\n\nApparently, yes. Air Berlin announced on Tuesday that all flights booked with the company remain valid. They also said that the flight plans for the airline and its subsidiary Niki would remain unchanged and that every scheduled flight would take place.\n\nBut the airline has been hit by delays and cancellations in recent months and repeatedly sought to reassure customers that everything was okay. So history should tell us that anyone flying with Air Berlin shouldn't be shocked if they are hit by problems.\n\nCan I still buy tickets with Air Berlin?\n\nThe company said on Tuesday that customers can buy tickets on all flights which have been scheduled by the company. The Local on Tuesday looked into buying flights from Berlin to Munich in December - i.e. after the government's three months deadline - and was offered seats starting at \u20ac41.60.\n\nWhat does this mean for ticket prices?\n\nRyanair are furious about the insolvency, claiming it has been planned to allow for a takeover of the company by Lufthansa, Germany's largest carrier.\n\nRyanair spokesman Robin Kiely said that a takeover by Lufthansa would contravene all German and EU competition rules. He also claimed that the German government was supporting Lufthansa by providing \u20ac150 million in credit to Air Berlin.\n\n\"German travellers as well as people visiting Germany will have to deal with higher prices and will end up paying for the Lufthansa monopoly,\" he said.\n\nTransport Minister Alexander Dobrindt has claimed that a partial takeover by Lufthansa would not contravene competition rules, as they would not be buying up the whole company. false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "FRANKFURT, Aug 17 (Reuters) - Insolvent German airline Air Berlin is in talks with a total of three aviation firms, including Lufthansa, to find buyers for its assets, Chief Executive Thomas Winkelmann told Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung (FAZ), without naming names.\n\nAll three are \"reputable in terms of their finances, sufficiently large to offer Air Berlin a secure future and are interested in keeping Germany as a base of operations\", the daily newspaper quoted Winkelmann as saying in its Thursday edition.\n\nAir Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses, leaving valuable runway slots up for grabs.\n\nAccording to Winkelmann, the negotiations include assets of Air Berlin unit Niki, which Etihad had bought from the German carrier for 300 million euros ($354 million) this year.\n\nLufthansa has confirmed it is in talks to take over parts of Air Berlin's business, while a source has said easyJet was also part of the negotiations.\n\nThomas Cook's German airline Condor said on Wednesday it was ready to play \"an active role\" in Air Berlin's restructuring, without being more specific.\n\nWinkelmann aims to strike a deal with two or more buyers by the end of September, the newspaper said.\n\nThe government granted a bridging loan of 150 million euros to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of its 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations go on.\n\n($1 = 0.8485 euros) (Reporting by Maria Sheahan; Editing by Robert Birsel)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your device.", "id": {"timeCrawl": "10:55:00", "uri": "710832834", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:55:00Z", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "source": {"title": "Luxemburger Wort", "uri": "wort.lu", "id": "510"}, "url": "http://www.wort.lu/en/business/airlines-three-airlines-interested-in-air-berlin-assets-ceo-says-599574d7a5e74263e13c5dae", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "(AFP) Air Berlin is in talks with three competitors about buying up its assets, the insolvent airline's boss said on Thursday, adding that not all jobs would be saved.\n\n\"Aside from Lufthansa, we are in contact with two other interested parties from the aviation industry,\" Air Berlin Chief Executive Thomas Winkelmann told the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung newspaper.\n\nThe negotiations have been going on for weeks, he said, and all three airlines were financially sound and large enough \"to offer Air Berlin a secure future\" while keeping Germany as an operations hub.\n\nHe did not name the other two airlines, but EasyJet has long been eyeing Air Berlin and German media have speculated that Thomas Cook subsidiary Condor is the third party.\n\nAir Berlin was forced to file for insolvency on Tuesday after main shareholder Etihad suddenly ended its financial support for the loss-making airline.\n\nThe government stepped in with a \u20ac150-million bridging loan to keep Germany's second-largest airline flying for the next three months, saying it did not want to leave tens of thousands of holidaymakers stranded.\n\nWinkelmann said he aimed to strike a deal with at least two of the interested buyers by the end of September, with Air Berlin's landing rights considered particularly valuable and the fate of Austrian subsidiary Niki also under discussion.\n\n\"We won't be able to save all jobs,\" the newspaper quoted Winkelmann as telling employees in staff meetings.\n\nThe airline, sometimes dubbed the \"Mallorca shuttle\" for its popularity with German tourists headed for Spanish beaches, employs some 8,000 people.\n\nIt has long battled for survival, booking losses amounting to \u20ac1.2 billion over the past two years and relying on cash infusions from Etihad.\n\nBut the government's intervention, just weeks before a September 24 general election, to keep Air Berlin flying for now has come in for criticism.\n\nLow-cost rival Ryanair has lodged complaints with German and European competition regulators, slamming what it called a \"conspiracy\" between the government, Lufthansa and Air Berlin to carve up the insolvent carrier's assets.\n\nForeign Minister Sigmar Gabriel defended the move, saying the financial lifeline was needed to prevent 80,000 travellers a day from being stranded during the busy holiday period.\n\nBut a government official told the Handelsblatt financial daily the state aid was a clear example of electioneering.\n\n\"Eighty thousand stranded holidaymakers are almost 80,000 voters. "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Air Berlin is in talks with three competitors about buying up its assets, the insolvent airline's boss said Thursday, warning that not all jobs would be saved.\n\n\"Aside from Lufthansa, we are in contact with two other interested parties from the aviation industry,\" Air Berlin chief executive Thomas Winkelmann told the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung newspaper.\n\nThe negotiations have been going on for weeks, he said, and all three airlines were financially sound and large enough \"to offer Air Berlin a secure future\" while keeping Germany as an operations hub.\n\nHe did not name the other two airlines, but EasyJet has long been eyeing Air Berlin and German media have speculated that Thomas Cook subsidiary Condor is the third party.\n\nAir Berlin was forced to file for insolvency on Tuesday after main shareholder Etihad suddenly ended its financial support for the loss-making airline.\n\nThe government stepped in with a 150-million-euro ($170-million) bridging loan to keep Germany's second-largest airline flying for the next three months, saying it did not want to leave tens of thousands of holidaymakers stranded.\n\nWinkelmann said he aimed to strike a deal with at least two of the interested buyers by the end of September, with Air Berlin's landing rights considered particularly valuable and the fate of Austrian subsidiary Niki also under discussion.\n\n\"But we won't be able to save all jobs,\" the newspaper quoted Winkelmann as telling employees in staff meetings.\n\nThe airline, sometimes dubbed the \"Mallorca shuttle\" for its popularity with German tourists headed for Spanish beaches, employs some 8,000 people.\n\nIt has long battled for survival, booking losses amounting to 1.2 billion euros over the past two years and relying on cash infusions from Etihad.\n\n- 'Conspiracy' -\n\nBut the government's intervention, just weeks before a September 24 general election, to keep Air Berlin flying for now has come in for criticism.\n\nLow-cost rival Ryanair has lodged complaints with German and European competition regulators, slamming what it called a \"conspiracy\" between the government, Lufthansa and Air Berlin to carve up the insolvent carrier's assets.\n\nForeign Minister Sigmar Gabriel defended the move, saying the financial lifeline was needed to prevent 80,000 travellers a day from being stranded during the busy holiday period.\n\nBut a government official told the Handelsblatt financial daily the state aid was a clear example of electioneering.\n\n\"Eighty thousand stranded holidaymakers are {"timeCrawl": "14:20:00", "uri": "709808592", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T14:20:00Z", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "source": {"title": "Fortune", "uri": "fortune.com", "id": "18439"}, "url": "http://fortune.com/2017/08/15/air-berlin-bankruptcy-etihad/", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Air Berlin, the discount airline that is Germany's second-biggest carrier and Europe's seventh-largest by passenger numbers, said Tuesday it is filing for insolvency.\n\nThe news ends months of speculation over the indebted carrier, which had been dependent for some time on cash injections from its largest shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad Airways. The company's operating loss had more than doubled last year to 667 million euros ($787 million) due to various write-offs and restructuring charges as it belatedly tried to save itself.\n\nThe company said in a statement to the Frankfurt Stock Exchange that it had had no option after Etihad refused to offer any further financial support. Etihad had bought into a number of European airlines in recent years, not least because it hoped they would drive long-haul traffic to its hub in Abu Dhabi and also support its efforts to break into the U.S. market.\n\nHowever, that strategy has unravelled as losses proved too heavy to sustain. In May, Italian flag-carrier Alitalia went into bankruptcy proceedings, leaving Etihad sitting on a loss of nearly $2 billion.\n\nEtihad didn't respond immediately to a request for comment from Fortune.\n\nAir Berlin said it's now in talks with German flag carrier Lufthansa for parts of its business. It has also asked for, and been given, a 150 million euro bridging loan from the federal German government to avoid disruptions to service -- especially during the height of tourist season -- while it conducts such talks.\n\nDespite its well-publicized troubles, Air Berlin had insisted as recently as June that it wasn't about to go bankrupt.\n\n\"Insolvency is not an issue for us. We have sufficient liquidity and a reliable partner, Etihad, which has pledged its support through to October 2018,\" a spokeswoman from the airline told AFP at the time.\n\nShares in other European airlines rose in response to the news. Companies such as Ryanair and Easyjet have warned about excess capacity on their routes in recent earnings statements, and the exit of Air Berlin from the market will reduce the pressure on them to keep fares down. {"timeCrawl": "14:47:00", "uri": "710378404", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T14:47:00Z", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "source": {"title": "Reuters India", "uri": "in.reuters.com", "id": "630"}, "url": "https://in.reuters.com/article/air-berlin-lufthansa-ryanair-idINKCN1AW1OE", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "BERLIN (Reuters) - Ryanair sees any plans by Lufthansa to take over parts of insolvent rival Air Berlin as a \"conspiracy\" to halt the Irish carrier's expansion, its chief executive told Reuters.\n\nAir Berlin on Tuesday filed for insolvency after shareholder Etihad said it would not provide more funding, turning to the German government for a 150 million euro ($176 million) loan to keep planes in the air while it negotiates a sale of parts of its business to Lufthansa and one other airline.\n\nRyanair has already filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the insolvency process, which it describes as a \"conspiracy\" because it believes that Lufthansa will gain a bigger share of the German market.\n\n\"All this is down to prevent Ryanair growing in Germany, but it won't stop us,\" Michael O'Leary told Reuters in a telephone interview on Wednesday.\n\nGermany has rejected Ryanair's claims.\n\nA German economy ministry spokeswoman said a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($175.5 million) the government had granted Air Berlin did not breach anti-trust rules.\n\n\"I reject the accusation by Ryanair today that it was a staged insolvency application,\" the spokeswoman said.\n\nA spokesman for Lufthansa declined to comment on the Ryanair accusations.\n\nGermany faces allegations of maintaining a cosy relationship with its domestic industry and questions about whether authorities did enough to uncover an emissions scandal at carmaker Volkswagen, which is partially state-owned.\n\nAir Berlin said it had sounded out the German states of North-Rhine Westphalia and Berlin in June to see whether they would provide loan guarantees after Etihad signalled it was rethinking its strategy of holding minority investments in smaller carriers.\n\nThe German economy ministry spokeswoman said that negotiations between Lufthansa and Air Berlin had been going on for \"months\" as executives sought a long-term solution for the airline.\n\nThe German government said it expected no anti-trust issues because Air Berlin would be sold off in bits.\n\nBut O'Leary is not convinced his airline is being given a fair chance.\n\n\"A merger will take Lufthansa from 68 percent to 95 percent of the German domestic market and from 47 percent to 60 percent control of the total German market, which would be in breach of every known competition threshold rule and guideline in Germany and the EU,\" O'Leary said.\n\nHe said Alitalia's insolvency was being done on a fairer basis, with rival airlines being invited to submit offers.\n\n\"That's the process they should be going through with Air Berlin,\" he said.\n\nWhen asked if Ryanair could bid for Air Berlin assets, he said he expected a deal would go through too quickly to give Ryanair a chance to bid and that only unattractive airport slots would be offered up.\n\n\"There's nothing to bid for, it's a ready-up,\" he said. \"We will continue to grow, we're still buying more aircraft. But we will struggle to get slots, to base more aircraft in airports like Frankfurt, Berlin, Munich.\"\n\nO'Leary said he hoped the EU authorities would step in to force competition remedies, such as giving up airport slots to rivals.\n\nThe EU Commission said it was in \"constructive contact\" with Germany. \"We are confident that solutions can be found within the framework of EU law,\" a Commission spokesman said.\n\nIzzet Sinan, partner at law firm Morgan, Lewis & Bockius said it was no surprise that Ryanair had voiced its objections.\n\n\"The question is what actions will follow the words,\" Sinan said.", "id": "9502216", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Ryanair CEO hits out at Air Berlin/Lufthansa deal", "image": {"timeCrawl": "14:18:00", "uri": "710364208", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T14:18:00Z", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4796056/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "By Victoria Bryan\n\nBERLIN, Aug 16 (Reuters) - Ryanair sees any plans by Lufthansa to take over parts of insolvent rival Air Berlin as a \"conspiracy\" to halt the Irish carrier's expansion, its chief executive told Reuters.\n\nAir Berlin on Tuesday filed for insolvency after shareholder Etihad said it would not provide more funding, turning to the German government for a 150 million euro ($176 million) loan to keep planes in the air while it negotiates a sale of parts of its business to Lufthansa and one other airline.\n\nRyanair has already filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the insolvency process, which it describes as a \"conspiracy\" because it believes that Lufthansa will gain a bigger share of the German market.\n\n\"All this is down to prevent Ryanair growing in Germany, but it won't stop us,\" Michael O'Leary told Reuters in a telephone interview on Wednesday.\n\nGermany has rejected Ryanair's claims.\n\nA German economy ministry spokeswoman said a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($175.5 million) the government had granted Air Berlin did not breach anti-trust rules.\n\n\"I reject the accusation by Ryanair today that it was a staged insolvency application,\" the spokeswoman said.\n\nA spokesman for Lufthansa declined to comment on the Ryanair accusations.\n\nGermany faces allegations of maintaining a cosy relationship with its domestic industry and questions about whether authorities did enough to uncover an emissions scandal at carmaker Volkswagen, which is partially state-owned.\n\nAir Berlin said it had sounded out the German states of North-Rhine Westphalia and Berlin in June to see whether they would provide loan guarantees after Etihad signalled it was rethinking its strategy of holding minority investments in smaller carriers.\n\nThe German economy ministry spokeswoman said that negotiations between Lufthansa and Air Berlin had been going on for \"months\" as executives sought a long-term solution for the airline.\n\nThe German government said it expected no anti-trust issues because Air Berlin would be sold off in bits.\n\nBut O'Leary is not convinced his airline is being given a fair chance.\n\n\"A merger will take Lufthansa from 68 percent to 95 percent of the German domestic market and from 47 percent to 60 percent control of the total German market, which would be in breach of every known competition threshold rule and guideline in Germany and the EU,\" O'Leary said.\n\nHe said Alitalia's insolvency was being done on a fairer basis, with rival airlines being invited to submit offers.\n\n\"That's the process they should be going through with Air Berlin,\" he said.\n\nWhen asked if Ryanair could bid for Air Berlin assets, he said he expected a deal would go through too quickly to give Ryanair a chance to bid and that only unattractive airport slots would be offered up.\n\n\"There's nothing to bid for, it's a ready-up,\" he said. \"We will continue to grow, we're still buying more aircraft. But we will struggle to get slots, to base more aircraft in airports like Frankfurt, Berlin, Munich.\"\n\nO'Leary said he hoped the EU authorities would step in to force competition remedies, such as giving up airport slots to rivals.\n\nThe EU Commission said it was in \"constructive contact\" with Germany. \"We are confident that solutions can be found within the framework of EU law,\" a Commission spokesman said.\n\nIzzet Sinan, partner at law firm Morgan, Lewis &amp; Bockius said it was no surprise that Ryanair had voiced its objections.\n\n\"The question is what actions will follow the words,\" Sinan said.\n\n($1 = 0.8540 euros) (Additional reporting by Foo Yun Chee in Brussels; Editing by Maria Sheahan and Jane Merriman)", "id": "9496520", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "By Victoria Bryan\n\nBERLIN (Reuters) - Ryanair sees any plans by Lufthansa to take over parts of insolvent rival Air Berlin as a \"conspiracy\" to halt the Irish carrier's expansion, its chief executive told Reuters.\n\nAir Berlin on Tuesday filed for insolvency after shareholder Etihad said it would not provide more funding, turning to the German government for a 150 million euro ($176 million) loan to keep planes in the air while it negotiates a sale of parts of its business to Lufthansa and one other airline.\n\nRyanair has already filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the insolvency process, which it describes as a \"conspiracy\" because it believes that Lufthansa will gain a bigger share of the German market.\n\n\"All this is down to prevent Ryanair growing in Germany, but it won't stop us,\" Michael O'Leary told Reuters in a telephone interview on Wednesday.\n\nGermany has rejected Ryanair's claims.\n\nA German economy ministry spokeswoman said a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($175.5 million) the government had granted Air Berlin did not breach anti-trust rules.\n\n\"I reject the accusation by Ryanair today that it was a staged insolvency application,\" the spokeswoman said.\n\nA spokesman for Lufthansa declined to comment on the Ryanair accusations.\n\nGermany faces allegations of maintaining a cosy relationship with its domestic industry and questions about whether authorities did enough to uncover an emissions scandal at carmaker Volkswagen, which is partially state-owned.\n\nAir Berlin said it had sounded out the German states of North-Rhine Westphalia and Berlin in June to see whether they would provide loan guarantees after Etihad signalled it was rethinking its strategy of holding minority investments in smaller carriers.\n\nThe German economy ministry spokeswoman said that negotiations between Lufthansa and Air Berlin had been going on for \"months\" as executives sought a long-term solution for the airline.\n\nThe German government said it expected no anti-trust issues because Air Berlin would be sold off in bits.\n\nBut O'Leary is not convinced his airline is being given a fair chance.\n\n\"A merger will take Lufthansa from 68 percent to 95 percent of the German domestic market and from 47 percent to 60 percent control of the total German market, which would be in breach of every known competition threshold rule and guideline in Germany and the EU,\" O'Leary said.\n\nHe said Alitalia's insolvency was being done on a fairer basis, with rival airlines being invited to submit offers.\n\n\"That's the process they should be going through with Air Berlin,\" he said.\n\nWhen asked if Ryanair could bid for Air Berlin assets, he said he expected a deal would go through too quickly to give Ryanair a chance to bid and that only unattractive airport slots would be offered up.\n\n\"There's nothing to bid for, it's a ready-up,\" he said. \"We will continue to grow, we're still buying more aircraft. But we will struggle to get slots, to base more aircraft in airports like Frankfurt, Berlin, Munich.\"\n\nO'Leary said he hoped the EU authorities would step in to force competition remedies, such as giving up airport slots to rivals.\n\nThe EU Commission said it was in \"constructive contact\" with Germany. \"We are confident that solutions can be found within the framework of EU law,\" a Commission spokesman said.\n\nIzzet Sinan, partner at law firm Morgan, Lewis & Bockius said it was no surprise that Ryanair had voiced its objections.\n\n\"The question is what actions will follow the words,\" Sinan said.\n\n($1 = 0.8540 euros)\n\n(Additional reporting by Foo Yun Chee in Brussels; Editing by Maria Sheahan and Jane Merriman)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc The return flights of these travelers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nThe airline, which didn't answer calls, said in a statement that after Etihad pulled funding, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin.\"\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. {"timeCrawl": "14:14:00", "uri": "710362570", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T14:14:00Z", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/ryanair-ceo-hits-out-at-air-berlin/lufthansa-deal/articleshow/60089115.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "* Ryanair CEO says Air Berlin insolvency is \"conspiracy\"\n\n* Says does not expect to get a chance to bid for slots\n\n* German government rejects Ryanair's allegations (Adds additional quotes, comment from EU Commission, lawyer)\n\nBy Victoria Bryan\n\nBERLIN, Aug 16 (Reuters) - Ryanair sees any plans by Lufthansa to take over parts of insolvent rival Air Berlin as a \"conspiracy\" to halt the Irish carrier's expansion, its chief executive told Reuters.\n\nAir Berlin on Tuesday filed for insolvency after shareholder Etihad said it would not provide more funding, turning to the German government for a 150 million euro ($176 million) loan to keep planes in the air while it negotiates a sale of parts of its business to Lufthansa and one other airline.\n\nRyanair has already filed a complaint with German and European Union competition authorities over the insolvency process, which it describes as a \"conspiracy\" because it believes that Lufthansa will gain a bigger share of the German market.\n\n\"All this is down to prevent Ryanair growing in Germany, but it won't stop us,\" Michael O'Leary told Reuters in a telephone interview on Wednesday.\n\nGermany has rejected Ryanair's claims.\n\nA German economy ministry spokeswoman said a bridging loan of 150 million euros ($175.5 million) the government had granted Air Berlin did not breach anti-trust rules.\n\n\"I reject the accusation by Ryanair today that it was a staged insolvency application,\" the spokeswoman said.\n\nA spokesman for Lufthansa declined to comment on the Ryanair accusations.\n\nGermany faces allegations of maintaining a cosy relationship with its domestic industry and questions about whether authorities did enough to uncover an emissions scandal at carmaker Volkswagen, which is partially state-owned.\n\nAir Berlin said it had sounded out the German states of North-Rhine Westphalia and Berlin in June to see whether they would provide loan guarantees after Etihad signalled it was rethinking its strategy of holding minority investments in smaller carriers.\n\nThe German economy ministry spokeswoman said that negotiations between Lufthansa and Air Berlin had been going on for \"months\" as executives sought a long-term solution for the airline.\n\nThe German government said it expected no anti-trust issues because Air Berlin would be sold off in bits.\n\nBut O'Leary is not convinced his airline is being given a fair chance.\n\n\"A merger will take Lufthansa from 68 percent to 95 percent of the German domestic market and from 47 percent to 60 percent control of the total German market, which would be in breach of every known competition threshold rule and guideline in Germany and the EU,\" O'Leary said.\n\nHe said Alitalia's insolvency was being done on a fairer basis, with rival airlines being invited to submit offers.\n\n\"That's the process they should be going through with Air Berlin,\" he said.\n\nWhen asked if Ryanair could bid for Air Berlin assets, he said he expected a deal would go through too quickly to give Ryanair a chance to bid and that only unattractive airport slots would be offered up.\n\n\"There's nothing to bid for, it's a ready-up,\" he said. \"We will continue to grow, we're still buying more aircraft. But we will struggle to get slots, to base more aircraft in airports like Frankfurt, Berlin, Munich.\"\n\nO'Leary said he hoped the EU authorities would step in to force competition remedies, such as giving up airport slots to rivals.\n\nThe EU Commission said it was in \"constructive contact\" with Germany. \"We are confident that solutions can be found within the framework of EU law,\" a Commission spokesman said.\n\nIzzet Sinan, partner at law firm Morgan, Lewis & Bockius said it was no surprise that Ryanair had voiced its objections.\n\n\"The question is what actions will follow the words,\" Sinan said.\n\n($1 = 0.8540 euros) (Additional reporting by Foo Yun Chee in Brussels; Editing by Maria Sheahan and Jane Merriman)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with operations hub.\n\nHe did not name the other two airlines, but EasyJet has long been eyeing Air Berlin and German media have speculated that Thomas Cook subsidiary Condor is the third party.\n\nAir Berlin was forced to file for insolvency on Tuesday after main shareholder Etihad suddenly ended its financial support for the loss-making airline.\n\nThe government stepped in with a 150-million-euro ($170-million) bridging loan to keep Germany's second-largest airline flying for the next three months, saying it did not want to leave tens of thousands of holidaymakers stranded.\n\nWinkelmann said The airline had been running at a loss for several years, prompting owner Etihad to pull the plug on Tuesday.\n\nAir Berlin is particularly strong at Zurich airport, operating 11 daily flights to destinations such as Berlin and D\u00fcsseldorf. It is second only to Swiss International Air Lines in terms of passengers transported from Zurich airport.\n\nA \u20ac150 million (CHF170 million) emergency credit line from the German government will keep Air Berlin flying until the end of August, but the long-term future of the carrier will probably boil down to a takeover from a rival.\n\nIt has been reported that Lufthansa, the owner of Swiss, is in talks to take over Air Berlin. It has also been speculated that budget airlines EasyJet or Ryanair could join the bidding.\n\nIf there is a future takeover, the new owner will have to take a hard look at a business model that has seen continuous losses since 2008. Last year, Air Berlin booked a \u20ac782 million annual loss. Even Etihad, based in the oil-rich Abu Dhabi, has decided it can no longer support the continuous haemorrhage.\n\nThe Swiss newspaper Tages-Anzeiger sees only one result of Lufthansa buying up Air Berlin: more expensive tickets for passengers. \"At first glance from the passengers point of view, the development [Air Berlin's near collapse] is not so good,\" the newspaper said in an editorial on Wednesday. \"They must reckon with higher prices.\"\n\nAnother option being touted for Air Berlin in the media is the sale of some airline slots. Traffic from Zurich to Germany is especially valuable. A spokesperson for Swiss told the Tages-Anzeiger that it was in principle always looking for opportunities to add new slots, regardless of their current owner.\n\nShould that happen, competition to many German destinations would shrink.\n\nIn the meantime, Swiss tour operators are refusing to panic. Hotelplan Suisse and Kuoni said that all tickets already purchased remain valid. {"timeCrawl": "11:44:00", "uri": "711417483", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T11:44:00Z", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4802430/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "BERLIN, Aug 18 (Reuters) - The German government is not involved in talks on the sale of insolvent German airline Air Berlin's assets, an Economy Ministry spokesman said on Friday, adding there was no deadline for any deal to be sealed.\n\nThe comments were made after Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt called for market leader Lufthansa to buy a major part of the assets of Air Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, saying Germany needed a \"national champion\" in international aviation.\n\n\"The companies are negotiating now. The government is not sitting at the table there and is also not steering this,\" Economy Ministry spokesman Korbinian Wagner said during a regular government news conference in Berlin.\n\nThe German government does not have a preferred outcome for the Air Berlin negotiations and it is now up to the companies involved to find a solution, the spokesman added.\n\nThe Economy Ministry spokesman said no time frame had been set for the government's bridging loan of 150 million euros ($176 million) to Air Berlin. He said the aim was for the sum to be sufficient to find a sustainable and sensible solution.\n\nThe government granted the loan to allow Air Berlin to keep its planes in the air for three months and secure the jobs of 7,200 workers in Germany while negotiations continued.\n\nEconomy Minister Brigitte Zypries had made clear that more than one airline needed to come forward for Air Berlin for competition reasons, the Economy Ministry spokesman said.\n\n($1 = 0.8515 euros) (Reporting by Michael Nienaber; Editing by Michelle Martin and Edmund Blair)", "id": "9884300", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "15:45:00", "uri": "710973024", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T15:12:00Z", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "source": {"title": "Deutsche Welle (English)", "uri": "dw.com", "id": "430"}, "url": "http://www.dw.com/en/air-berlin-insolvency-to-hit-staff-and-clients/a-40138364", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Air Berlin's filing for insolvency after Etihad withdrew its financial support has created an uncertain future. Staff and clients, including Berlin's Brandenburg airport, face an anxious few months.\n\nOnly a federal government loan of 150 million euros ($175.4 million) saved Air Berlin and its daughter company Niki from the embarrassment of having to cease flights with immediate effect.\n\nThe bridging loan should ease some of the immediate pressure on the company, which was once Germany's second biggest airline after Lufthansa but has run into serious financial difficulties in the ten years since it became a public company.\n\nWith Etihad no longer willing to prop up the beleaguered carrier, Air Berlin looks set to be dismantled and divided by Lufthansa, EasyJet or Ryanair, although the latter's CEO Michael O'Leary has claimed the deal is \"corrupt\" as any Lufthansa takeover would create a monopoly.\n\nRelocation to Frankfurt\n\nAir Berlin's pilots and crew seem likely to have the best chance of avoiding redundancy, with the impending takeover likely to incorporate the majority of current cabin crew.\n\nIf Lufthansa takes Air Berlin under its wing, routes are likely to transfer to the company's low-flying subsidiary Eurowings. Such a move would protect many jobs.\n\nHowever, Air Berlin's demise could mean a more uncertain future for the 1,200 employees at the Berlin headquarters and the 700 employees working at the Berlin technology subsidiary.\n\nThe boss of Germany's services trade union Verdi, Christine Behle, is concerned for the futures of these employees. \"Every possible buyer already has an administration,\" she said, adding that this would also apply to the airline's technology. After the application for insolvency, an initial discussion between the union and the management will be held on Friday. \"We want to help shape it,\" Behle announced.\n\nHowever, cabin crew will not be immune from the negative effects of a Lufthansa takeover. Lufthansa's Frankfurt base raises the possibility of an enforced relocation for staff from Berlin. The worst case scenario is that even long-serving flight attendants would be forced to reapply for their jobs, possibly receiving only the starting salary.\n\n\"This would result in up to 40 percent wage loss for some flight attendants,\" explains Christine Behle. In negotiations with Lufthansa, Verdi and cabin crew trade union UFO want to ensure that the years of employment of Air Berlin employees are recognized.\n\nFurther blow to Berlin-Brandenburg Airport\n\nAs if Berlin's projected and protracted airport, Berlin-Brandenburg or BER, wasn't mired in enough trouble, the news of Air Berlin's emergency landing comes as yet another blow to the airport.\n\nAir Berlin is the most important customer for the airport company Berlin-Brandenburg (FBB). Almost 30 percent of the flights handled in Berlin bear the airline's red and white logo, and the airline had plans to turn BER into its hub, but had to drop these plans.\n\nThere is still a special terminal area for Air Berlin at BER with nine passenger bridges, the so-called \"S\u00fcdpier\". An Air Berlin lounge with 200 seats has been waiting empty for guests for years.\n\nAs yet, Lufthansa and Easyjet have shown no interest in creating a hub at BER and the share of passengers who change at BER is likely to be smaller if no other airline wants to establish a hub there. And that is a problem for the FBB, because every second euro at BER is to be generated by the shopping malls and catering offers in the terminals. Passengers booking direct flights, however, consume significantly less at the airport than passengers who have time to walk through the terminal.", "id": "9724697", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "16:01:00", "uri": "710415497", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T16:01:00Z", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/sale-of-air-berlin-slots-offers-rare-german-entry-ticket/articleshow/60090187.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "* Air Berlin administrators focus on selling slots\n\n* Ryanair CEO doubts whether new entrants welcome\n\n* Industrial heartland makes Duesseldorf slots appeal\n\n* easyJet, Condor express interest in Air Berlin assets\n\nBy Victoria Bryan and Alexander Hubner\n\nBERLIN/FRANKFURT, Aug 16 (Reuters) - Air Berlin's administrators will focus on selling its attractive take-off and landing slots in Germany, a source familiar with the process said, potentially opening up the market to new players.\n\nLoss-making Air Berlin has until now helped to shield Lufthansa and Germany, where a booming economy is fuelling demand for travel, from low-cost carriers.\n\nBut the fight is now on for German passengers after Air Berlin filed for insolvency on Tuesday, with Lufthansa seeking to shore up its own position against budget rivals Ryanair and easyJet.\n\nSome doubt that the German government will allow the demise of the country's second largest carrier to change the balance of power, highlighting Berlin's willingness to give Air Berlin a loan to keep planes in the air while it negotiates the sale of parts of its business after shareholder Etihad said it would not provide any more funding.\n\nRyanair's outspoken chief executive Michael O'Leary told Reuters he sees in the Air Berlin insolvency process a further attempt to block it out of Germany.\n\n\"When Malev went bust, everybody stepped in. But there's no gap to step into here because they're going to keep the airline flying,\" O'Leary said, referring to the failure of Hungarian airline Malev in 2012.\n\nOverall, low-cost carriers account for only 33 percent of flights from Germany, against a market share of around 42 percent in Europe as a whole and 61 percent in Britain, according to data from Flightglobal Schedules data.\n\nWhile Air Berlin is small internationally, it has 27 percent of the market for German domestic flights, while Lufthansa has 68 percent.\n\nThe opportunity offered by Air Berlin's demise has already sparked interest from Britain's easyJet, which is in talks with the German government over its assets, a source has said.\n\n\"Lufthansa and easyJet would be a good fit,\" said the first source of the slots on offer.\n\nMeanwhile, Thomas Cook's German airline Condor said on Wednesday it was ready to play \"an active role\".\n\nINDUSTRIAL PRIZE\n\nAmong Air Berlin's potentially most attractive assets include its presence in Germany's industrial heartland of North Rhine Westphalia, where it has around a third of the slots at Duesseldorf airport.\n\n\"(Duesseldorf) is particularly important as it is a heavily slot-constrained airport for environmental reasons and is at the heart of the German economy providing potentially more lucrative business traffic for Lufthansa,\" aviation consultant John Strickland said.\n\nWhile Lufthansa has long been interested in taking over more of Air Berlin's operations and the insolvency means it stands a better chance of being able to pick up parts of the business without taking on Air Berlin's debt, it may still fall foul of competition rules.\n\n\"It could be difficult for Lufthansa to acquire all of Air Berlin's slots, especially as Lufthansa is very strong in Germany,\" Jens-Olrik Murach, a partner at Brussels-based law firm Gibson Dunn, said.\n\nLiberum analyst Gerald Khoo also said Lufthansa would have to be careful to avoid increasing its costs, whether through securing aircraft that Air Berlin already flies on behalf of Lufthansa, or through taking on further assets.\n\nHe said that Lufthansa's position in Germany may be secure for a while yet as Ryanair and easyJet may not be able to re-deploy capacity to Germany this winter.\n\n\"However, we would expect German airports to move up the list of priorities for next summer for both major low-cost carriers, whether or not they attempt to pick up assets and/or staff from Air Berlin's bankruptcy process,\" he said in a note. {"timeCrawl": "14:39:00", "uri": "710374003", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T14:39:00Z", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "source": {"title": "Zawya", "uri": "zawya.com", "id": "3109"}, "url": "http://www.zawya.com/mena/en/story/Etihad_Airways_partners_bonds_drop_again_as_Air_Berlin_bankruptcy_sparks_bailout_concerns-TR20170816nL8N1L2393X2/", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "A billboard of carriers Air Berlin (L) and Etihad Airways is seen at Tegel Airport in Berlin December 18, 2012. Image for illustrative purpose.\n\nBy Davide Barbuscia\n\nDUBAI, Aug 16 (Reuters) - Etihad Airways' bonds issued through a special purpose vehicle have dropped more than five points in the secondary market a day after Air Berlin, in which Etihad has a large minority stake, filed for bankruptcy protection.\n\nIn April, the \"EA Partners\" bonds dropped by almost 10 cents on the dollar after workers at the Italian carrier Alitalia - in which Etihad has a 49 percent stake - rejected the company's latest turnaround plan, blocking it from accessing rescue financing.\n\nAn \"internal debt assumption\" agreement between Etihad and Alitalia - revealed through a Fitch note in the days following Alitalia entering special administration, but had been signed earlier - put a floor under the bonds, and they subsequently bounced back almost to par value.\n\nBut it is unclear if a similar agreement is in place for Air Berlin , and some of EA Partners' creditors fear that after years of losses supporting the German carrier, Etihad might not cover the carrier's portion of debt in the SPV bonds.\n\nAdvertisement Etihad and Air Berlin declined to comment.\n\n\"Air Berlin adds to what has been a steady stream of bad news - whether related to Alitalia or Etihad itself,\" said a Dubai-based portfolio manager, speaking on condition of anonymity because of commercial sensitivities.\n\nEtihad's is undertaking a strategic review which began last year and saw it offload its minority stake in a regional European carrier in July before announcing on Tuesday it was no longer willing to prop up Air Berlin.\n\n\"The added problems don't necessarily mean help isn't still on the way for the bond, but it does it make it more complicated. The bond's credit enhancement has limits, and so does the appetite for bailouts,\" the portfolio manager said.\n\nYields on the notes - a $700 million bond maturing in 2020 and a $500 million bond maturing in 2021 - jumped by more than 2 percentage points after Air Berlin's bankruptcy announcement. The 2021 had a bid yield of 11.5 percent on Wednesday, up from 9.1 percent before the announcement. The 2020 notes were quoted at 12.3 percent on Wednesday, from 9.4 percent on Monday.\n\nThe EAP bonds include Etihad and several other airlines partially-owned by the Abu Dhabi carrier. The bond proceeds were used to enter into separate debt obligations with the entities involved, which included Etihad Airways, Etihad Airport Services, Alitalia, Air Berlin, and other airlines such as Air Serbia and Air Seychelles.\n\nThe bond had no cross-default provision, and according to their structure none of the SPV partners is legally obliged to support other partners in the event of a default. However, the paper is generally perceived as Etihad's credit, to the point that traders and portfolio managers have assumed in the past that reputational considerations could push the Abu Dhabi-owned company to bail out other SPV members, should the need arise.\n\nAccording to Air Berlin's 2016 annual report published in April, Etihad confirmed by letter its intention to provide the necessary support to Air Berlin to enable it to meet its financial obligations for a period of 18 months from April 28.\n\nHowever, it is not clear to what extent the letter is binding, and whether creditors can rely on it. The bonds are due beyond the 18 month period indicated in the letter, said an investment analyst at a hedge fund in London.\n\nAn independent auditor in the same report said: \"The group is reliant on a letter of support from a significant shareholder; as with such letters there remains a doubt whether this can be enforced in the event that such a need arises.\"\n\nIn the absence of some official announcement from the companies involved, the bonds are likely to drift, said the analyst. \"Now that Etihad has given up on Air Berlin, they could distance themselves from the debt assumption agreement with Alitalia too,\" he added.\n\n(Additional reporting by Alexander Cornwell in Dubai and Victoria Bryan in Berlin, editing by David Evans) ((Davide.Barbuscia@thomsonreuters.com;))", "id": {"timeCrawl": "01:27:00", "uri": "710056154", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T01:27:00Z", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "source": {"title": "Handelsblatt Global Edition", "uri": "global.handelsblatt.com", "id": "17733"}, "url": "https://global.handelsblatt.com/companies-markets/air-berlins-swashbuckling-american-roots-812853", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Despite its German-sounding name, Air Berlin was the brainchild of two Americans who wanted to fly Germans to the sun.\n\nDespite its German sounding name, Air Berlin was the brainchild of a couple of young American entrepreneurs who saw an opportunity to make money from an unlikely combination of Russian stubbornness and German vacationers' love of the sun.\n\nOne of them, Kim Lundgren, was a pilot who had been left high and dry in Berlin when he was furloughed by Pan American World Airways. The other, John P. MacDonald, had run a charter airline in West Berlin called Modern Air, which collapsed after the 1973 oil embargo sent airlines' expenses through the roof.\n\nThe two saw a unique opportunity: the Potsdam agreement in 1945 gave the allied powers of Britain, France and the United States just three small air corridors into Berlin, which was under the control of the Soviets. The only planes allowed to fly in these corridors were airlines of the three Western allies, not German airlines. Long after the war, a joint American-Soviet air control center in Berlin enforced this limitation.\n\n\"Merging companies with different DNA doesn't work well, especially in the airline business\"\n\nThe airline, which filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday, was conceived as a European short-haul airline much like Ryanair and Easyjet are today. But the entry of the Middle East's Etihad airways into the company's ownership ranks five years ago changed the airline's trajectory into a short haul/long haul hybrid that had no real strategy, said Shane Lundgren, the son of the founder, who was also one of the airline's pilots for 15 years.\n\n\"Merging companies with different DNA doesn't work well, especially in the airline business,\" the younger Mr. Lundgren, who now lives in Oregon, said in an interview with Handelsblatt Global.\n\nBut in 1979, when he was furloughed waiting for an opening as a Pan Am pilot, the elder Mr. Lundgren saw that West Berlin was prospering despite being surrounded by Russian troops and people there craved holidays in the sun far away from the barbed wire of the Berlin Wall.\n\nUsing aircraft that had been part of Modern Air's fleet, the team began assembling pilots and crew, mostly from Modern Air, which had been based in New York. Because only a US-based airline could fly to Berlin, they created Air Berlin as a charter company based in Mr. Lundgren's home state of Oregon.\n\nIn fact, the airline literally got off the ground in secret because the four powers had not approved its use of the air corridors. When the first Air Berlin plane flew into Berlin's Tegel Airport, it was quickly moved to a remote corner of the tarmac, where workers painted USA on the side of the plane.\n\nThe airline's first flight was on April 28, 1979 to Palma de Mallorca, a favorite destination of winter-weary Germans. It expanded to long haul flights to the US and European cities, but nearly went under when Mr. MacDonald decided to challenge Pan Am's monopoly on the Berlin-Frankfurt route. By 1986, Mr. MacDonald and the two German directors who ran the airline had departed and Mr. Lundgren took over management himself.\n\nThe airline went through another transformation when the Berlin Wall fell, taking with it the monopoly limitation on flights to Berlin. The airline switched to being a German company, Air Berlin GmbH & Co. Luftverkehrs KG, in what the younger Lundgren called \"the first time in history that an airline has switched nationality.\"\n\nHis father formed a partnership with Joachim Hunold, a former rock'n'roll roadie who had once worked as a baggage handler in D\u00fcsseldorf but had become an executive at a German charter airline. Mr Hunold bought 82.5% of Air Berlin's shares.\n\nThe airline grew to more than 140 jets in the next 20 years as Mr. Hunold went on a buying spree, acquiring its rivals, LTU, the former Deutsche British Airways, Niki airways and Belair.\n\n\"It didn't help that there was a financial collapse in 2008 after Air Berlin had its IPO and acquired all these other airlines,\" Shane Lundgren said.\n\nHe added that he and his father both advised Etihad, which had acquired a one-third interest in the airline in 2011, to stick with the airline's development as a European carrier. But he said that Etihad was more interested in Air Berlin's long haul routes based in D\u00fcsseldorf and didn't bring a cohesive strategy to running the airline.\n\n\"They never took the time to deal with the nuts and bolts of making a success of Air Berlin,\" he said.\n\nShane said that his father, now 75 and still in good health, splits his time between Oregon and London.\n\n\"We were very saddened to hear the news about the bankruptcy,\" he said. \"We still have a lot of friends at the airline and hope they will continue to be well treated.\" He added that it was unusual for an airline to enter insolvency proceedings in the summer, which is the height of its business year, so things must have reached a crisis point with Etihad's financial support.", "id": "9385591", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Air Berlin's Swashbuckling American Roots", "image": "https://global.handelsblatt.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Lundbergtease-e1502826826248.jpg", "extractedDates": {"timeCrawl": "16:34:00", "uri": "710997809", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T16:34:00Z", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "source": {"title": "Handelsblatt Global Edition", "uri": "global.handelsblatt.com", "id": "17733"}, "url": "https://global.handelsblatt.com/opinion/a-good-time-to-go-814037", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Air Berlin's bankruptcy was unavoidable, but the timing was carefully chosen to leverage maximum benefit for potential buyer Lufthansa, writes Jens Koenen.\n\nThe choice of words was strong, as is always the case with the Irish budget airline Ryanair. It said Air Berlin's bankruptcy on Tuesday was \"artificially induced,\" implying that there was a conspiracy to enable Germany's national flag carrier Lufthansa to take over its rival.\n\nAngela Merkel's government has stepped in with a \u20ac150 million taxpayer-funded bridging loan to shore up Germany's second largest airline while its affairs are sorted out. In line with its strong words, Ryanair - a rival to both Air Berlin and Lufthansa in the German market - filed a complaint with European Union competition authorities against the bailout.\n\nIt seems unlikely that it will succeed, because it is clear that the Air Berlin insolvency is anything but artificially induced. In fact, it was overdue. The airline has been burdened by negative equity and overwhelming debt for years. Any other business would have filed for bankruptcy long ago. The carrier was only able to continue operating because major shareholder Etihad, the national airline of the United Arab Emirates, kept injecting more and more of the liquidity necessary to avoid insolvency. "arabnews.com", "id": "4355"}, "url": "http://www.arabnews.com/node/1146031/business-economy", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "DUBAI: Etihad Airways' bonds issued through a special purpose vehicle have dropped more than five points in the secondary mar- ket a day after Air Berlin, in which Etihad has a large minority stake, filed for bankruptcy protection.\n\nIn April, the \"EA Partners\" bonds dropped by almost 10 cents on the dollar after workers at the Italian carrier Alitalia -- in which Etihad has a 49 percent stake -- rejected the company's latest turn- around plan, blocking it from accessing rescue financing.\n\nAn \"internal debt assumption\" agreement between Etihad and Alitalia -- revealed through a Fitch note in the days following Alitalia entering special adminis-\n\ntration, but had been signed ear- lier -- put a floor under the bonds, and they subsequently bounced back almost to par value.\n\nBut it is unclear if a similar agreement is in place for Air Berlin, and some of EA Partners' creditors fear that after years of losses supporting the German car- rier, Etihad might not cover the carrier's portion of debt in the SPV bonds.\n\nEtihad and Air Berlin declined to comment.\n\n\"Air Berlin adds to what has been a steady stream of bad news -- whether related to Alitalia or Etihad itself,\" said a Dubai-based portfolio manager, speaking on condition of anonymity because of\n\ncommercial sensitivities.\n\nEtihad is undertaking a strate-\n\ngic review which began last year and saw it offload its minority stake in a regional European car- rier in July before announcing on Tuesday it was no longer willing to prop up Air Berlin.\n\n\"The added problems don't nec- essarily mean help isn't still on the way for the bond, but it does it make it more complicated. The bond's credit enhancement has limits, and so does the appetite for bailouts,\" the portfolio manager said.\n\nYields on the notes -- a $700 million bond maturing in 2020 and a $500 million bond matur- ing in 2021 -- jumped by more\n\nthan 2 percentage points after Air Berlin's bankruptcy announce- ment. The 2021 had a bid yield of 11.5 percent on Wednesday, up from 9.1 percent before the announcement. The 2020 notes were quoted at 12.3 percent on Wednesday, from 9.4 percent on Monday.\n\nThe EAP bonds include Etihad and several other airlines partial- ly-owned by the Abu Dhabi carrier. The bond proceeds were used to enter into separate debt obliga- tions with the entities involved, which included Etihad Airways, Etihad Airport Services, Alitalia, Air Berlin, and other airlines such as Air Serbia and Air Seychelles.\n\nThe bond had no cross-default\n\nAir Berlin recently led for bankruptcy protection. (Reuters)\n\nprovision, and according to their structure none of the SPV partners is legally obliged to support other partners in the event of a default. However, the paper is generally perceived as Etihad's credit, to the point that traders and portfolio managers have assumed in the past that reputational consider- ations could push the Abu Dhabi- owned company to bail out other SPV members, should the need arise.\n\nAccording to Air Berlin's 2016 annual report published in April, Etihad confirmed by letter its intention to provide the necessary support to Air Berlin to enable it to meet its financial obligations for a period of 18 months from April 28.\n\nHowever, it is not clear to what extent the letter is binding, and whether creditors can rely on it. The bonds are due beyond the 18-month period indicated in the letter, said an investment analyst at a hedge fund in London.\n\nAn independent auditor in the same report said: \"The group is reliant on a letter of support from a significant shareholder; as with such letters there remains a doubt whether this can be enforced in the event that such a need arises.\"\n\nIn the absence of some official announcement from the compa- nies involved, the bonds are likely to drift, said the analyst. \"Now that Etihad has given up on Air Berlin, they could distance themselves from the debt assumption {"timeCrawl": "15:42:00", "uri": "710405646", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T15:42:00Z", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4796372/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "By Victoria Bryan and Alexander H\u00fcbner\n\nBERLIN/FRANKFURT, Aug 16 (Reuters) - Air Berlin's administrators will focus on selling its attractive take-off and landing slots in Germany, a source familiar with the process said, potentially opening up the market to new players.\n\nLoss-making Air Berlin has until now helped to shield Lufthansa and Germany, where a booming economy is fuelling demand for travel, from low-cost carriers.\n\nBut the fight is now on for German passengers after Air Berlin filed for insolvency on Tuesday, with Lufthansa seeking to shore up its own position against budget rivals Ryanair and easyJet.\n\nSome doubt that the German government will allow the demise of the country's second largest carrier to change the balance of power, highlighting Berlin's willingness to give Air Berlin a loan to keep planes in the air while it negotiates the sale of parts of its business after shareholder Etihad said it would not provide any more funding.\n\nRyanair's outspoken chief executive Michael O'Leary told Reuters he sees in the Air Berlin insolvency process a further attempt to block it out of Germany.\n\n\"When Malev went bust, everybody stepped in. But there's no gap to step into here because they're going to keep the airline flying,\" O'Leary said, referring to the failure of Hungarian airline Malev in 2012.\n\nOverall, low-cost carriers account for only 33 percent of flights from Germany, against a market share of around 42 percent in Europe as a whole and 61 percent in Britain, according to data from Flightglobal Schedules data.\n\nWhile Air Berlin is small internationally, it has 27 percent of the market for German domestic flights, while Lufthansa has 68 percent.\n\nThe opportunity offered by Air Berlin's demise has already sparked interest from Britain's easyJet, which is in talks with the German government over its assets, a source has said.\n\n\"Lufthansa and easyJet would be a good fit,\" said the first source of the slots on offer.\n\nMeanwhile, Thomas Cook's German airline Condor said on Wednesday it was ready to play \"an active role\".\n\nINDUSTRIAL PRIZE\n\nAmong Air Berlin's potentially most attractive assets include its presence in Germany's industrial heartland of North Rhine Westphalia, where it has around a third of the slots at Duesseldorf airport.\n\n\"(Duesseldorf) is particularly important as it is a heavily slot-constrained airport for environmental reasons and is at the heart of the German economy providing potentially more lucrative business traffic for Lufthansa,\" aviation consultant John Strickland said.\n\nWhile Lufthansa has long been interested in taking over more of Air Berlin's operations and the insolvency means it stands a better chance of being able to pick up parts of the business without taking on Air Berlin's debt, it may still fall foul of competition rules.\n\n\"It could be difficult for Lufthansa to acquire all of Air Berlin's slots, especially as Lufthansa is very strong in Germany,\" Jens-Olrik Murach, a partner at Brussels-based law firm Gibson Dunn, said.\n\nLiberum analyst Gerald Khoo also said Lufthansa would have to be careful to avoid increasing its costs, whether through securing aircraft that Air Berlin already flies on behalf of Lufthansa, or through taking on further assets.\n\nHe said that Lufthansa's position in Germany may be secure for a while yet as Ryanair and easyJet may not be able to re-deploy capacity to Germany this winter.\n\n\"However, we would expect German airports to move up the list of priorities for next summer for both major low-cost carriers, whether or not they attempt to pick up assets and/or staff from Air Berlin's bankruptcy process,\" he said in a note. {"timeCrawl": "05:52:00", "uri": "710129645", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T05:52:00Z", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "source": {"title": "International Business Times UK", "uri": "ibtimes.co.uk", "id": "713"}, "url": "http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/ryanair-files-eu-complaint-over-lufthansas-takeover-air-berlin-1635189", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Budget carrier claims 'conspiracy' to give German flag carrier a 'debt-free' carve-up of struggling rival.\n\nLeading budget carrier Ryanair has filed competition complaints with the German competition regulator Bundeskartellamt and the European Commission regarding the \"obvious conspiracy\" playing out in Germany between the country's government and flag carrier Lufthansa to carve up struggling Air Berlin's assets.\n\nOn Tuesday (15 August) Air Berlin filed for insolvency after its main shareholder - Abu Dhabi's Etihad Airways - withdrew its financial support. Ryanair claims the subsequent rescue bid excludes major competitors and ignoring both EU competition and State Aid rules\n\nOvernight, a spokesperson for Air Berlin told IB Times UK its flights were continuing to \"operate as normal\" as the German government has stepped in to provide a temporary bridging loan to support daily operations for three months thought to be around \u20ac150m (\u00a3137m).\n\nIt also emerged that Air Berlin is in advanced talks with rival Lufthansa for the sale of some aspects of its business as it already leases aircraft to the German flag carrier.\n\nHowever, in a statement Ryanair noted: \"Given the fact that the German Government is centrally involved in these manoeuvres, the Bundeskartellamt is likely to struggle to get out of bed. On this basis, and bearing in mind the scale of the market shares and the European implications involved, it is all the more important that the European Commission takes immediate and decisive action.\"\n\nIt alleged that the \"manufactured\" insolvency is being set up to allow Lufthansa to take over a debt-free Air Berlin, which will be in breach of \"all known German and EU competition rules.\"\n\nRyanair said measures taken by the German government effectively amount to state aid courtesy which \"Lufthansa can acquire Air Berlin and drive domestic air fares in Germany even higher than they already are. Meanwhile, Ryanair, its Irish rival, accused conspiracy in the deal and said that the acquisition move will breach the existing competition rules in Germany in general and EU in particular.\n\nAir Berlin had to choose the bankruptcy route as its businesses deteriorated in a fast pace. The airline's financial supporter and minority shareholder Etithad of Abu Dhabi has stopped its funding as Germany's second largest airline failed to record profits. Air Berlin has recorded loss of 782 million euros last year.\n\nThe German Federal Government has offered a bridge loan, secured by a federal guarantee, to maintain flight operations. The airline has been carrying around 80 thousand passengers on a daily basis. The funding to the tune of 150 million euros from the government will help continue the services.\n\nThe filing at the local district court of Berlin-Charlottenburg is a petition for the opening of debtor-in-possession insolvency proceedings. {"timeCrawl": "12:51:00", "uri": "710319493", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T12:51:00Z", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "source": {"title": "Reuters", "uri": "reuters.com", "id": "8"}, "url": "https://www.reuters.com/article/us-air-berlin-lufthansa-idUSKCN1AW1CE", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "FRANKFURT (Reuters) - Air Berlin's (AB1.DE) chief executive blamed long delays in the opening of a new Berlin airport for the German airline's insolvency in an interview published by Germany's Die Zeit.\n\n\"Air Berlin is also a victim of the constant postponements of the new airport,\" the weekly newspaper on Wednesday quoted Thomas Winkelmann as saying.\n\nWinkelmann's comments came a day after Air Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection after key shareholder Etihad Airways withdrew funding following years of losses.\n\nThe German capital's new airport was meant to open in 2011, replacing Air Berlin's home airport Tegel and Schoenefeld.\n\n\"We have Berlin in our name, are the prime carrier here and have designed our whole concept based on transfer traffic at this new airport. That is not possible at Tegel, my predecessors made that painful experience,\" he added.\n\nSeveral opening dates for the planned new airport have been postponed as the project faced red tape and technical problems with smoke ventilation systems, cabling and doors.\n\nWinkelmann told Die Zeit that he believed he could save most of the Air Berlin jobs through a restructuring.\n\nThe German {"timeCrawl": "10:30:00", "uri": "710821353", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:30:00Z", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "source": {"title": "Agence France Presse (AFP)", "uri": "afp.com", "id": "2391"}, "url": "https://www.afp.com/en/news/2266/three-airlines-interested-air-berlin-assets-ceo", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "He did not name the other two airlines, but EasyJet has long been eyeing Air Berlin and German media have speculated that Thomas Cook subsidiary Condor is the third party.\n\nAir Berlin was forced to file for insolvency on Tuesday after main shareholder Etihad suddenly ended its financial support for the loss-making airline.\n\nThe government stepped in with a 150-million-euro ($170-million) bridging loan to keep Germany's second-largest airline flying for the next three months, saying it did not want to leave tens of thousands of holidaymakers stranded.\n\nWinkelmann said he aimed to strike a deal with at least two of the interested buyers by the end of September, with Air Berlin's landing rights considered particularly valuable and the fate of Austrian subsidiary Niki also under discussion.\n\n\"But we won't be able to save all jobs,\" the newspaper quoted Winkelmann as telling employees in staff meetings.\n\nThe airline, sometimes dubbed the \"Mallorca shuttle\" for its popularity with German tourists headed for Spanish beaches, employs some 8,000 people.\n\nIt has long battled for survival, booking losses amounting to 1.2 billion euros over the past two years and relying on cash infusions from Etihad.\n\n- 'Conspiracy' -\n\nBut the government's intervention, just weeks before a September 24 general election, to keep Air Berlin flying for now has come in for criticism.\n\nLow-cost rival Ryanair has lodged complaints with German and European competition regulators, slamming what it called a \"conspiracy\" between the government, Lufthansa and Air Berlin to carve up the insolvent carrier's assets.\n\nForeign Minister Sigmar Gabriel defended the move, saying the financial lifeline was needed to prevent 80,000 travellers a day from being stranded during the busy holiday period.\n\nBut a government official told the Handelsblatt financial daily the state aid was a clear example of electioneering.\n\n\"Eighty thousand stranded holidaymakers are almost 80,000 voters. {"timeCrawl": "14:15:00", "uri": "710362594", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T14:15:00Z", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/etihad-partners-bonds-drop-again-as-air-berlin-bankruptcy-sparks-bailout-concerns/articleshow/60088846.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "(Removes erroneous product code)\n\nBy Davide Barbuscia\n\nDUBAI, Aug 16 (Reuters) - Etihad Airways' bonds issued through a special purpose vehicle have dropped more than five points in the secondary market a day after Air Berlin, in which Etihad has a large minority stake, filed for bankruptcy protection.\n\nIn April, the \"EA Partners\" bonds dropped by almost 10 cents on the dollar after workers at the Italian carrier Alitalia - in which Etihad has a 49 percent stake - rejected the company's latest turnaround plan, blocking it from accessing rescue financing.\n\nAn \"internal debt assumption\" agreement between Etihad and Alitalia - revealed through a Fitch note in the days following Alitalia entering special administration, but had been signed earlier - put a floor under the bonds, and they subsequently bounced back almost to par value.\n\nBut it is unclear if a similar agreement is in place for Air Berlin, and some of EA Partners' creditors fear that after years of losses supporting the German carrier, Etihad might not cover the carrier's portion of debt in the SPV bonds.\n\nEtihad and Air Berlin declined to comment.\n\n\"Air Berlin adds to what has been a steady stream of bad news - whether related to Alitalia or Etihad itself,\" said a Dubai-based portfolio manager, speaking on condition of anonymity because of commercial sensitivities.\n\nEtihad's is undertaking a strategic review which began last year and saw it offload its minority stake in a regional European carrier in July before announcing on Tuesday it was no longer willing to prop up Air Berlin.\n\n\"The added problems don't necessarily mean help isn't still on the way for the bond, but it does it make it more complicated. The bond's credit enhancement has limits, and so does the appetite for bailouts,\" the portfolio manager said.\n\nYields on the notes - a $700 million bond maturing in 2020 and a $500 million bond maturing in 2021 - jumped by more than 2 percentage points after Air Berlin's bankruptcy announcement. The 2021 had a bid yield of 11.5 percent on Wednesday, up from 9.1 percent before the announcement. The 2020 notes were quoted at 12.3 percent on Wednesday, from 9.4 percent on Monday.\n\nThe EAP bonds include Etihad and several other airlines partially-owned by the Abu Dhabi carrier. The bond proceeds were used to enter into separate debt obligations with the entities involved, which included Etihad Airways, Etihad Airport Services, Alitalia, Air Berlin, and other airlines such as Air Serbia and Air Seychelles.\n\nThe bond had no cross-default provision, and according to their structure none of the SPV partners is legally obliged to support other partners in the event of a default. However, the paper is generally perceived as Etihad's credit, to the point that traders and portfolio managers have assumed in the past that reputational considerations could push the Abu Dhabi-owned company to bail out other SPV members, should the need arise.\n\nAccording to Air Berlin's 2016 annual report published in April, Etihad confirmed by letter its intention to provide the necessary support to Air Berlin to enable it to meet its financial obligations for a period of 18 months from April 28.\n\nHowever, it is not clear to what extent the letter is binding, and whether creditors can rely on it. The bonds are due beyond the 18 month period indicated in the letter, said an investment analyst at a hedge fund in London.\n\nAn independent auditor in the same report said: \"The group is reliant on a letter of support from a significant shareholder; as with such letters there remains a doubt whether this can be enforced in the event that such a need arises.\"\n\nIn the absence of some official announcement from the companies involved, the bonds are likely to drift, said the analyst. \"Now that Etihad has given up on Air Berlin, they could distance themselves from the debt assumption agreement with Alitalia too,\" he added. (Additional reporting by Alexander Cornwell in Dubai and Victoria Bryan in Berlin, editing by David Evans)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of {"timeCrawl": "14:33:00", "uri": "710371067", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T14:33:00Z", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "source": {"title": "Sify", "uri": "sify.com", "id": "186"}, "url": "http://www.sify.com/finance/fullstory.php?a=riqtdyighidgg&title=Etihad%2C_partners%27_bonds_drop_again_as_Air_Berlin_bankruptcy_sparks_bailout_concerns", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "By Davide Barbuscia\n\nDUBAI (Reuters) - Etihad Airways' bonds issued through a special purpose vehicle have dropped more than five points in the secondary market a day after Air Berlin, in which Etihad has a large minority stake, filed for bankruptcy protection.\n\nIn April, the \"EA Partners\" bonds dropped by almost 10 cents on the dollar after workers at the Italian carrier Alitalia - in which Etihad has a 49 percent stake - rejected the company's latest turnaround plan, blocking it from accessing rescue financing.\n\nAn \"internal debt assumption\" agreement between Etihad and Alitalia - revealed through a Fitch note in the days following Alitalia entering special administration, but had been signed earlier - put a floor under the bonds, and they subsequently bounced back almost to par value.\n\nBut it is unclear if a similar agreement is in place for Air Berlin, and some of EA Partners' creditors fear that after years of losses supporting the German carrier, Etihad might not cover the carrier's portion of debt in the SPV bonds.\n\nEtihad and Air Berlin declined to comment.\n\n\"Air Berlin adds to what has been a steady stream of bad news - whether related to Alitalia or Etihad itself,\" said a Dubai-based portfolio manager, speaking on condition of anonymity because of commercial sensitivities.\n\nEtihad's is undertaking a strategic review which began last year and saw it offload its minority stake in a regional European carrier in July before announcing on Tuesday it was no longer willing to prop up Air Berlin.\n\n\"The added problems don't necessarily mean help isn't still on the way for the bond, but it does it make it more complicated. The bond's credit enhancement has limits, and so does the appetite for bailouts,\" the portfolio manager said.\n\nYields on the notes - a $700 million bond maturing in 2020 and a $500 million bond maturing in 2021 - jumped by more than 2 percentage points after Air Berlin's bankruptcy announcement. The 2021 had a bid yield of 11.5 percent on Wednesday, up from 9.1 percent before the announcement. The 2020 notes were quoted at 12.3 percent on Wednesday, from 9.4 percent on Monday.\n\nThe EAP bonds include Etihad and several other airlines partially-owned by the Abu Dhabi carrier. The bond proceeds were used to enter into separate debt obligations with the entities involved, which included Etihad Airways, Etihad Airport Services, Alitalia, Air Berlin, and other airlines such as Air Serbia and Air Seychelles.\n\nThe bond had no cross-default provision, and according to their structure none of the SPV partners is legally obliged to support other partners in the event of a default. However, the paper is generally perceived as Etihad's credit, to the point that traders and portfolio managers have assumed in the past that reputational considerations could push the Abu Dhabi-owned company to bail out other SPV members, should the need arise.\n\nAccording to Air Berlin's 2016 annual report published in April, Etihad confirmed by letter its intention to provide the necessary support to Air Berlin to enable it to meet its financial obligations for a period of 18 months from April 28.\n\nHowever, it is not clear to what extent the letter is binding, and whether creditors can rely on it. The bonds are due beyond the 18 month period indicated in the letter, said an investment analyst at a hedge fund in London.\n\nAn independent auditor in the same report said: \"The group is reliant on a letter of support from a significant shareholder; as with such letters there remains a doubt whether this can be enforced in the event that such a need arises.\"\n\nIn the absence of some official announcement from the companies involved, the bonds are likely to drift, said the analyst. \"Now that Etihad has given up on Air Berlin, they could distance themselves from the debt assumption
