{"timeCrawl": "14:02:00", "uri": "710357271", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T14:02:00Z", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "source": {"title": "Reuters India", "uri": "in.reuters.com", "id": "630"}, "url": "https://in.reuters.com/article/air-berlin-etihad-bonds-idINKCN1AW1KH", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "DUBAI (Reuters) - Etihad Airways' bonds issued through a special purpose vehicle have dropped more than five points in the secondary market a day after Air Berlin, in which Etihad has a large minority stake, filed for bankruptcy protection.\n\nIn April, the \"EA Partners\" bonds dropped by almost 10 cents on the dollar after workers at the Italian carrier Alitalia - in which Etihad has a 49 percent stake - rejected the company's latest turnaround plan, blocking it from accessing rescue financing.\n\nAn \"internal debt assumption\" agreement between Etihad and Alitalia - revealed through a Fitch note in the days following Alitalia entering special administration, but had been signed earlier - put a floor under the bonds, and they subsequently bounced back almost to par value.\n\nBut it is unclear if a similar agreement is in place for Air Berlin, and some of EA Partners' creditors fear that after years of losses supporting the German carrier, Etihad might not cover the carrier's portion of debt in the SPV bonds.\n\nEtihad and Air Berlin declined to comment.\n\n\"Air Berlin adds to what has been a steady stream of bad news - whether related to Alitalia or Etihad itself,\" said a Dubai-based portfolio manager, speaking on condition of anonymity because of commercial sensitivities.\n\nEtihad's is undertaking a strategic review which began last year and saw it offload its minority stake in a regional European carrier in July before announcing on Tuesday it was no longer willing to prop up Air Berlin.\n\n\"The added problems don't necessarily mean help isn't still on the way for the bond, but it does it make it more complicated. The bond's credit enhancement has limits, and so does the appetite for bailouts,\" the portfolio manager said.\n\nYields on the notes - a $700 million bond maturing in 2020 and a $500 million bond maturing in 2021 - jumped by more than 2 percentage points after Air Berlin's bankruptcy announcement. The 2021 had a bid yield of 11.5 percent on Wednesday, up from 9.1 percent before the announcement. The 2020 notes were quoted at 12.3 percent on Wednesday, from 9.4 percent on Monday.\n\nThe EAP bonds include Etihad and several other airlines partially-owned by the Abu Dhabi carrier. The bond proceeds were used to enter into separate debt obligations with the entities involved, which included Etihad Airways, Etihad Airport Services, Alitalia, Air Berlin, and other airlines such as Air Serbia and Air Seychelles.\n\nThe bond had no cross-default provision, and according to their structure none of the SPV partners is legally obliged to support other partners in the event of a default. However, the paper is generally perceived as Etihad's credit, to the point that traders and portfolio managers have assumed in the past that reputational considerations could push the Abu Dhabi-owned company to bail out other SPV members, should the need arise.\n\nAccording to Air Berlin's 2016 annual report published in April, Etihad confirmed by letter its intention to provide the necessary support to Air Berlin to enable it to meet its financial obligations for a period of 18 months from April 28.\n\nHowever, it is not clear to what extent the letter is binding, and whether creditors can rely on it. The bonds are due beyond the 18 month period indicated in the letter, said an investment analyst at a hedge fund in London.\n\nAn independent auditor in the same report said: \"The group is reliant on a letter of support from a significant shareholder; as with such letters there remains a doubt whether this can be enforced in the event that such a need arises.\"\n\nIn the absence of some official announcement from the companies involved, the bonds are likely to drift, said the analyst. \"Now that Etihad has given up on Air Berlin, they could distance themselves from the debt assumption agreement with Alitalia too,\" he added.", "id": "9493778", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Etihad, partners' bonds drop again as Air Berlin bankruptcy sparks bailout concerns", Etihad Airways' bonds issued through a special purpose vehicle have dropped more than five points in the secondary market a day after Air Berlin, in which Etihad has a large minority stake, filed for bankruptcy protection.\n\nIn April, the \"EA Partners\" bonds dropped by almost 10 cents on the dollar after workers at the Italian carrier Alitalia [CAITLA.UL] - in which Etihad has a 49 percent stake - rejected the company's latest turnaround plan, blocking it from accessing rescue financing.\n\nAn \"internal debt assumption\" agreement between Etihad and Alitalia - revealed through a Fitch note in the days following Alitalia entering special administration, but had been signed earlier - put a floor under the bonds, and they subsequently bounced back almost to par value.\n\nBut it is unclear if a similar agreement is in place for Air Berlin <AB1.DE>, and some of EA Partners' creditors fear that after years of losses supporting the German carrier, Etihad might not cover the carrier's portion of debt in the SPV bonds.\n\nEtihad and Air Berlin declined to comment.\n\n\"Air Berlin adds to what has been a steady stream of bad news - whether related to Alitalia or Etihad itself,\" said a Dubai-based portfolio manager, speaking on condition of anonymity because of commercial sensitivities.\n\nEtihad's is undertaking a strategic review which began last year and saw it offload its minority stake in a regional European carrier in July before announcing on Tuesday it was no longer willing to prop up Air Berlin.\n\n\"The added problems don't necessarily mean help isn't still on the way for the bond, but it does it make it more complicated. The bond's credit enhancement has limits, and so does the appetite for bailouts,\" the portfolio manager said.\n\nYields on the notes - a $700 million bond maturing in 2020 <NL129357339=> and a $500 million bond maturing in 2021 <NL142377918=> - jumped by more than 2 percentage points after Air Berlin's bankruptcy announcement. The 2021 had a bid yield of 11.5 percent on Wednesday, up from 9.1 percent before the announcement. The 2020 notes were quoted at 12.3 percent on Wednesday, from 9.4 percent on Monday.\n\nThe EAP bonds include Etihad and several other airlines partially-owned by the Abu Dhabi carrier. The bond proceeds were used to enter into separate debt obligations with the entities involved, which included Etihad Airways, Etihad Airport Services, Alitalia, Air Berlin, and other airlines such as Air Serbia and Air Seychelles.\n\nThe bond had no cross-default provision, and according to their structure none of the SPV partners is legally obliged to support other partners in the event of a default. However, the paper is generally perceived as Etihad's credit, to the point that traders and portfolio managers have assumed in the past that reputational considerations could push the Abu Dhabi-owned company to bail out other SPV members, should the need arise.\n\nAccording to Air Berlin's 2016 annual report published in April, Etihad confirmed by letter its intention to provide the necessary support to Air Berlin to enable it to meet its financial obligations for a period of 18 months from April 28.\n\nHowever, it is not clear to what extent the letter is binding, and whether creditors can rely on it. The bonds are due beyond the 18 month period indicated in the letter, said an investment analyst at a hedge fund in London.\n\nAn independent auditor in the same report said: \"The group is reliant on a letter of support from a significant shareholder; as with such letters there remains a doubt whether this can be enforced in the event that such a need arises.\"\n\nIn the absence of some official announcement from the companies involved, the bonds are likely to drift, said the analyst. \"Now that Etihad has given up on Air Berlin, they could distance themselves from the debt assumption agreement with Alitalia too,\" he added. We avoided a national disaster,\" German daily Bild quoted CEO Thomas Winkelmann as saying.\n\nStill, the Air Berlin brand is likely to disappear, he said, with the carrier's assets set to be divided up and sold to rivals.\n\nWinkelmann also said Air Berlin's woes were partly down to constant delays to the opening of the capital's new airport, which was meant to open in 2011, replacing Air Berlin's home airport Tegel and Schoenefeld.\n\n\"We have Berlin in our name, are the prime carrier here and have designed our whole concept based on transfer traffic at this new airport. That is not possible at Tegel, my predecessors had that painful experience,\" he said in comments to weekly Die Zeit.\n\nSeveral opening dates for the planned new airport have been postponed as the project faced red tape and technical problems with smoke ventilation systems, cabling and doors.\n\nWinkelmann told Die Zeit that he believed he could save most of the Air Berlin jobs through a restructuring. We avoided a national disaster,\" German daily Bild quoted CEO Thomas Winkelmann as saying.\n\nStill, the Air Berlin brand is likely to disappear, he said, with the carrier's assets set to be divided up and sold to rivals.\n\nWinkelmann also said Air Berlin's woes were partly down to constant delays to the opening of the capital's new airport, which was meant to open in 2011, replacing Air Berlin's home airport Tegel and Schoenefeld.\n\n\"We have Berlin in our name, are the prime carrier here and have designed our whole concept based on transfer traffic at this new airport. That is not possible at Tegel, my predecessors had that painful experience,\" he said in comments to weekly Die Zeit.\n\nSeveral opening dates for the planned new airport have been postponed as the project faced red tape and technical problems with smoke ventilation systems, cabling and doors.\n\nWinkelmann told Die Zeit that he believed he could save most of the Air Berlin jobs through a restructuring.\n\n($1 = 0.8545 euros)\n\n(Reporting by Maria Sheahan; Additional reporting by Victoria Bryan; editing by Alexander Smith and David Evans)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on {"timeCrawl": "12:43:00", "uri": "710316782", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T12:43:00Z", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/ryanair-ceo-vows-to-grow-in-germany-despite-air-berlin-conspiracy/articleshow/60087691.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "By Victoria Bryan\n\nBERLIN, Aug 16 (Reuters) - Ryanair will continue to grow in Germany, even though it sees any plans by Lufthansa to take over parts of insolvent rival Air Berlin as a conspiracy to halt the Irish carrier's expansion, its chief executive told Reuters.\n\nAir Berlin on Tuesday filed for insolvency after shareholder Etihad said it would not provide any more funding, turning to the German government for a 150 million euro ($176 million) loan to help its keep planes in the air while it negotiates the sale of parts of its business to Lufthansa and one other airline.\n\nRyanair has already filed a complaint with German and EU competition authorities over the insolvency process, which it describes as a \"conspiracy\" because it believes that Lufthansa will end up with an even more dominant position in Germany.\n\n\"All this is down to prevent Ryanair growing in Germany, but it won't stop us,\" Michael O'Leary told Reuters in a telephone interview on Wednesday.\n\n\"A merger will take Lufthansa from 68 percent to 95 percent of the German domestic market and from 47 percent to 60 percent control of the total German market, which would be in breach of every known competition threshold rule and guideline in Germany and the EU,\" he said.\n\nThe German government rejected the claims of a conspiracy by Ryanair. It has said it expects no anti-trust issues because Air Berlin will be sold off in bits.\n\nO'Leary said he hoped the EU authorities would step in to force competition remedies, such as giving up airport slots to rivals.\n\nWhen asked if Ryanair could bid for Air Berlin assets, he said he expected a deal would go through too quickly to give Ryanair a chance to bid and that only unattractive airport slots would be offered up.\n\n\"We will continue to grow, we're still buying more aircraft. But we will struggle to get slots, to base more aircraft in airports like Frankfurt, Berlin, Munich,\" he said.\n\n($1 = 0.8540 euros) (Editing by Maria Sheahan)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on The price on the debt slumped to 89 cents from 96 cents a week ago, reflecting lower expected recoveries.\n\nIt's the second time in four months Etihad has rocked the airline industry by severing ties with European partners. In May, Alitalia SpA said it would start bankruptcy proceedings for the second time in a decade after the Abu Dhabi-based carrier pulled financing, sparking a yield surge in EA bonds.\n\nEtihad bought a 29 percent stake in Air Berlin back in 2012 as it sought to build a network of minority investments that would help funnel more passengers into its Abu Dhabi hub, but that strategy is now being dismantled following the departure of CEO James Hogan earlier this year.\n\n\"Etihad recently wrote off $808 million exposure to its partner airlines,\" CreditSights Inc. analyst Roger King said in a research note. \"Fundamentally, the bonds should drop to 60.\"\n\nEtihad and its associate airlines sold the bonds two years ago, attracting orders for the 2020 issue at a yield of 6.875 percent. The deal was later given a speculative-grade rating of 'B-' by Fitch Ratings, which noted that \"the credit quality of the obligors varies substantially\" given the entities involved. At the time, those included Etihad and its airport services subsidiary, Air Berlin, Alitalia, Air Serbia and Air Seychelles Ltd.\n\nAccording to Bloomberg data, Fitch currently rates the deal as 'CCC' It has said it expects no anti-trust issues because Air Berlin will be sold off in bits.\n\nO'Leary said he hoped the EU authorities would step in to force competition remedies, such as giving up airport slots to rivals.\n\nWhen asked if Ryanair could bid for Air Berlin assets, he said he expected a deal would go through too quickly to give Ryanair a chance to bid and that only unattractive airport slots would be offered up.\n\n\"We will continue to grow, we're still buying more aircraft. But we will struggle to get slots, to base more aircraft in airports like Frankfurt, Berlin, Munich,\" he said. {"timeCrawl": "13:23:00", "uri": "710337147", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T09:43:00Z", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "source": {"title": "TheStreet", "uri": "thestreet.com", "id": "465"}, "url": "https://www.thestreet.com/story/14273113/1/lufthansa-and-ryanair-likely-winners-from-air-berlin-collapse.html", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "Air Berlin's bankruptcy means about 3.4% of Europe's short-haul market is up for grabs.\n\nLufthansa (DLAKF) and Ryanair (RYAAY) could be the big winners following the collapse of Air Berlin, one of Europe's biggest carriers, with both airlines poised to pick up short-haul market share into and out of Germany.\n\nAir Berlin declared bankruptcy on Tuesday, August 15, after Middle Eastern backer Etihad Aviation Group pulled finance guarantees. Germany's No.2 Airline will keep flying for the time being after its larger domestic rival Lufthansa and the German government stepped in to prevent a complete collapse.\n\nAir Berlin plc shares traded in the early afternoon Wednesday at \u20ac0.414 ($0.48), down 18% on the day and 46% since news of the bankruptcy broke on Tuesday. Lufthansa shares were back to Tuesday's closing price of \u20ac20.66 after an initial surge of almost 1%. Ryanair was up 1.2% on Wednesday to \u20ac19.44 and has climbed 4.7% over two days.\n\n\"We see Lufthansa and Ryanair as the biggest potential beneficiaries from possible reduced supply in the medium term...with other European airlines also benefiting from better short-haul supply and demand,\" wrote Goldman Sachs analysts including Daniil Federov and Patrick Creuset. \"In the long term, we believe that legacy exits in Europe should support market share gains for LCCs (low cost carriers) and for Ryanair in particular.\"\n\nAir Berlin has about 3.4% of Europe's short-haul market and 13% of the German market. Its collapse means that about 5% of Europe's short-haul capacity is now operated by bankrupt carriers, after Italy's Alitalia tumbled into administration in May when its employees rejected a restructuring plan. {"timeCrawl": "14:25:00", "uri": "709811203", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T14:25:00Z", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "source": {"title": "Bloomberg Business", "uri": "bloomberg.com", "id": "1749"}, "url": "https://www.bloomberg.com/gadfly/articles/2017-08-15/air-berlin-s-magnificent-flying-cash-burn-machine", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "If you want to know why Air Berlin Plc has filed for insolvency protection, look at this chart:\n\nYep, those free cash flow numbers are all negative and they add up to minus-2 billion euros (minus-$2.3 billion).\n\nThat wasn't insurmountable when anchor shareholder Etihad Airways PJSC was propping up the company. But on Tuesday, Etihad, which has a 29 percent stake and supplies plenty of debt financing, effectively pulled the plug. It won't provide any more financial help and its two representatives have quit Air Berlin's board.\n\nAir Berlin's collapse is alarming for its almost 9,000 employees, but it's been a long time coming. The company has about 1.2 billion euros in net debt and minus-1.8 billion euros of shareholder equity, according to Bloomberg data. Compared to budget carriers such as Ryanair Holdings Plc and EasyJet Plc, which are busy adding capacity and cutting fares, Air Berlin's cost base was simply too high.\n\nGulf carriers like Eithad were once feared in Europe but they're struggling now, as Gadfly colleague David Fickling has explained. Etihad's strategy of buying minority stakes in various far-flung airlines appears to have been particularly ill-conceived: the Abu Dhabi hub carrier reported a $1.9 billion loss for its 2017 fiscal year. Another Eithad investment, Alitalia SpA, filed for bankruptcy in May.\n\nIn theory, these airline failures should be an opportunity for the needed consolidation of Europe's skies, which are far more fragmented than in the U.S. It makes European airlines susceptible to adding too much capacity, at little profit. The five biggest carriers on the continent control just 46 percent of the market, whereas in the U.S. just four carriers have a stranglehold on more than two-thirds of the domestic market.\n\nBut don't bet on things changing in a hurry. Lufthansa hopes to profit from its rival's troubles and has already leased some of its planes for its own new low-cost airline, Eurowings. The German government, perhaps conscious of federal elections next month, has offered Air Berlin a bridging loan.\n\nRyanair and its ilk will be scouring for opportunities too to push into the German market. The Irish carrier is one of several airlines to have submitted non-binding bids for Alitalia. That could mean Europe's oversupply of airline seats ends up being preserved -- albeit at airlines with stronger balance sheets. Expect more of the same rather than up, up and away.\n\nThis column does not necessarily reflect the opinion of Bloomberg LP and its owners.", "id": "9295860", "details": {"liCnt": 12}, "date": Sanger took over as independent chairman late last year after John Stumpf, Wells Fargo's then CEO and chairman, abruptly resigned in the aftermath of the bank's sales practices scandal.\n\nWhile Sanger was applauded for the sales-scandal investigation, investors said he and the board shared some responsibility for how Wells Fargo operated in the years before the scandal broke.\n\nThe San Francisco bank said that retired PricewaterhouseCooper executive Juan Pujadas will join the board.\n\nCynthia Milligan and Susan Swenson will retire from the board at the end of this year and the bank will add three independent directors.\n\nGermany's second-largest carrier, Air Berlin, is filing for bankruptcy protection after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad of Abu Dhabi, said it would make no more financing available.\n\nThe airline said Tuesday that after Etihad pulled funding, it \"came to the conclusion that there was no further positive way ahead for Air Berlin.\"\n\nTo allay travelers' fears that they could be stranded on summer holiday, the German government immediately said it would provide a loan of $177 million so the airline it can continue flights for the time being.\n\n\"We're in a time when many tens of thousands of travelers and vacationers are in multiple international holiday spots,\" the Economy and Transport ministries said. \"The return flights of these travelers back to Germany with Air Berlin would not have been otherwise possible.\"\n\nEconomy Minister Brigitte Zypries told reporters the money was expected to last for three months.\n\nThe union representing workers called it a \"severe blow\" for the more-than 7,000 employees of Air Berlin.\n\nAir Berlin has been posting losses for years. {"timeCrawl": "18:34:00", "uri": "709919968", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T18:28:00Z", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "source": {"title": "The Guardian", "uri": "theguardian.com", "id": "260"}, "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/business/nils-pratley-on-finance/2017/aug/15/easyjet-ryanair-air-berlin-lufthansa", "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3363010", "body": "The Irish carrier is right to smell a stitch-up to hand the ailing airline to Lufthansa - but rivals should not be forced to overpay\n\nThere's nothing like the failure of a competitor to perk up other airline's share prices. Sure enough, as Air Berlin filed for insolvency on Tuesday, almost every other European airline gained altitude. EasyJet's shares were up 4.5%, Ryanair's by 3.3%, British Airways owner IAG's by 2.9%, and even little Wizz Air improved 4.6%.\n\nThe reaction makes sense. Air Berlin has been loss-making for years but it is still a top 10 European airline, measured by numbers of passengers, and thus has been able to irritate rivals by merely surviving. That is why one reason why low-cost winners, such as easyJet and Ryanair, grumble about irrational economics and the current state of overcapacity in the market.\n\nIn a business like aviation, it is rarely safe to assume any airline's financial crisis is terminal. But Air Berlin's troubles, like those at Alitalia (now in administration), do look destined to lead a major restructuring of some form. Credit lines from the German government are only a temporary measure. The harder fact is that Etihad, a big shareholder in both Air Berlin and Alitalia, seems to have abandoned its strange strategy of throwing millions of euros at loss-making investments.\n\nShould either easyJet or Ryanair exploit a once-in-a-generation opportunity to pick up the pieces, buy Air Berlin and bag a big slice of the German market? Ryanair has spoken about wanting a 20% share there eventually and easyJet has been expanding too.\n\nBoth should tread carefully. The prize assets are slots at big German airports. If they become available on a clean basis, then fine. But restructuring a loss-making airline of the size of Air Berlin could be a messy business.\n\nYet Ryanair has certainly got the right idea in demanding that state-aid rules are followed. The Irish carrier smells \"an obvious conspiracy\" to deliver Air Berlin on a debt-free basis to national flag-carrier Lufthansa. A stitch-up would indeed be outrageous. It is worth making a fuss at Brussels - just don't get mugged into overpaying as an alternative.\n\nFund managers shouldn't get too pumped up over pay pressure\n\nThe City's fund managers would like you to know they are not a bunch of supine lickspittles on the troubled issue of executive pay. On the contrary, says Chris Cummings, chief executive of trade body the Investment Association, 2017's round of annual meetings shows shareholders \"are flexing their muscles and holding big business to account\".\n\nReally? This claim seems to rest on \"dissent\" being defined as a vote of 20% or more against a company's pay resolution. True, such a level can be noteworthy in a field where Soviet-style majorities are commonplace. But would you really describe a 20% vote as a muscular show of force? If you score a fifth of goals in a football match, you've lost.\n\nThe association's curious yardstick is also capable of generating flattering conclusions whatever the reading. When the number of \"rebellions\" falls, as at FTSE 100 companies, it means \"companies have listened\". But when the figure increases, as at FTSE 250 firms, we're told it doesn't mean the board has closed its ears; rather, it shows the companies are \"in the investor spotlight\".\n\nTo be fair to the association, its work behind the scenes almost certainly contributed to six FTSE 350 companies withdrawing contentious pay proposals last year instead of risking a defeat. That is a significant figure. The association is also plainly on the side of reform. It has backed the mandatory publication of pay ratios and wants boardroom pay to be simpler.\n\nJolly good, but before boasting about its members' toughness, the association needs to look outside the window. FTSE 100 chief executives took a collective 17% pay cut to \"only\" \u00a34.5m last year but, to most observers, the big new factor was the government's threat to introduce pay ratios, workers on pay committees and annual binding votes. Those ideas probably persuaded a few pay committees to tone things down, at least temporarily.\n\nYes, greater fund manager pressure may have helped at the margin, but, please, don't tell us shareholder activism is winning. If it were that easy, the government wouldn't be contemplating reform after so many years of dancing around the subject.\n\nGovernment still on the wrong track over rail fares\n\nAnnoyed that rail fares will go up by 3.6%? So you should be. Linking the annual increase to July's retail prices index, which consistently gives higher readings than the consumer prices index, makes no sense. The Bank of England uses CPI for inflation-targeting. CPI is used for calculating annual increases to benefits. And CPI forms one part of the triple-lock on pensions. By rights, RPI should be history.\n\nTo quote the Office for National Statistics: \"We know there will be a focus on the RPI this month, but the national statistician has been clear it is not a good measure and we do not recommend its use.\" The ONS trots out the same line every August. It's time ministers noticed.", "id": "9337580", "details": {"liCnt": 864}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "EasyJet and Ryanair should be wary of launching Air Berlin bid | Nils Pratley", "image": This announcement comes as a result of one of its major shareholders withdrawing all of their support. The German government has announced that it will provide AirBerlin with a loan to get the carrier through the busy summer travel season to minimize impact on travelers.\n\nEtihad Airways, an Abu Dhabi-based airline, previously owned 29.2 percent stake in the company. Etihad has stated that it can no longer continue funnelling money into the German carrier that does not seem to have the ability to overcome its losses. As recently as April 2017, Etihad had pumped in nearly $300 million dollars to help AirBerlin stay afloat. Now, after six years of pouring money into the failing airline, Etihad has had enough.\n\nAirBerlin moves nearly 80,000 people every day. Most of these flights are short haul flights within the European region. Despite these high numbers, AirBerlin cannot seem to stop losing money.\n\nThe German Economy and Transport Ministries have stated that they will provide the airline with a $177 million bridge loan to get them through the next three months till the summer traveling season comes to an end. This was the only way to ensure that travelers who are out of the country have a guaranteed way to get home.\n\nLufthansa, Germany's largest airline, and another unnamed carrier, are currently in talks to take over some of AirBerlin's operations. At this time, airline unions are trying to secure positions for the 7,000 employees of AirBerlin.\n\nThis withdrawal of support by Etihad comes only three months after it pulled out all support for Other partners included Jet Airways, Air Serbia and Air Seychelles.\n\nThe proceeds from the deals represented separate debt obligations of each partner as a percentage of the total amount raised.\n\nFor example, Alitalia and Air Berlin each have an 18.85% exposure of the overall principal in the first EA Partner bond that was issued. That deal, which took place in 2015, raised US$700m through a five-year note\n\nThere is no cross-default provision and none of the partners are legally obliged to support each other in the event of Nach Angaben aus Wien soll das unbedingt verhindert werden. Dem Niki-Betriebsrat zufolge ist Air Berlin daran interessiert, den Betrieb bei Niki am Laufen zu halten.\n\nDie \u00f6sterreichische Tochter von Air Berlin soll nicht mit in den Strudel der Insolvenz gerissen werden. Es gebe die Zusage der Gesch\u00e4ftsf\u00fchrung, dass der vom Ex-Rennfahrer Niki Lauda gegr\u00fcndeten Niki das n\u00f6tige Geld zur Verf\u00fcgung gestellt werde, sagte Betriebsrat Stefan Tankovits in Wien. \"Wir haben auch die Anzeichen bekommen, dass Air Berlin sehr interessiert daran ist, hier den Betrieb am Laufen zu halten, um uns dann m\u00f6glichst reibungslos verkaufen zu k\u00f6nnen.\" Bisher seien alle \u00dcberweisungen aus Deutschland erfolgt, erg\u00e4nzte Peter Stattmann von der Gewerkschaft GPA.\n\n\"Wir lassen niemanden im Regen stehen\", versprach \u00d6sterreichs Verkehrsminister J\u00f6rg Leichtfried. \"Unser Ziel ist, heimische Arbeitspl\u00e4tze zu sichern und daf\u00fcr zu sorgen, dass die \u00d6sterreicherinnen und \u00d6sterreicher gut von ihrem Urlaub nach Hause kommen.\" Niki hat bisher nicht Insolvenz angemeldet, h\u00e4ngt aber finanziell am Tropf von Air Berlin, bei der die Zahlungen der Flugg\u00e4ste ankommen. In der Insolvenz sind \u00dcberweisungen aber nicht unproblematisch, weil es darum geht, m\u00f6glichst viel Geld f\u00fcr die Gl\u00e4ubiger zu sichern.\n\nAuszuschlie\u00dfen sei eine Insolvenz von Niki nicht, sagte Betriebsrat Tankovits. \"Wir sind auf alles vorbereitet.\" Nach der Ansicht von Gewerkschafter Stattmann sind die Gehaltszahlungen Ende August die n\u00e4chste Nagelprobe. \"Wir werden sehen - es ist uns zugesagt worden - ob das auch so eintrifft.\" Verkehrsminister Leichtfried sagte zu, dass sich die Regierung in Wien im Falle einer Insolvenz um eine L\u00f6sung bem\u00fchen werde.\n\nNiki geh\u00f6rt zu den wertvollsten Verm\u00f6genswerten, die Air Berlin in der Insolvenz zu Geld machen kann. Verhandlungen mit der Lufthansa \u00fcber eine \u00dcbernahme von Teilen von Air Berlin, darunter Niki, laufen. Interesse an der \u00f6sterreichischen Airline haben einem Insider zufolge aber auch andere Unternehmen angemeldet, unter anderem die britische Billigfluglinie Easyjet. Attraktiv sind vor allem die Start- und Landerechte von Niki am Flughafen in der NRW-Metropole D\u00fcsseldorf.\n\nUnterdessen warnte Bundeswirtschaftsministerin Brigitte Zypries die Lufthansa davor, sich einer \u00dcbernahme von Air Berlin zu sicher zu sein. Aus Wettbewerbsgr\u00fcnden m\u00fcsse mehr als eine Airline zum Zug kommen. \"Nat\u00fcrlich ist die Bundesregierung da nicht vorfestgelegt\", sagte ein Sprecher des Ministeriums.\n\nVerkehrsminister Alexander Dobrindt hatte sich daf\u00fcr starkgemacht, dass die Lufthansa die wesentlichen Teile von Air Berlin bekommt. Das Wirtschaftsministerium stellte klar, dass die Bundesregierung an den Verhandlungen \u00fcber die Zukunft von Air Berlin nicht beteiligt sei. Der Bund hatte einen Massekredit von 150 Millionen Euro bereitgestellt. {"eng-3363010": {"articles": {"count": 1, "page": 1, "results": [{"sim": 0.4823529422283173, "details": {}, "storyUri": "deu-755179", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9912836", "lang": "deu", "source": {"uri": "euractiv.de", "title": "EurActiv.de", "id": "6642"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3363010", "image": "http://www.euractiv.de/wp-content/uploads/sites/4/2017/08/shutterstock_371947684.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.euractiv.de/section/finanzen-und-wirtschaft/news/air-berlin-sorge-um-arbeitsplaetze-zukunft-von-oesterreichischer-tochter-unklar/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:19:00", "title": "Air Berlin: Sorge um Arbeitspl\u00e4tze, Zukunft von \u00f6sterreichischer Tochter unklar", "uri": "711489182", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T14:19:00Z", "wgt": 1, "time": "14:19:00", "body": "Auch die Zukunft der \u00f6sterreichischen Niki ist nach der Air Berlin-Pleite ungewiss. [Shutterstock]\n\nDie Dienstleistungsgewerkschaft ver.di \u00e4u\u00dfert \"gro\u00dfe Sorge um Arbeitspl\u00e4tze der Besch\u00e4ftigten\". Der Betriebsrat der \u00f6sterreichischen Tochtergesellschaft Niki ist hingegen zuversichtlich.\n\n\"Wir haben gro\u00dfe Sorge um die Arbeitspl\u00e4tze der Besch\u00e4ftigten\", sagte Christian Behle vom ver.di-Bundesvorstand. \"Wir erwarten von Air Berlin, dass vorrangig die Interessen der Besch\u00e4ftigten ber\u00fccksichtigt werden und das Unternehmen mit Hochdruck daran arbeitet, tragf\u00e4hige und gute Konzepte zu entwickeln, um m\u00f6glichst viele Arbeitspl\u00e4tze zu retten. Dazu bedarf es einer Transparenz und der Einbeziehung der Gewerkschaft in die weiteren Planungen.\"\n\nDer Generalbevollm\u00e4chtigte der insolventen Fluggesellschaft, Frank Kebekus, gibt sich optimistisch, dass die \"Arbeitspl\u00e4tze der meisten der 8600 Mitarbeiter gerettet werden k\u00f6nnen.\" Man befinde sich in guten Gespr\u00e4chen mit potenziellen K\u00e4ufern.\n\nVerunsicherung gibt es auch unter den Besch\u00e4ftigten der \u00f6sterreichischen Air Berlin-Tochter Niki. Wie die Nachrichtenagentur Reuters berichtete, gehen die dortigen Arbeitnehmervertreter jedoch nicht davon aus, von der Insolvenz bedroht zu sein. Betriebsrat Stefan Tankovits in Wien: \"Wir haben auch die Anzeichen bekommen, dass Air Berlin sehr interessiert daran ist, hier den Betrieb am Laufen zu halten, um uns dann m\u00f6glichst reibungslos verkaufen zu k\u00f6nnen.\" Auszuschlie\u00dfen sei eine Insolvenz aber nicht. \"Wir sind auf alles vorbereitet.\"\n\nAir Berlin hatte Anfang der Woche Insolvenz angemeldet, nachdem der arabische Gro\u00dfaktion\u00e4r Etihad seine finanzielle Unterst\u00fctzung gestrichen hatte. Interesse an Teil\u00fcbernahmen wurden bisher sowohl seitens der Lufthansa wie auch vom Billigflieger Easyjet angemeldet. Die Bundesregierung hatte angek\u00fcndigt, Air Berlin mit einem Kredit zu unterst\u00fctzen, um den Flugbetrieb zun\u00e4chst abzusichern.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [], "concepts":
